PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Schacht who, I think, regards himself as the minister for organising Labor's electoral support in South Australia. I refer the minister to his threat to withdraw federal funding from the multifunction polis if the Liberals won the election in South Australia. In view of the overwhelming endorsement of Dean Brown and his team, does the minister still stand by that threat? Has the minister communicated to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, the extent to which Labor's election lies, the fuel tax and the wine tax contributed to the Liberals' consolidating their support in South Australia?

—I was hoping I would get this question. With regard to my electoral record in South Australia, I point out that during my nearly 8 1/2 years as party secretary I never lost a Labor-held state or federal seat. Senator Minchin, who was then the party secretary of the Liberal Party, would acknowledge that I won every contest in South Australia when I was secretary. I never lost. I gave the Liberal Party more than a fair belting around the head.

PARA.TAB: Everyone acknowledges, and I certainly do, that the number one issue regarding the South Australian election was a state issue—the State Bank. The electorate made its judgment accordingly. There can be no excuse by the Labor Party. The State Bank collapse and the $3 billion bail out was the number one issue at the election.

I have said before and I say again that the MFP is an international project. If Mr Brown and the Liberal Party in government wish to turn it into a limited technology park venture, without its international or national connections, it will then change the whole scope of the MFP and the basis on which the federal government has contributed money.

The money is contributed to the MFP in two ways. It is contributed under the better cities program. That program is under negotiation. The matter has been raised that the better cities money is part of the proportion allocated to the states. It is argued that that money could be redirected elsewhere under negotiation. The other specific allocation of money is by the federal government to the administration of the MFP because it is an international project.

I emphasise again to Senator Hill that he should talk to his colleague in South Australia Mr Brown and point out to him that the MFP is an international and national project, not a local government technology park. I think if he understands that he will understand why the federal government is supporting the development of the MFP, which is a long term project.

Senator Hill raised other issues about the state election campaign purely to try to get some comfort from the election win. People baying on the other side want that comfort because they realise that had they adopted similar tactics in the March election campaign, they would not be sitting on the other side. It was their stupidity that lost the unlosable election. I think Dean Brown made some adjustment to his policies to ensure that he could capitalise on the State Bank debacle in South Australia. All in all, the election victory for the Liberal Party in South Australia is of no comfort to the Liberal Party here. It was the monumental political incompetence of those opposite that cost them the election in March this year. That is why we are still sitting on this side and those opposite are still sitting on the other side after 13 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Schacht is misleading the Senate because the state Labor Party in South Australia now has fewer state seats than we have federal seats.
—This is another occasion of people not raising proper points of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism. I understand that the latest figures from the Bureau of Statistics show that there has been a significant increase in international visitor arrivals to Australia. Is the minister aware of these figures and is he able to provide any further information on international visitor arrivals to Australia?

—This is good news for the development of the tourist industry and for the economy in Australia. Of course, members opposite may not want to hear it because they always try to ignore the very good recent economic news. I am aware of the Bureau of Statistics figures on visitor arrivals. They confirm that the Australian tourism industry continues to attract increasing numbers of international tourists.

PARA.TAB: Overseas arrivals for September, a traditionally slow month for international tourism to Australia, were at a record high of 224,000. That represents an 18 per cent increase, compared with September 1992. For the first nine months of 1993 international tourist arrivals increased by 16 per cent compared with the same period in 1992. It is also significant that our embassies and consulates, especially those in the Asian region, have reported an increased level of visa issuances over the past few months. Airlines are experiencing high levels of demand for travel to Australia in December. All the indications are that in 1993 we will break the three million barrier for international visitor arrivals.

Another pleasing aspect of the increased growth in international tourism is the increasing numbers from both established and new markets. This increased diversification is highlighted by a 75 per cent increase in arrivals from Taiwan, a 71 per cent increase from Korea and a 51 per cent increase from Indonesia. Also, despite the downturn in the Japanese economy, the Japanese market has continued to grow. In fact, while the outbound tourism from Japan has decreased in 1993, the number of Japanese tourists visiting Australia has grown by six per cent and Japan continues to be our largest single market, followed by New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the USA.

In 1995 the Australian Tourist Commission anticipates 3.8 million international tourists to visit Australia, and this figure is expected to grow to 6.8 million by the year 2000. Of course, we expect the successful bid for the Olympic Games in Sydney in 2000 to further enhance the number of visitors coming. With that in mind, both the government and the industry are already planning on how best to capitalise on this exposure. We need to ensure that we maximise the numbers of international tourists not only in the year 2000, but also in the years leading up to that. This is one more example of where the government, in partnership with industry—and we emphasise that it is in partnership with industry—is building more strength into the Australian economy and providing opportunities for new employment growth. The industry is to be congratulated for its efforts to make the tourist industry one of the real success stories in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer the minister to the proposed Mackay joint venture sugar refinery which would have moved Australia into the expanding $5 billion a year refined sugar export market for the first time, and which the Trade Practices Commission refused to authorise. I refer also to support for entry into the refined sugar export market from the Industry Commission, support for the project from Kelloggs, ABARE and the Prices Surveillance Authority, strong support for the project from the Queensland government and the Department of Primary Industry and support from the government's own Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Like its own departments and agencies and Labor state government, does the government also support the joint venture going ahead? If so, what does it intend to do to ensure that it does proceed?

—Senator Boswell has been well noted for his interest in small business issues in this parliament, particularly the role of the Trade Practices Commission. In the past he has insisted on the Trade Practices Commission taking action to ensure that competition is allowed and that small business gets a fair share. He has often asked the TPC to be pro-active in intervening in that way against monopoly activities. Therefore, it was with some surprise initially that I heard that he supported this merger taking place and that he is now criticising the TPC decision. He has made these representations to me on a number of occasions.

PARA.TAB: Although part of this matter is dealt with by my colleague the Treasurer and the Assistant Treasurer, represented by Senator McMullan, it is true that there are industry aspects about this that are important. It is true that the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development closely considered the joint venture, for which applicants sought approval from the TPC. The department concluded that the application was likely to result in: firstly, a significant increase in real value of exports; secondly, the fostering of business efficiency; and, thirdly, rationalisation resulting in more efficient allocation of resources. My department made it quite clear that it saw a number of merits in the proposal.

On 8 December the TPC—which, of course, is an independent statutory authority—released its final determination rejecting CSR's application for authorisation of a joint venture involving other sugar refineries. The TPC found—and I summarise—that CSR's involvement in the project was likely to, firstly, substantially lessen competition which would otherwise arise from the presence of new competitors. Secondly, enhanced exports would constitute a public benefit, but this benefit was not attributable to the proposed joint venture. It found that enhanced sugar exports are likely to occur with or without the joint venture. Thirdly, it found that the benefits of rationalisation were not likely to flow through to the public. Fourthly, there were not sufficient public benefits to outweigh the anti-competitive detriments, and for this reason the TPC refused that application for authorisation.

As you can see, Mr President, the advice from my own department, when it considered this matter, made a number of positive points. The TPC obviously took that and other information on hand and it came down against the proposal. I emphasise also that the TPC is the government's independent competition expert and it would be inappropriate for the government to interfere with its administrative proceedings. While the government has power to direct the TPC to place special emphasis on particular matters, it cannot direct the TPC to come to a particular decision in authorisation proceedings relating to individual cases. The joint applicants are able to lodge an appeal from the TPC's decision with the trade practices tribunal within 21 days of the determination. That tribunal will be able to independently assess the decision of the TPC and that is the proper and legal process to go through. It is up to the participants, particularly CSR, to determine whether they wish to take that choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer, in which he quoted extensively from the TPC report. I advise him that I can read the TPC report as well as he can. My question was: does his government support the amalgamation? If it does—I would suspect it does because everyone else does, including CSR, the sugar industry, the milling industry, the Queensland government and, I suspect, most people—what does it intend to do about it?

—I thought I had clearly indicated DITARD's response. As minister for the department, I can state that our view is that there were a number of positive things about the merger for the future of the industry. However, I emphasise that the TPC is an independent body and I would imagine that some members opposite would be the first to scream if the government interfered in the independent processes of the TPC, so we are damned if we do and we are damned if we don't. However, because of Senator Boswell's consistent interest in this issue, I will have further discussions with my colleagues—the Treasurer and the Assistant Treasurer—and come back with a further response, but I emphasise that the company does have the right to appeal.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and refers to the progress towards democracy in South Africa. How significant are recent political events for the transition to a non-racial democracy in South Africa—events which have seen the establishment of the Transitional Executive Council on 7 December, and a decision by the multi-party negotiators to bring the apartheid homelands system to an end? Secondly, what assistance will Australia provide to elections in South Africa? Will Australia join other members of the international community in observing the country's first non-racial elections in April next year?

—It is important to state for the record—we were a bit distracted from doing so last week by other things—how warmly Australia welcomes the establishment on 7 December of the Transitional Executive Council which, for the first time in South Africa's history, does acknowledge the role of all South Africans, regardless of race, in the government of the country. The TEC will work alongside the South African government to, in effect, level the playing field in the lead-up to the elections next year.

PARA.TAB: Three days after the establishment of the TEC, we saw the Nobel Peace Prize conferred upon President Frederik de Klerk and the President of the ANC, Nelson Mandela. Again, I think it is appropriate to congratulate those two on the crucial personal and political commitment they put into the negotiation process, which has produced these results.

The successful outcome of the negotiations was a remarkable achievement and a great tribute to all those South Africans who have committed themselves to a peaceful democratic ending to apartheid. We had already welcomed the agreement of an interim constitution, which is now expected to pass into law during the current session of parliament. Provision in the constitution for the repeal of the legislation establishing the so-called homelands is especially significant in this respect and, when this happens, one of the really crucial last vestiges of the apartheid system will have been swept away.

We hope very much that the various conservative parties which have boycotted the multi-party talks in recent times—including the white right wing groups, the Inkatha Freedom Party and some of the homeland governments—continue their talks with the ruling national party and the ANC. We hope, furthermore, that they will join the majority of South Africans in supporting that transition to democratic elections and the new post-apartheid government, and will end any threats of secession and violence. I hope that a number of those opposite who, over the years, have given strong support to Chief Buthelezi will exercise whatever residual influence they might possess in this respect to encourage Chief Buthelezi and the IFP to now participate in these talks and not to persist with the rather extraordinary liaison in which he has recently been engaged with the extreme right wing white parties.

Finally, the Australian government is committed to doing everything we can to help the transition to democracy through the coming critical months. We joined other Commonwealth countries at the heads of government meeting in Cyprus on 25 October in reaffirming support for the elections next April. We will contribute towards a Commonwealth group to monitor those elections. We also stand ready to provide technical assistance to the electoral process. We are also continuing our participation in COMSA—the Commonwealth observer mission to South Africa—which is working with UN and other international observers and with members of the South African peace accord to try to help bring an end to violence. We would expect to maintain our participation in COMSA until after the elections in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health and relates to his package of health reforms. I acknowledge that he has consulted with a number of individuals about his plans but, given the considerable concern about his proposals now being expressed by almost every health related organisation in the country, does he believe that he has an obligation to consult far more widely and fully before putting these proposals to cabinet? Will the minister agree to put the cabinet discussions on hold until he has given the Australian public and interested health organisations an opportunity to comment fully and publicly on the details of his proposals?

—No. I have consulted pretty widely. When one seeks to bring about any major reform package it is not at all unusual for community groups to react, particularly when they see anything that is traditional under threat. In two areas of the package that has certainly been the case. One was the levy proposal, which, as has already been announced, will be referred to a working party between the caucus of the Labor Party and the ACTU to discuss over the course of the next few months. That is quite sensible.

PARA.TAB: The second area is that part of the package which refers to allowing a gap for the medical cost and then making sure there is only one fee and effectively, therefore, putting a cap on surgeons' fees. While I know that is different because there is a gap involved—and that will obviously upset some people—the truth is that when ACOSS and ACA find themselves lined up with the AMA and the surgeons they should wake up that they are on the wrong tram.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer the minister to the answer given by the foreign minister last week regarding the secret United States nuclear testing program and, in particular, to his statement that Australia had no knowledge of these tests. Is it a fact that a United States geological and geophysical research station has been operating at Alice Springs under an agreement signed in 1954? Is it also a fact that this facility was converted to so-called joint status in 1978? Can the minister explain how it is that this facility, which has been operating on Australian soil for almost 30 years with the specific purpose of monitoring seismic disturbances to distinguish nuclear explosions, has failed to detect or report any of the secret United States nuclear tests?

—I appreciate that Senator Margetts gave my office some notice of this just before question time, but I cannot see that this question has any relevance to my portfolio. I understand that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, will give a full response to this question at the end of question time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The minister should be aware of claims published in today's issue of the Australian Financial Review that industrial relations on the Australian waterfront is heading back to the bad old days of confrontation.
—You would hope!
—No. I do not say that whatsoever, as an exporter. What action does the government propose to take to keep the waterfront reform on track?

—The entire purpose of the government's reform program—and it has succeeded in doing it—is to get this industry into the same situation as every other industry in Australia, and that is where employers and employees are not having their hands held by the government every five minutes in a national labour pool with the government inextricably involved in the relationships in this industry. The whole purpose of that reform exercise was to put this industry in a situation where the employers and the employees work out their arrangements themselves.

PARA.TAB: The article goes on to acknowledge something that Senator Panizza has not acknowledged, and that is that the federal government's waterfront reform program has brought about a fundamental structural change in the Australian stevedoring industry to make that industry subject to the same employment arrangements as other Australian industries. This has brought about, as the article acknowledges, direct productivity and efficiency benefits, but it has also brought about, as I have acknowledged here in the Senate on many occasions, the need for those parties to reassess their commercial and industrial practices and relationships. That industry has been operating for almost half a century under these outmoded arrangements.

As I have told this Senate before, when the formal period of waterfront reform had concluded—which it did about a year ago—and when the enterprise agreements that were put into place under those formalised arrangements under a structured government program had concluded, there would be a period of time when the first enterprise agreements were negotiated party to party and these sorts of strains would be evident, and indeed they have been. For the first time ever the government has provided for this industry the basis of a strongly competitive environment.

Since the completion of the program in October 1992, these competitive pressures have directly resulted in the merger of two stevedoring companies into Australian Stevedores in order to provide a stronger and more commercially viable competitor to Conaust, additional changes to waterfront work practices, and further changes—downwards—to waterfront employment levels. Both employers and employees are now adapting to this changed commercial and industrial environment.

It should be noted that over the past 12 months the changes have been negotiated with relatively little disruption to stevedoring operations. I might add that these changes have brought about pressures, because the amalgamation that I have just referred to resulted in the need for significant additional redundancies. At the end of the formalised process we had removed from the Australian stevedoring work force almost six out of 10 employees. In addition to the loss of those workers to the industry, the recent merger of the companies to form Australian Stevedores resulted in a further number of redundancies that totalled almost 250 at the last count that I saw.

These changes have brought about pressures, but the pressures are necessary for the further reform of the Australian waterfront. I am confident that the competitive arrangements that this government has put into place will continue to provide for further improvements and enhancements and further competition in the Australian waterfront industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. I understand that the Australian Bureau of Statistics released figures today about the number of people who worked in cultural and leisure activities in the 12 months ending March 1993. What do these figures show about the size and scope of cultural industries within Australia? Do they confirm the government's view about the economic worth of cultural industries and their importance as a key source of employment opportunities?

—What we have had released today is probably the most important set of statistical data about cultural industries in Australia. It should make very interesting reading for those people in this place who from time to time when the arts are discussed say, `What about the concern of working people?' I have been spending some effort during the course of this year in seeking to persuade Australians, my colleagues and the Senate that this is an important industry and that it creates a lot of jobs. But I have to confess that I substantially underestimated the amount of employment and the amount of community activity in this area.

PARA.TAB: The most significant factor to which the ABS draws attention is that during the past 12 months 1.6 million people—that is, 11.8 per cent of the population—over 15 years of age were involved in work in culture and leisure activities. On top of this, another one million people saw their involvement in culture and leisure activities as a hobby. These figures are very large, but when one breaks them down what one needs to look at is the number of people actually in paid employment in this area because many of those people are working in a voluntary capacity.

What really struck me when I read the figures today was that more than 550,000 Australians are in paid employment, full-time or part-time, in cultural and leisure activities such as heritage, museums, literature, library, archives, music, performing arts, visual arts, film, video, radio, TV, education, festival and arts administration.

So, in that narrow definition of `arts and cultural and leisure activities', there are more than 550,000 people who are receiving payment for their participation, with more than 100,000 of them in full-time employment in those industries. The fact that more than two million Australians are giving a substantial amount of their time to these activities shows not only the enormous size of the voluntary sector but also that the figures we have used in the past, drawn from more general population statistics, greatly underestimate the scope of employment opportunities in the arts. These new figures certainly confirm the government's view about the economic worth of cultural industries and their importance as a source of employment in the economy.

As the nature of employment changes and with the growth in employment that is under way in the economy at the moment, these will be important industries in the development of employment, and they will create very important job opportunities for the tens of thousands of young Australians training in this area in tertiary institutions around Australia.

There are, of course, a large number of other people involved significantly in arts activities who are not measured here. For example, school teachers who are teaching arts activities in the course of their other teaching activities are not included. So there are many other people playing a significant role in the development of this industry. We should hope that a recognition is starting to appear in Australia that, behind every feature film and every CD, there are hundreds of jobs; and, behind every gallery, there are not only artists and technicians but all sorts of people in a broad range of occupations, from those traditionally defined as working class occupations to artists, technicians and specialists.

This survey reaffirms that the government's intention to target employment activity and other government taxpayer funded support to this industry is well founded both for cultural and economic reasons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Given his answer just a moment ago, I think my colleagues will be interested in this. I refer to an article in last Friday's Australian in which the minister reportedly stated that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the one area where I think we can do more things efficiently is in the international projection of Australian cultural activity.

Is the minister the `Senator somebody-or-other' who wrote to the Canadian Commonwealth Games President, Mr Heller, in August saying that Australia had `no plans' to take part in the proposed international arts festival during next year's Commonwealth Games? When 15 other countries have responded, all of them accepting Mr Heller's invitation, including many at prime ministerial level, what message does this action convey about Australia's interest in cultural and international cooperation?

TALK.START.PARA: —What it really conveys is how much faith we can place in stories in the Sun-Herald because that story was mischievously misapplied. The situation is that we had a letter which carried with it the implication that the Australian government should divert some of its international cultural projection funding into this area, and we said that we did not currently have any plans to do that—which was accurate. It is so long ago since this article appeared that I do not have the brief here, but let me tell Senator Patterson those things which I remember about it and, if I leave anything out, I will come back to the Senate.
—It has taken them a couple of weeks to ask the question.

—Yes, it is more than a couple of weeks, that is right, but they get around to it. My recollection is that the Canadians, when they received that reply, quite clearly understood that we had said no decision had yet been made. That did not appear in the article; I am not quite sure why but, anyway, we will assume that it was ignorance rather than malice.

PARA.TAB: Given the advice about the nature of the cost sharing between Canada and Australia in the development of the cultural activities in association with the Commonwealth Games, and the fact that they have a view about a very good Australian Aboriginal company, Tjatukai, who might be the people who should be there, we have now said that we are looking to see whether there is, within the existing resources, funding that we can provide to assist Tjatukai to go to the Commonwealth Games.

The article was mischievous. Nevertheless, our support for this project looks pretty promising. If we can make a contribution, I think it will be very worth while and I am looking for ways to do it. I do not want to pretend that having a group appear in Vancouver in association with the Commonwealth Games is our top international cultural projection priority; it is not. If we can only fund it by diverting things from higher profile activities, we will not do that. But I am fairly optimistic that we will be able to come up with a positive response and that Tjatukai will make a big impact at the Commonwealth Games because it is a very good company.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Did the government turn down the offer by the Smithsonian Institution to be the featured guest country at its 1993 festival, thus becoming the first of 48 countries to reject such an invitation in the 25-year history of the festival; or is this yet another, what the minister would call, mischievous article?

—No. It is a decision, which I support, to say that the top priority for the international projection of Australia is not to have people standing in the mall in Washington performing when there are many more important things that can be done in very many places more important for Australia to develop its cultural projection. While we have given massive increases in arts funding to which the opposition would have made cuts, there are nevertheless limits to the amount that can be spent, and this is not a priority.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What are the government's plans for the deregulation of Australian postal services? In what time frame are these plans to be implemented? What is the number and the time frame of planned retrenchments from Australia Post? To what extent are these retrenchments being driven by anticipation of the government's deregulation program?

—The government has agreed upon a sensible phased package of reforms to introduce further competition to Australia Post. The government expects that these changes will be phased in from the middle of next year. The reforms provide the impetus for further improvements to customer services, greater flexibility, choice of price and service quality while safeguarding the basic letter service. Under the government's decision, Australia Post will be able to continue its current restructuring program to provide postal services at what are acknowledged as world best practice standards.

PARA.TAB: The government has decided that some areas will be open to competition, including letters where the charge is greater than $1.80, a reduction in protection from 10 times to four times the standard letter rate; halving the weight limit from 500 to 250 grams; and outgoing international mail and incoming international mail up to the point of lodgment in the Australian postal network to ensure the same treatment for domestic and international mailers. The government has also decided that bulk mailers be allowed to lodge mail at designated mail centres in return for greater discounts.

Media commentators have speculated about the possibility of 10,000 job losses and a reduction in service standards. I noted just a few days ago the extraordinary statement made by Senator Alston in Sydney that the government should not be worried about the prospect of 10,000 job losses or a loss of $600 million in revenue. These reports are exaggerated and relate to proposals for full deregulation, which were not adopted by the government.

Australia Post has been implementing changes to its operational structure that have resulted in some 1,000 post office and agency staff taking early retirement and voluntary redundancy packages. A further 3,500 voluntary redundancies are planned over the next four years under the restructuring program. The arrangements for those redundancies have been fully agreed by unions as part of a wider enterprise agreement which was struck in 1992. These redundancies were already in the pipeline.

It is premature to speculate on possible job losses arising from the government's competitive reforms. In line with these reforms, Australia Post will be able to continue its current restructuring program to provide postal services at world best practice standards. Australia Post has responded positively to the government's decisions already noting that prospective competitors will continue to face vigorous competition from Australia Post.

As I indicated to honourable senators last week, I am dismayed at the industrial action that has been taken by the communication workers in refusing to deliver mail to members of parliament. I advised the Senate last week that the matter was in the Industrial Relations Commission. I did indicate that my staff in Darwin were fairly delighted about having a post-free week.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it?

—If loud mouth would shut up for a minute, she would find out. Last Thursday the Industrial Relations Commission recommended that all industrial action by the CWU be lifted. The CWU has rejected that recommendation. Australia Post has today sought a relisting of the hearing before the commission. In the meantime I am advised that Australia Post management is engaged in direct discussions with CWU officials to resolve the matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and the Minister for Family Services. I refer specifically to a recent Affirmative Action Agency report that indicates that only 19 per cent of trade union management positions are held by women, despite the fact that women make up 58 per cent of employees; that jobs held by women are likely to have less power and status than those held by men; and that no union has a strategy to address the lack of career paths for women. Given the government's much touted commitment to greater job opportunities for women, can the minister explain the hypocrisy whereby the government's alter ego, the trade unions, has one of the poorest records in promoting women to higher jobs and, indeed, could be seen to be excluding women from senior elected positions?

—I have not seen the report of the Affirmative Action Agency relating to the trade unions, but I do not wish to dispute the figures at all. It depends which way we look at figures as to whether they are moving up or moving down. But there is no way we could take any comfort from those figures and the trade union movement itself does not. Indeed, that is why the ACTU has direct programs and policies setting targets to improve the number of women in the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: The climate change that is happening across our country in which we are seeing an increased representation of women in senior positions is being reflected in the union movement, just as it is being reflected in business, in banking and in parliament. Any way that Senator Troeth looks at it, there is no way women in Australia or I as minister could settle for the figures we have at the moment. However, it is also true that those figures indicate certainly that gains have been made to this point and, in the case of the ACTU, goals and targets have been clearly set to ensure that the position improves. The ACTU has clear goals to increase the number of women, just as the Liberal Party has, just as our party has, just as is the case in business and banking.

I am not strictly the minister for the trade union movement. While I am very happy to take responsibility for the status of women in this country—and I am pleased that Senator Troeth is interested in the outcome of the Affirmative Action Agency report—I will certainly continue to argue for increased representation of women in all forums. But I also admit—certainly I hope Senator Troeth does too—that that is not entirely a government responsibility.

Finally, we may set the cultural climate, we may set the challenge and we may set the tone, but it is up to some of those organisations—business, the private sector, banking and industry—to follow. However, I point out that this question should have been addressed to the minister responsible for the Affirmative Action Agency, the Minister for Industrial Relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. My question is prompted by growing overseas interest in the way in which Australia approaches immigration and multicultural issues. Is it a fact that there will soon be a symposium on immigration issues in Berlin? If so, will Australia be able to use this symposium to highlight our policies in this area?

—Senator Colston is right when he focuses the premise of his question on a growing recognition overseas of Australia's achievements in the field of migration, ethnic affairs and, of course, our success in building a harmonious multicultural society. It is particularly important to recognise this at a time when, internationally, countries are facing the challenge of increasing global mobility. They are looking carefully at their policies on migration, settlement, citizenship and multiculturalism.

PARA.TAB: This was confirmed to me by my personal experience in visits overseas this year. I have been convinced that we are seen by many players internationally as having a successful model and that we should take the opportunity to, wherever possible, share such model and experience with other parts of the world. This is, of course, one way through which Australia can enhance its international standing.

A particular recognition of the way we do things was appreciated and reflected in Germany during my visit earlier this year. The Berlin Commissioner for Foreigners, Frau Barbara John, expressed great interest in Germany learning more about how Australia has implemented migration, settlement and multicultural policies and programs. One reason why Germany is focusing on how we do it in Australia is that reunification has meant new challenges for Germans. They are particularly keen to see how our policies are implemented in a federal structure. This has led to discussions between Australia and Berlin in Germany, and plans have been discussed as to the holding of a symposium in Germany on the Australian experience some time early next year. Those plans have now been finalised and the symposium will go ahead in Berlin in February.

Senator Colston touches on what I think is a very real opportunity for Australia. This symposium is an opportunity for Australians to share our experience with an interested and important part of the world. It is an opportunity for Germany to focus on and to get an understanding of how we do it. It is an opportunity for us to present to other parts of the world our results and our experiences when internationally many countries are looking at ways of better enhancing their approaches to migration, settlement, citizenship and multiculturalism.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Given that the United States has insisted that the main justification for its export enhancement program has been to force the European Community to the negotiating table and, in light of that, the events now occurring in the present GATT negotiations, does that not provide Australia with greater bargaining power with the United States to improve Australia's access for grains? What effects will any change to the original Blair House accord have for Australian growers?

—Starting with the latter part of the question, the fundamental reform principles of the Blair House agreement do remain intact. I think it is important to understand that, notwithstanding the changes that have been negotiated in the last few days. Importantly, the endpoints for cuts in subsidised exports remain unchanged, and the cuts will be required to be made in six steps, commencing in the first year.

PARA.TAB: What has altered is the base period from which the cuts in subsidised exports will commence—that base period being altered from 1986 to 1990 to 1991 and 1992. This will increase, for example, the total volume of subsidised wheat and flour exports that the EC and the United States can export over the six-year implementation period by around eight million and 7.5 million tonnes, respectively, as compared with the original Blair House deal.

It is important to stress, however, that this still means that the volume of subsidised exports of wheat and flour by the EC and the US will be around 50 million tonnes less over this period than if the present situation continued. Of course, in practice, if the Uruguay Round were not to be successful, if it fell apart at the last minute, there is a real risk that the level of subsidised exports from the EC and the US would be considerably in excess, in the future, of that 50 million tonnes.

As to current activity, the Prime Minister has written to President Clinton, as has been announced, about Australia's concerns with the US offer on market access for beef, dairy and sugar. Senator Cook, in Geneva at the moment, is certainly very vigorously following that up at the negotiator level. I do not think there is very much more I can say specifically about what might be achievable in this respect. It is really, essentially, on the market access side that the effort is finally being put in. We hope there will be some more fruit from this process.

The main focus at the moment seems to be on the last-minute crisis that has developed in the area of financial services and audio visual services in particular. It is not to be assumed that we are going to do very much better than we have out of the agricultural negotiations. We will just have to wait and see what happens over the next 24 or 48 hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Prime Minister asked for an assurance that Australia will not, once again, become the innocent victim of the trade wars or bargaining deals between the United States and the European Community? Can the minister give some assurance that that has been asked for and that we will not get hit in the crossfire again?

—That is certainly the point that is being very vigorously put by Senator Cook in Geneva. Without being in a position to confirm that right now, I assume that that point, again, has been made in recent communications by the Prime Minister. We are concerned that, in areas such as rice and so on, we do get effective access to the Japanese and Korean markets as they open up. It would be a rather quixotic victory in that respect if we were to be swamped out of that market by a flood of subsidised grain coming from the US and the EC in the period immediately ahead.

PARA.TAB: Whatever might be the outcome of these ups and downs, I think that one needs to look at the Uruguay Round in its totality. The estimates that are being made of the boost to both agricultural and industrial trade are very large indeed—the latest from the OECD being some $A418 billion a year by the year 2002, and rather more than that by 2005.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Given the disappointment that the minister expressed in this chamber last week about the Northern Territory government's failure to introduce the .05 blood alcohol limit in line with every other state and territory, and given the hope that the minister expressed that it would do so before Christmas to maximise its involvement in the current national road safety campaign, I ask: has the minister received any indication from the Country-Liberal Party government in the Northern Territory that it will take this important step before Christmas—that is, 1993?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to say that the Minister for Transport and Works in the Northern Territory has publicly responded in a most disappointing and, I must say, disturbing way in terms of his understanding of the facts relating to drink-driving. I am particularly concerned about this because, as I told the Senate last week, the Northern Territory is currently the only place in Australia that has not joined every other state and territory on a .05 blood alcohol limit—
—Shame.

—It is a shame, particularly for those who will die on our roads. It is particularly disturbing that the public response of the responsible Northern Territory minister has shown such a bad grasp of the facts. The minister has said publicly in an interview that he gave to the ABC that the Northern Territory had yet to announce a date for when it would join the rest of Australia on .05. He did confirm publicly that drink-driving was a major contributor to road deaths in the Territory which, as I said in my previous advice to the Senate, is three times the national average rate for road deaths. He then went on to say—and I found this astonishing—that the Northern Territory Government was:

ANSWER.PARA: being blackmailed by the Commonwealth into lowering its blood alcohol limit in order to obtain the federal funds that were attached to the ten point package.
That is extremely disappointing. What was more disturbing was that he went on to say:
I do not believe there will be any change in the accident statistics about fatalities with alcohol involvement if we drop the level to .05.

I found that astonishing. I normally have a great deal of respect for Mr Manzie, whom I consider to be one of the best of a bad bunch. But I am profoundly disturbed that a minister responsible for oversighting a part of Australia that has a road death fatality rate three times the national average could possibly assert that when the weight of evidence is so profoundly against him.

PARA.TAB: The case for setting .05 on statistical grounds is compelling. Indeed, that was the reason that every state and territory jurisdiction, with the exception of the Northern Territory, adopted it. Studies of crash statistics show that the risk of being involved in an accident for a driver with a blood alcohol count of between .05 and .08 is more than double that of a sober driver, with the risk doubling again if the driver goes over .08.

However, there is compelling evidence that the .05 limit does more than just eliminate low level drink driving; it also reduces significantly the number of people taking to the roads with very high blood alcohol readings, and it is easy to understand why.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's this got to do with the federal government?

—It has everything to do with us. What an astonishing interjection. We administer the Federal Office of Road Safety. We implemented the 10-point package that provided for the national system of .05. What a ridiculous interjection.

PARA.TAB: I will now turn to the statistics. For example, in the ACT, the number of people driving with blood alcohol counts above .05 dropped by almost 40 per cent after the introduction of the lower limit in 1990. That reduction was sustained over a follow-up 12-month study. This represents an enormous gain to road safety because the road risks, not just to those with high blood alcohol levels but also to other drivers, is extreme.I reiterate that all states and territories, with the exception of the Northern Territory, are joined together in both implementing and advertising a .05 limit. I hope that the Northern Territory government implements such a limit prior to Christmas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to his recent visit to Vietnam during which, I understand from discussions with him before his departure, details of the forthcoming Australian human rights delegation to Vietnam were to be finalised. Will the minister advise the Senate of the outcome of his discussions in Vietnam and, in particular, whether a final date for the visit has been agreed, bearing in mind Senator Ray's advice to me in the Senate on 16 November that `we are aiming for the week beginning 7 March 1994 and we'll be doing what we can to ensure that there is no further slippage'? Secondly, what will be the composition of the delegation? Thirdly, how long will the delegation be in Vietnam? Where will it go and with whom will it meet?

—I told Senator Short that I would give him full information when it was available and appropriate to do so. I am not in a position to give him full information; I can only answer some of those questions at this stage.

PARA.TAB: The result of my discussions in Vietnam was to confirm the willingness of the Vietnam authorities to accept a delegation. The date that we agreed on was either late March or early April in a precise band of days still to be agreed between the two of us. There were domestic considerations which made it difficult for the Vietnamese side to do it, as we had originally thought possible, in the earlier March period. It is intended that the delegation be a mixed one, as was the delegation to China, comprising parliamentarians, experts and one or two community representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who appoints our nominee, Gareth?
—I will be doing the appointment and we will be paying for it from Foreign Affairs; it is not coming out of parliamentary funds.
—We'll appoint our own.

—We will talk about that privately. It is intended that the duration of the visit be of the order of 10 days. The places to be visited and the people that the delegation will meet with are still the subject of ongoing discussion and have not yet been settled.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. As far as the latter part of his answer is concerned—in particular, the question of settling with whom the delegation will meet—can he assure the Senate that the delegation will be able to meet with the prisoners of conscience who are so well known to the West, such as Professor Hoat and Dr Que? Does he agree that if the delegation cannot meet and talk with them, it will lose a lot of the significance that it should otherwise have?

—I am not able to give that assurance. Clearly, as with all these things, it is a matter for the Vietnamese government just as it was a matter for the Chinese government. There are bound to be some disappointments in terms of the delegation meeting with everyone that it would ideally like to, just as there were disappointments with the two visits to China that were led by Senator Schacht.We will be doing our best to get the maximum possible exposure of the delegation to relevant people across the spectrum of those who have expressed political concerns and religious freedom concerns, particularly involving the United Buddhist congregation and the Catholic church. My hope is that the visit will be a fruitful one in that respect.

PARA.TAB: It is important to realise that what we are about here is establishing a dialogue process, as we have been doing with China. It is a protracted business to establish confidence and lines of communication in these areas. Necessarily, progress is likely to be a little slower than some of us would ideally like. But it does not mean the exercise is a useless one if we do not get everything we want in the organisation of these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer to the recently concluded OECD world conference held in Sydney which focused on the issue of small to medium size enterprises and job creation. I understand that the minister was amongst those who attended the conference, and I ask whether he is able to provide any information on the issues covered and the positive outcomes that might flow from the conference.

—Last week a very important conference was held in Australia. It was the OECD world conference on small and medium size enterprises and job creation. It is the first time such a conference dealing with these issues has been held outside the OECD headquarters in Paris. Australia was selected in recognition of the efforts being made by Australian governments, both state and federal, to promote small business.

PARA.TAB: The conference was held over three days. Some 250 delegates attended and there were 40 speakers. These included not only myself but also my colleagues Minister Griffiths, Minister Beazley, Minister Beddall and Parliamentary Secretary Snowdon.
Senator Vanstone interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone would be pleased to know that we also invited Senator Bishop to make a contribution in one of the sessions. She spoke for only 10 minutes and was well received. This compares with the 50-minute disaster she made recently at the Australian Business Monthly awards where she sent people to sleep with her long, tedious, ideological statements. Her contribution, amongst all the others, was well received. Senior people from other governments were present, such as Minister Wada from the MITI Department in Japan, Mr Tanaguchi, the Deputy Secretary-General of the OECD, and Virginia Littlejohn from the World Association of Women Entrepreneurs from the United States.

PARA.TAB: During the conference a wide range of issues and problems were discussed. We discussed the unacceptably high level of unemployment within the OECD, which is at the moment around 36 million people. The points also discussed included the need for venture capital and the need to constantly encourage development of an entrepreneurial culture. Within those discussions what became very clear and what I was pleased to hear from the many foreign guests present was that they believe that Australian governments, both state and federal—this is not just a partisan comment I am making—and the private sector rank equally with what is going on in the world in the development of small and medium size enterprises. In a number of areas they believe that Australia is ahead of the development in other parts of the world. This includes the things we are doing in Australia to assist small and medium size enterprises to become export oriented, encouraging women into small business and encouraging technology and innovation amongst small businesses.

They also commented on the way Australia deals with the No. 1 one issue which has been raised in Australia and overseas and that is the need for investment capital for small business, whether it be overdrafts from banks, development capital, venture capital or seeding capital for small and medium size enterprises. This was the No. 1 issue discussed. It is interesting to note that across the OECD the complaints made by small business in Australia about the availability of finance are similarly reflected by small business operators in all the other OECD countries.

I congratulate those who organised the conference, including the Small Business Centre in New South Wales and officers of my department, and the contributions made by the guests from overseas and overwhelmingly the contributions made by the people of Australia. In this case, I even congratulate Senator Bishop for the contribution she made. I congratulate her on her pre-selection and look forward to all the trouble she will cause Dr Hewson in the lower house.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—In answer to a question from Senator Bourne on 9 December, I said that I would keep the Senate informed as further information came to hand on the issue of previously undisclosed United States nuclear tests over the past 50 years. I also have some answers to the questions raised today by Senator Margetts on the same subject. I now table, as I foreshadowed last week that I would, the following documents: first, several official fact sheets of the United States Department of Energy released in Washington on 10 December concerning US unannounced tests, pre-1961 Pacific tests, national archives and records administration declassified records, and an FOI act request regarding classified programs; secondly, a list of US nuclear explosions extracted from the Australian Geological Survey Organisation's database on nuclear explosions; and, thirdly, AGSO's quarterly reports on underground nuclear tests for the period 1 January 1987 to 30 September 1993.

PARA.TAB: According to the US documents to which I have referred, the US government did not inform Australia, or other countries for that matter, of 204 nuclear tests—not 250 tests, as has been suggested in media reports. Through routine seismological data exchanges, including with the US seismological network, the Australian Geological Survey Organisation, AGSO, was aware of 116 of those undisclosed tests, although data about the remainder is still unavailable in Australia. Of those 116, 49 were conducted between 1962 and 1969; 56 between 1970 and 1979; 10 in the 1980s; and one in 1990.

The US authorities have confirmed that the US has conducted no tests in the Pacific since 1962. All the tests in the Pacific that were conducted before that date were announced. They took place at Enewitok between 1948 and 1958, on Johnston Island in 1958 and 1962, on Christmas Island in 1962 and on Bikini Island between 1946 and 1958. It is clear that, in referring to the unannounced tests, Energy Secretary O'Leary was disclosing only underground nuclear tests which had been conducted in the continental United States. Moreover, although some of these tests were undoubtedly detected by seismic arrays elsewhere, they were not identified by the Australian seismic network as nuclear tests, essentially because they were all small in size—less than 20 kilotons.

As to the organisations in Australia which detect these things, in 1986 the Australian government established in AGSO a nuclear monitoring group which, through its own seismic monitoring network and through its exchanges with other such networks, maintains a database on nuclear testing activity. This work has been carried out in preparation for global verification under a comprehensive test ban treaty, when in due course that is negotiated, and reflects the high priority that Australia places on the conclusion of such a treaty.

As to the United States station in Alice Springs, about which Senator Margetts asked, the situation is as follows: the US Geological and Geophysical Research Station has been operating at Alice Springs under an agreement signed in 1954. It is run by the US Air Force technical applications centre and I understand that there are no Australian personnel at the station. Australia has been receiving a complete set of raw data from this US station since 1978. Until 1986 it was transmitted to the ANU's Research School of Earth Sciences and from 1986 the data has been transmitted to AGSO. Since coming on stream in 1986, AGSO, through its own arrays or through information supplied from the US station in Alice Springs, has not, as I have said, detected any unannounced nuclear explosions, essentially for the reason that I have mentioned, that they are all so small in size. Taking place as they did at that distance in the continental US, the Australian networks or arrays by themselves were simply unable to pick them up.

Finally, seismic monitoring is an inexact science when it comes to differentiating between low level nuclear tests and natural seismic activity. It is, therefore, particularly important, in order to refine verification procedures for a future test ban treaty, to know precisely what past tests have been conducted and when. It was for this reason that the answer given to Senator Bourne in the Senate last week registered Australia's disappointment at the US failure to disclose approximately one-fifth of the tests conducted. Nevertheless, we continue to welcome the new US openness in respect of these tests, data about which should enable seismologists to re-evaluate the information—they already have—and thus assist in the complex process of elaborating verification measures for a CTBT. The US has also foreshadowed the release of more data on its nuclear weapons program and we look forward to that release as a further contribution to enhancing the nuclear disarmament process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), to a question without notice asked by Senator Lees this day, relating to health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fascinated to hear Senator Richardson's response to Senator Lees because he is in a fascinating position at the moment. He has fallen out with ACOSS, the Consumers Health Forum, the Australian Council on the Ageing, the Public Health Association, Dr Deeble, one of the developers of Medicare, the ACTU and, incidentally, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), of all people. I listened to Question Time in the House of Representatives this afternoon. The Prime Minister attacked the coalition, saying that the coalition was pulling away at the entrails of Medicare. How better could one describe what Senator Richardson is doing at the moment—pulling away at the entrails of Medicare?

PARA.TAB: For the first time Senator Richardson has admitted that after 10 years Medicare has failed. Why else is he trying to promote private health insurance? At last he has seen the light. He spent nine months finding out what is going on with Medicare. He has been told, quite rightly, that people are dropping out of private medical insurance at a fast rate—two per cent a year. They cannot afford private insurance.

The Prime Minister said today—this is where Senator Richardson has a great education program ahead of him—that they were dropping out of private insurance and leaving the private health care system to go to the public system because Medicare was working so well. There are 100,000 people on waiting lists around the country, as acknowledged by Senator Richardson, trying to get into hospitals. They cannot get in. But it is working so well, according to the Prime Minister, that they are leaving private insurance to go to the public system.

I would like the Prime Minister to explain why 20,000 people in Queensland took out private insurance last year. Overall in Australia 72,000 dropped out of private insurance but 20,000 in Queensland took it out. If the public hospital system is working so well in Queensland, why are they privately insuring? He cannot have it both ways. The only group that I can see that Senator Richardson has on side for his proposals is the Australian Health Insurance Association. As I mentioned before, the director, Mr Russell Schneider, is supporting them. The only reason that it is supporting Senator Richardson is that the big health insurance associations will get bigger while the smaller ones will get smaller—or will disappear and be amalgamated. That is where he is getting that support.

I point out to the Australian Health Insurance Association that it had better watch out for the three-card trick. The first card is to reduce the number of health insurance associations from their current 38 to fewer than 20, which is what Senator Richardson is proposing. The next proposal is to have one large insurer in each state, as well as Medicare Private. The third card is to have one national insurer. The left wing of the Labor Party will love that. It is a three-step process: the first step is to reduce the number of health insurance associations from 38 to fewer than 20; the next step is to have one major insurer in each state, plus Medibank Private; and the third step is to nationalise the lot. Senator Richardson has parts of the Australian Private Hospitals Association in favour of his proposals.

The fundamental thing that Senator Richardson cannot see—I have told him this personally—is that he is going to bring in, between the patients or people who get sick and the doctor who is treating them, a private hospital in agreement with the Health Insurance Association. So, when one gets sick, one would not go to one's doctor; rather one would go to a private hospital and the Health Insurance Association and say, `How much money can I have to be treated with?'. When one is told what sort of money, one can go to the doctor, and the doctor has to have a contract with the private hospital to determine how much will be spent on him or her.

This is the preferred provider organisations system as in the US. It did not work there but we should look at what it did. Those hospitals would only take in patients who would not be there very long. They would race them through for that amount of money to get them out as fast as they could because they would lose money if they kept them any longer. This is what Senator Richardson is proposing. No wonder the Prime Minister is opposing him, no wonder Dr Deeble is opposing him and no wonder the ACTU is opposing him. He is obviously in an intolerable position because if he does get rolled on this, he has to resign.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 191, I want to explain a material part of a speech of mine which was quite deliberately misquoted by Mr Leo McLeay in the other place on 24 November 1993.
—The Clerk shares my view that it is standing order 190 which you should be referring to, under which leave is required.
—Standing order 190 relates to a personal explanation; 191 relates to a speech that has been misquoted.
—I think that standing order refers to debate in the Senate, not a debate which has taken place in another place.
—The only other thing is that I need leave for the first but not for the second, and I am assuming that Senator Gareth Evans would give leave.
—Providing you will confine yourself to the matters in issue.
—I will respond to some matters that—
—To the extent that Senator Macdonald wants to correct a misrepresentation that has been made, and providing he stays within the ordinary bounds of such a correction, leave is happily given.

—In the House of Representatives on 24 November 1993, Mr Leo McLeay referred to Senator Alston and me and a debate we had in estimates committee hearings about the ABC. According to Hansard, Mr McLeay said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macdonald said:
When are you going to get 50 per cent of your staff as Liberals . . .
Mr McLeay then said:
These are the sorts of civil libertarians we have on the opposition side . . . Senator Macdonald says, `What we want in the ABC is 50 per cent Liberals'.
Not many people would take too much notice of what Mr McLeay says, but it is on the record and I wanted to correct it.

PARA.TAB: I refer the Senate to page 532 of the Hansard of that estimates committee on 15 November when this matter came up. It is important that I explain how it came up. Senator Kemp, in a very clever question, had asked Mr Hill, the Managing Director of the ABC, about some advertisements that the ABC had placed calling for staff with non-English speaking backgrounds; he also asked about an advertisement for a staff position which required a female trainee sports reporter. Senator Kemp asked why Mr Hill was being sexist and racist in his advertisements. Mr Hill was suitably embarrassed and said that it was a mistake and it would not happen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know that he has reneged? He has gone back on that one.
—Has he reneged on that? Has he gone back on that? I was not aware of that. Perhaps someone could elucidate on that.
—I wouldn't take Senator Alston's word for that.
—I would take Senator Alston's word. He is very rarely wrong in anything he says, even by way of interjection. In this Senate estimates committee Mr Hill went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC should not have quotas but we have very firm targets to make the ABC more fairly representative of the Australian community.
He went on to say:

. . . the ABC has tried to devise equal employment opportunity plans to try to get its work force to more fairly reflect the community as a whole . . . To be quite honest, that will not happen until 50 per cent of all positions in the ABC are female, until about a third of them are people from non-English speaking backgrounds and until there is a representation of people who are disabled.

He said that the ABC had targeted one area successfully, and had got a fair representation of Aboriginal people. In the context of that debate, I asked Mr Hill—somewhat in jest but I was also making an important point—why, if he wants to be representative of the Australian community, as he said one should be, does he not have 50 per cent of his staff who are Liberals rather than the 90 per cent who currently seem to follow the Labor party line.

PARA.TAB: It was in that context. I think it was quite an appropriate observation from me, but it was in no way suggesting that we should conduct a witch-hunt as to what peoples' politics are. It was simply making the point that the ABC, and some of its news reports in particular, are thought by many people to be somewhat biased. I was simply saying to Mr Hill that if you want a good representation of the Australian community in the ABC then you should ensure that you get a few more people with a more balanced political view of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
the Australian Government's policy of detaining people seeking asylum has caused enormous hardship and misery for those detained;
the policy has contravened international obligations undertaken by Australia;
as a result of the detention of asylum seekers the Australian community has borne a considerable financial burden;

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:

PETITION.PARA: to end the policy of detaining asylum seekers, and
to release those asylum seekers still being held in Department of Immigration Processing Centres.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PETITION.PARA: The United Nations declaration on the elimination of all forms of intolerance and of discrimination based on religious belief:
prohibits all forms of religious discrimination, thus potentially restricting the freedom of Australians to make any choices on the grounds of their belief;
could lead to US-style prohibitions on public Christian prayers, Christmas carols, or nativity scenes;
has the potential, according to the NSW Attorney-General, to restrict greatly the freedom of religious groups.
and that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12-16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only the legally-weak term "respect" for the rights of parents in Article 5;
could result in Government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:

PARA.TAB: Act to disallow these two international instruments from the HREOC Act.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Government's current practice of detaining asylum seekers is inhumane and has been the cause of profound psychological damage to detainees;
that this practice contravenes the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention on the Rights of the Child; and
that detention has in particular cases been found to be illegal.

PARA.TAB: Your Petitioners therefore request that the Senate assembled should request the Government:

PETITION.PARA: to recognise that those who have suffered prolonged detention should be able to claim resident status on humanitarian grounds now.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child:
a. Has the potential to deny parents their rightful authority over their children, even empowering the Government to represent children against their parents (Article 12)
b. Removes parents freedom to protect their children from exposure to material which the parents believe to be objectionable or harmful on religious, moral or other grounds (Art. 13)
c. Denies parental rights to discourage their children from harmful groups or beliefs (Art. 14)
d. Denies parents power to stop their children being with persons they believe harmful (Art. 15)
e. May prevent parents "interfering" in any area of life a child claims to be private (Art. 16)
We believe this Convention could be used to deny the freedom of parents to nurture and educate their children in accordance with their own beliefs, and could destroy family relationships.
We believe its use as law would be an abuse of the external affairs power of the Constitution.
We ask that the Senate act disallow this Convention from the HREOC Act.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PARA.TAB: The 1993 Federal Budget announcement by the Keating Labor Government to increase wholesale sales tax on wine by more than 50%, from 20% to 31%:

PETITION.PARA: discriminates against the wine industry compared with other beverages;
threatens the continuing existence of 150 smaller wineries;
destroys the capacity for further multi $million investment in the wine industry and the creation of jobs;
will undermine the growth in the export market for Australian wine by severely damaging the industry's domestic base;
will undermine the profitability of the retail liquor industry.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore implore the Senate to reject the increase in the wholesale sales tax on wine.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Huon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Keating Government's decision to close down HMAS Huon is clearly and demonstrably wrong and should be reversed having regard to:
(a)The fact that HMAS Huon has been part of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania for over 80 years;
(b)It has continually demonstrated itself to be a most efficient shore-based designated Naval facility and Headquarters for the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania;

(c)Its closure will place at risk the immediate future in Tasmania of 25 permanent Royal Australian Navy personnel, 108 active Reservists and 40 inactive Reservists and in addition will deprive the Naval Reserve Cadets of their Tasmanian Divisional Headquarters; and, the fact that only a miserable $250,000 will be allegedly saved out of the National Defence budget of over $9 billion,

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully submit that:
The High Court's Mabo decision has caused division and dissension, uncertainty, resentment and economic damage in Australia.
Mabo will not solve the social, educational, housing and other problems of Aboriginal people.
Mabo is an attack on our Federal system of government, under which the absolute control of Crown lands and management of land titles have always rested with the States.

The only solution to Mabo is a referendum of the Australian people for a law to overrule the High Court and re-establish equal land rights for all Australians, under the normal procedures of State and Territory laws.
And we strongly urge the Senate to reject any other proposed solution.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
