SPEECH.PARA: Happily, this document before us is the first annual report of the Australia-India Council. I congratulate all the members of the council, including the chairman, my friend Graham Feakes, former High Commissioner for Australia in India, on the council's work in its first year. As is acknowledged at the beginning of the report, the council was established following the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that there be such a council to promote knowledge of Australia in India and knowledge of India in Australia in a way that is economically to the benefit of our peoples.

PARA.TAB: I note on page 3 of the report that in its first year the council has had three priorities—three very introductory and broad priorities: firstly, to put the council on the map, both in Australia and in India, to see that there is a council in place and ready to respond to good ideas from within each country, especially Australia; secondly, to put India on the map in Australia; and, thirdly, to inform Australians and Indians interested in the bilateral relationship of key developments.

In an appendix there is set out, with dollar amounts, a whole range of activities the council has undertaken this year. I acknowledge, as the council does, that a number of these will bear fruit in the subsequent year and maybe even in a longer time frame. In fact, I commend the council for taking a long-term view and for trying to assess projects to be supported which will have an enduring positive effect on the relationship between our two countries.

It is quite an important observation to make that where 70 per cent of Australia's trade is with that part of Asia encompassing the countries that make up the Asia-Pacific economic consultation process, APEC, it is possible for Australians not to give enough attention to south Asia and to India, in particular. It is so vital that we have a close relationship and a good understanding with Japan, China, the Philippines and the other ASEAN members—Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei—and the other tigers, Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong, that we put so much effort into this strategic area of priority for Australia and forget that the relationship with south Asia is important as well, all in its proper perspective. Therefore, I welcome the existence of the council and commend it on the work that it has done as set out in the order constituting the Australia-India Council, which is included in this brief report.

I particularly want to refer to the development of a directory of institutional and other links between Australia and India. I look forward to seeing this directory in due course. I hope it will include the Australia-India parliamentary friendship group within this parliament; the names of the members of the group; and also some reference to those Australian senators who wrote the original Senate report and who have, as I do, a continuing interest in developing the Australia-India relationship, not just with India but also with the other countries of south Asia.

I also refer to the director of the secretariat of the council, Mr Ian Wille. I think he is a former counsellor of the Australian High Commission in New Delhi—a long serving diplomat of Australia who has now taken on this dedicated job to be based in Canberra but available for all the activities of the Australia-India Council. I am impressed with his dedication to the work of the council and I commend him for the first year of the council's operations.

It has probably not gone beyond the notice of most senators that the captain of the Australian cricket team, Allan Border, is a member of this council. I am very pleased to have been amongst those who first nominated that he be there because one of the languages common to Australia and India is not just English but, of course, cricket. I wish him and all the other members of the council real success in the second year of the council's operations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: The other curious thing about this report that came to my attention is that at around page 200 the department very dutifully lists the press releases by the various ministers with responsibility for this department. TALK.START.PARA: —What a broken promise.

SPEECH.PARA: Media Release
DAVID SIMMONS
MINISTER FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT—MINISTER FOR FAMILY SUPPORT
2 July 1992
LOCAL GOVERNMENT ELECTED MEMBERS EXEMPT FROM SUPER LEVY

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that since the election the Office of Local Government, which previously had a staff of 50 and its own first assistant secretary, has been downgraded quite substantially. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The first reference that the report makes, quite properly, is to activities of the Department of Defence in relation to peacekeeping throughout the last 12 months. It was my privilege to visit the Australian Defence Force contingents in Cambodia twice in the last 14 months and also to visit the contingent in Somalia. The distinction with which the Australian Defence Force carried out its duties in both those peacekeeping operations was exemplary. The report does note that it was the biggest overseas deployment of Australian troops since Vietnam, but it does not go on to say too much about the significance of that. Coping with those numbers overseas certainly placed quite a strain on the Australian Defence Force, given the poor resources that it has at present.

PARA.TAB: Without being unkind to the government in any way, I point out that peacekeeping operations are just about the only operations of an operational nature that the Australian Defence Force can now perform. We have had a considerable reduction in numbers as part of the force structure review and a definite diminution of the capability of the Australian Defence Force.

I have been worried for many years about the total lack of sustainability. There is not a word about sustainability in this report, as I see it, from a very quick look. In plain terms, that means that if we have to use the Australian defence forces on armed operations, which is why we retain them, at a cost of over $9 billion, the sustainability simply is not there. There are not the reserves of ammunition and equipment that we need to sustain the Australian defence forces on active service.

The nature of operations has changed so much in the last 30 years that the availability at short notice of things such as precision guided munitions and missiles simply does not exist. We have to have an in-house inventory within the country to give us any security and, therefore, to give any credibility at all to our defence forces. Furthermore, unless we have them in the country and train with them, we are certainly not going to be able to use them effectively on the first occasion. Sustainability is absolutely the dominant issue that faces the Australian Defence Force. From what I can see, there is not a word in this document, which is the major statement of the department for the year, which deals with that.

Another great glaring defect, which gets scant treatment in this report, is our weakness in electronic warfare capability. As I have said in the Senate many times, we have to be in the position where we can dominate the electromagnetic spectrum. All communications and a large number of sensors operate in the electromagnetic spectrum. We put some money into it, but we do not put anywhere near the amount of money into it that we need to, particularly for research through the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. Again, it is something that we cannot do overnight. If we have an emergency, we simply cannot acquire these skills from overseas and we cannot perform the research in a crash program, and we cannot get the equipment we need into production within any sort of meaningful time frame.

The third great area that seems to be missing in this report is any reflection and comment on the morale in the Australian defence forces, which is now at a very low level. Part of that comes from the fact that the government seems to have no defence policy at all. People in the defence forces feel abused, in so far as no-one appreciates them, no-one can tell them what they are there for, they are short of money for equipment, they are short of money for training, they are short of money for operations, and it all seems very pointless.

Added to that, the ready reserve scheme, which is showing all the signs of a total failure, has had a catastrophic effect on the morale of the army. Arguably its best brigade—6th Brigade in Brisbane, along with 8/9 Battalion, 6th Battalion and 49th Battalion—has been disbanded and replaced with the ready reserve scheme. We have had a spate of resignations or redundancies forced on the defence forces through the commercial support program, which again has operated very much against morale.

Added to that, a whole lot of unfortunate legislation is being put through, such as the fringe benefits tax for conditions of service, which has completely demoralised the defence forces. Those subjects that I have mentioned are very much part of the accounting that the department should do when presenting its annual report to the parliament, but it either avoids comment on them altogether or skates over them very lightly.

SPEECH.PARA: This annual report reports on a disastrous year for Australia's most important primary industry. Out of this terrible year came the Garnaut recommendations that have been fully aired in this Senate. Last week the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) made the board appointments to the two new industry structures that arose from the Garnaut report—the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, AWRAP, and Wool International. These appointments have received a mixed reaction from the industry and from the opposition.

PARA.TAB: The appointment of Mac Drysdale as chairman of AWRAP has been universally accepted as essential for continuity and his depth of knowledge, which is invaluable. The appointment of Charlie Massey, a grower from Cooma, gives me a great deal of pleasure. I have known him for many years. He is innovative with both his management and plans for the future of wool and he is committed to the future marketing of wool correctly.

The other appointments to AWRAP are encouraging, with the exception of Mr Jack Hallam. I cannot see why Minister Crean keeps appointing this relic of the Wran government in New South Wales to anything. He was first appointed to the AQIS advisory council and now he has been appointed to AWRAP. It very much has a ring of `jobs for the boys' about it. The only encouraging thing may be that even more people will realise that Mr Hallam has risen far beyond his level of competency, but that, unfortunately, will not help the industry.

The appointment of Mr Dick Warburton as chairman of Wool International has raised a few eyebrows, not that this reaction reflects on Mr Warburton's credentials as a leading and capable businessman; it is just his existing role of chairman and chief executive of Du Pont Australia—the maker of synthetic fibres which are in direct competition with wool. This introduces the prospect of a conflict of interest, which will be a real concern to the wool industry. Mr Warburton was on the selection committee and now finds himself chairman. While the appointment of the chairman is solely within the power of the minister, it is all a little cosy.

Mr Crean knows full well that many European processors are openly sceptical of Wool International. It is therefore critical to win their confidence and support for the new board. The appointment of Mr Warburton may make this task a little more difficult. Both the minister and Mr Warburton will need to move immediately to convince the industry that there will be no conflicts of interest.

The minister, along with the rest of the Labor government, has no idea how important confidence, faith and goodwill will be in rebuilding the wool industry. In times past in the wool industry, your word was your bond. It is essential that that situation be returned to for the benefit of the wool trade.

Every step must be taken to assure the trade that Wool International is above reproach and that the commercial secrets of the wool industry will not be discussed around the boardroom tables of its competitors. I know that I speak for every woolgrower, however, when I wish Mr Warburton well in his new role.

This is the second last annual report of AWIC. It will formally report for 1993-94 but not after that time. Time has moved on. The wool industry now goes forward under new structures. Above all, I am hopeful of a more sustainable market for the survival of growers.

A lot of criticism has been directed at both the Australian Wool Corporation over the past four years and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, which has operated for the past two or three years. There are some very capable and decent people in those two organisations who have a great knowledge of the industry and a great commitment to its future. Some of them will stay in the industry and some will leave. To those who stay and play their part in the new structures, I wish them well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

For the past 18 months, it has been in a transitional period whilst the secretariat establishes itself in Brisbane, Queensland, as a national focus for setting out advice and a draft plan for vocational education and training. ANTA will operate in full flight from 1 January next year.

PARA.TAB: We have had debates on the formation of ANTA. It is based upon legislation that was passed in the federal parliament and legislation that will be passed in some states which is parallel with the national legislation. Today's Notice Paper lists some amendments to the ANTA legislation that the government is proposing. That debate will take place later today or early tomorrow morning.

I note in response to this first annual report my confidence in the chairman of ANTA, Brian Finn, who is the managing director of IBM Australia. He has taken a careful interest in vocational education and training for many years. Indeed, because of his research and writing of reports, he has become a national authority on the subject.

I also have confidence in the chief executive officer, Mr Terry Moran, who was formerly the chief executive officer of the Office of Training and Further Education in Victoria. He is a man who, I have noted in the past, has been given a salary by the Commonwealth parliament that is greater than the Prime Minister's salary. I have high expectations of Mr Moran. I still have to meet him. I am looking forward to the chance to meet him as soon as appropriate after 1 January when he comes around to the states and territories to meet with those of us who are directly interested in vocational education and training policy. As honourable senators know, ANTA is principally interested in national policy for what we know as TAFE colleges. The operations of TAFE colleges are still the responsibility of state ministers.

The point I will make has been noted by a number of honourable senators in debates about ANTA, and it will continue later today. I wish to express a scepticism, and I hope it is a healthy scepticism. I state it again now to give encouragement to ANTA to avoid a danger that it faces. My scepticism relates to a second layer of empire bureaucracy that sits above the state bureaucracies and determines all sorts of guidelines about national policy which amount to a lot of motherhood. If it were anywhere in that direction that ANTA ends up, many of us will be greatly disappointed with this new national authority. We want to see end results in individual students and we want to see individual Australians equipped to make a good contribution to the Australian economy and to their lives and families.

It is this end point that needs to be kept in mind in the actual training outcomes of Australians. It will lead us to make our evaluation of ANTA, not as is naturally too much the case in the report that is before us now, with some very worthy generalisations which we would all support. I look forward to further reports of ANTA in the years ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 31, page 35, after proposed section 170MF, insert the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Commission to protect interests of certain employees

SPEECH.PARA: "`170MFA.(1) The Commission must comply with this section in performing its functions and exercising its powers in relation to an application to certify an agreement.

"`(2) The Commission must identify the employees ("relevant employees"), if any, who are covered by the agreement but whose interests may not have been sufficiently taken into account in the negotiations for, or the terms of, the agreement. TAB.TAB: (a)women;
(b)persons whose first language is not English;
(c)young persons.

SPEECH.PARA: "`(3) For the purposes of deciding whether it is satisfied as mentioned in paragraphs 170MC(1)(e) and (f), the Commission must do whatever is necessary to find out:

TAB.TAB: (a)whether:
(i)the relevant employees were consulted about the agreement, and informed about the matters referred to in subparagraphs 170MC(1)(f)(i) and (iv); and

in ways that were appropriate having regard to their particular circumstances and needs; and

SPEECH.PARA: "`(4) If it considers that there has been a failure to consult or explain as mentioned in subsection (3), the Commission must make whatever orders it thinks necessary to remedy the failure and its effects.'.".

As I previously indicated, the Greens have a number of concerns about the implementation of enterprise bargaining. While the rhetoric has been about worker flexibility and improvement of conditions, too often the reality has been divide and conquer and reduction of terms and conditions for little gain in pay. In particular, we have been concerned that those workers in weaker bargaining positions or those who may not be well informed or consulted may have their interests overridden by the majority. This would be the case, for example, with women, youth, non-English speakers and any others who fit into a smaller bargaining position. Women's groups, in particular, are worried about the potential impacts of enterprise bargaining on women workers, and I have heard them specify a number of fears. Surveys are also indicating some worrying aspects, though the overall verdict is still not in, due to lack of experience with enterprise bargaining and poor reporting systems in many states.

PARA.TAB: In order to increase protection of the interests of under-represented groups, the Greens are putting forward an amendment that requires the Industrial Relations Commission to do three things: first, the commission must identify any employees covered by an agreement whose interest may not have been sufficiently taken into account in the negotiations for, or the terms of, the agreement; second, the commission must ascertain whether the relevant employees were consulted about the agreement and had adequate information about the agreement and its effects; and third, the commission must make whatever orders it thinks necessary to remedy both any failure to consult or explain and any effects. These steps will have to be taken for both certified agreements and enterprise flexibility agreements. The commission is to be given a good deal of leeway in fulfilling these directions and there will not be any additional burden on those seeking the certification of agreements if they do the right thing by all their employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a couple of brief comments about this amendment. I would have thought that, in the context of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill and the way in which the functions of the commission have already been explained, all these points are already covered. I see amendments of this type as further cluttering up legislation unnecessarily and trying to selectively pick out certain people who might be in the workplace. We do not believe that this amendment is necessary to achieve these objectives. It is on the basis that we believe they are covered that we will not be supporting this amendment. We think it is unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS AND ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In a sense, Senator Crane has a point. There is an interpretation of the act that would say that everything this amendment does is covered and that this is a bit of a belt and braces approach. But let us proceed on a different premise of an abundance of caution.

PARA.TAB: The thing we are most concerned to do is to make sure that the act properly recognises the different strengths with which people come to the bargaining table. This explicitly seeks to do that. It says that there are parties to these contracts who are in very weak positions relative to others and it is necessary that we should take that into account. If the government had not felt that was done in the bill itself, we would have put in something like this in the first instance. But this will certainly make it clear to the commission that it is a primary concern of the parliament that those people who come to the bargaining table in a relatively weak position in relation to other parties to the contract need explicit and particular recognition and protection. Therefore, the government is prepared to accept the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will also be supporting this amendment on a similar basis to that which has been expressed by the government. The expression `belt and braces' may be appropriate, but we think that it is better explained in the actual text of the amendment moved by Senator Margetts. The final part of that amendment is quite instructive. Proposed subsection (4) in part reads:

SPEECH.PARA: If it—
meaning the commission—
considers that there has been a failure to consult or explain . . .

I think they are very important words. They are words that we really need to be careful about when looking at what has happened with the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, as proposed. At one stage in the very longstanding debate on it, I suggested that the minister needed to consult more widely. At that time I suggested that those with whom the minister should have consulted were the employer groups. Again, in this process, there was also a period in which there were certain other affected parties who believed, rightly or wrongly, that they needed more consultation. I would like to quote from a couple of letters I received in this regard. Both are from the National Pay Equity Coalition. The first letter of 31 August in part reads:

The National Pay Equity Coalition believes that the government's proposals to extend enterprise bargaining to non-union areas will be a disaster for women. We have compiled a page of facts and figures to let you know the true situation regarding women and non-union bargaining. We hope you find them informative.

I communicated with this group and I presume the government did too. Because of the outcome, I presume also that the government consulted and did what this very amendment suggests the commission may ensure is done. The government must have taken some trouble to explain as well. I believe there were also alterations as a result of this first communication. On 19 October, I received a communication from the National Pay Equity Coalition, which in part reads:

The National Pay Equity Coalition is much happier with the final version of the industrial relations legislation than we were with previous suggestions. We believe that adequate safeguards that protect women's wages and conditions are now in place.

It then goes on to express one of its remaining concerns. I think that process is an admirable process and one which we should ensure takes place at any alteration or consideration of any alteration to people's terms and conditions of employment. Senator Margetts's amendment ensures very completely that that will take place, even though proposed section 170MC(1) reads:
The Commission must certify an agreement if, and must not certify an agreement unless, it is satisfied that:
(b) the agreement does not, in relation to their terms and conditions of employment, disadvantage the employees who are covered by the agreement.

I interpret that Senator Margetts is attempting to ensure that all employees who are covered by that agreement are taken into account, not simply 50 per cent plus one. With this amendment, Senator Margetts is attempting to ensure that, when this bill says `employees', it really does mean `employees'—all of those who are considered by it. I think it is a worthy amendment to achieve that purpose and therefore we support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been various discussions with a number of groups who approached the Greens—the Democrats and other groups as well—suggesting that the percentage of people who are consulted should rise from 51 per cent to a higher percentage to try to make sure that there are not significant numbers of under-represented people who have been left out of the agreement or who feel dissatisfied or whose interests have been ridden over. We looked at that carefully. The reason, as has been mentioned by both the minister and Senator Bell, is that with the provisions in the act, which are admirable, there is no way of finding out necessarily unless we ask people.

PARA.TAB: All the amendment does in reality is provide the commission with a canvassing ability to find out. It does not say that the commission has to do it, but if there are reasonable grounds for it to think that there is a group whose interests have been overridden in the process, it has the ability to ask the questions. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reiterate the point that I made before. Without going over it, the explanation that Senator Bell gave absolutely confirms my point. I believe that the minister acknowledged that. One could well ask the question: when prescriptive amendments are going to be put in place, why are not disabled people, or a number of others, mentioned?

PARA.TAB: Following on from what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the minister have said about simplifying the processes, one would call this the duty of care of the commission in terms of addressing this matter and one would think it was well and truly already covered. TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go through those things I would otherwise have said in moving the amendment; perhaps I was too brief. As the bill stands at the moment, if the commission has been satisfied that an extension of a certified agreement would not be in the interests of the employees covered by the agreement, the commission would have to terminate the agreement. What we want, and what this amendment will make possible, is: if the commission thinks an extension is not in the interests of the employees, it will not extend it. The agreement still stands; it just does not have its term extended. Honourable senators would know that, when the period of operation specified in a certified agreement expires, the agreement does not automatically terminate; it continues in force with status like that of an award.

PARA.TAB: It would be anomalous—this is why we are moving the amendment—if an unsuccessful application for the extension of an agreement terminated its period of operation when, if there not been an application, it would not have been terminated. All it does is remedy a fairly small anomaly and make certified agreements continue beyond their specified period of operation, as they would if no such application for extension had been made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 9.Clause 31, page 39, after proposed subsection 170ML(2), insert the following subsection:

"(2A) A Full Bench must, within 3 years of the date on which a certified agreement continues in force because of subsection 170MH(3), and within each subsequent period of 3 years, review the operation of the agreement after giving the parties to the agreement an opportunity to be heard.".

Democrat amendments Nos. 9 and 10 are consequential and complementary. I will speak to both, even though I have moved just No. 9. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the laws of arithmetic, which have not changed, I can work out that the government is going to lose. For the record, we are opposed to this amendment. I am rather surprised that the opposition is agreeing to it because I think that existing provisions, which will enable the full bench to at any time review the operation are quite sufficient, rather than making it mandatory. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 11.Clause 31, page 41, proposed subsection 170NB(2), lines 12 to 16, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:
"(2) As soon as practicable after the application is made, the Commission must publish a notice, as prescribed, that the application has been made.".

This amendment relates to page 41 of the bill. It requires the commission to publish a notice, as prescribed when approval is being sought for an enterprise flexibility agreement. It replaces the requirement that the commission notify unions which are a party to an award which is varied by the agreement. This does not alter the right of such unions to be heard on application for approval. The Democrats support that right and, in any case, believe that the commission would grant such a right under section 43, even if this specific provision of the bill were removed.

PARA.TAB: However, the automatic notification of unions really smacks of the commission doing the homework that is rightly the task of the unions. We believe that a notice published in the law lists specifying the employer, and possibly specifying the award to be varied, is a more appropriate way of going about things.

This area has been a matter of great concern, and in some cases undue concern on the part of both employers and unions involved—the degree to which one group should be doing the work of another, the degree to which one group should be intervening in the affairs of others. I am particularly concerned that this opportunity to be heard at a commission hearing has been characterised as a right of intervention and, even worse, as a right of veto by some commentators on this matter. The recent case in Tasmania concerning the Delta Hydraulics agreement should be enough to demonstrate that the opportunity for unions to be heard in the actual conduct of the enterprise agreement hearing before the commission has been upheld by Tasmanian courts. It is a right with which I agree, and I think any sensible person should because, after all, what we are looking at is the alteration of an award in which the unions have had a considerable role. That is how in the past awards have been arrived at.

The right to be heard is a right which does not confer an opportunity for veto. It is not a right to intervene, it is not a right to impinge on the process of negotiation. The right to be heard is the right to express a point of view. Whether the commission takes any notice of that point of view is up to the commission. When I was speaking on Senator Margett's amendment, I noticed that the first part of the process of certification of agreement reads, on page 32 of the bill, under section 170MC(1):

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission must certify an agreement if, and must not certify an agreement unless, it is satisfied. . .

There follows a considerable list: (a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g) and (h). Section 170MC(2) then lists a considerable set of tests that the commission must apply. Not one of them mentions the union's concurrence or the union's agreement. Not one of them says that the union has the capacity to deny the agreement's approval. What is listed is a set of tests which are there to safeguard the enterprise itself and the employees. When those tests have been satisfied, the commission must certify the agreement. I remind senators of the word `must'—the commission `must'. The union has the opportunity to be heard but it does not have the opportunity to veto.I think we should spend a lot of time clarifying this aspect of the legislation because it has led to a great deal of fear and misunderstanding in this area. It is unjustified fear, I believe.

PARA.TAB: What we are asking for in our amendment is to reduce the opportunity of a group which is not paying attention, a group which is not interested, a group which is not servicing its members, a group or a union which is not performing the task which it should be performing on behalf of its members. We seek to reduce the opportunity of such a union to be able to put in perfunctory, matter-of-course objections. If we preserve that situation, we preserve a situation which is to the great disadvantage of both the employees and the enterprises involved. So it is with that in mind that I have moved Democrat amendment No. 11.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS AND ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposed to this amendment. We understand the motivation, but the problem is that the mere publication of applications without individual notification increases the possibility that a union will not be aware of an application. The notification obligation which is included in the bill is not going to be any major burden to the commission. The details of awards to which the employer concerned is a party will be known to the commission and notification will involve no more than checking off the list of respondents and notifying them accordingly—and in these days of union amalgamation that is not going to be a very long list.

PARA.TAB: What I am concerned about with this amendment is that the appearance of unions before the commission to represent the interests of employees who might be affected by the decision in one way or the other will be determined perhaps by the efficiency of the administration of a union rather than the merits of the case. It does not seem to me to be the appropriate process to have outcome determined by accident rather than judgment of the merits. It seems to me to be an unfortunate addition to the bill. I think it would be much better if we were able to do everything in our power to make sure people who have a right to be heard—and I accept what Senator Bell said about that matter in broad principle—are at least aware of the right. They may well choose not to exercise it, but that conscious decision can be based on the merits of the matter, whereas there may be some substantial merit in not being canvassed because the right to be heard cannot be exercised. For a right to be heard to be effective, one needs to know the circumstances in which the opportunity to exercise that right is before one. So I have some concerns about the amendment and the government, therefore, is opposing it.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7)Clause 31, page 41, after proposed section 170NB, add the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(4) This section does not apply where a majority of employees in an enterprise have approved an enterprise flexibility agreement by secret ballot.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will test those people who believe in the democratic process. The title at the head of this section says `Organisations entitled to be heard'. I cannot think of anyone who is more entitled to be heard than the employees in the workplace. This gives them the absolute and total unfettered right to be heard in what I would term the best of all processes in a democracy, and that is by secret ballot.

PARA.TAB: If the government is serious about freeing up the labour market and making the Australian position more flexible and more in tune with our becoming internationally competitive, I do not see how it or the Greens or the Democrats or Senator Harradine can vote against this amendment. From time to time we hear or read things in the press about the importance of the democratic process, about the importance of keeping its integrity. Under these provisions, when it comes to organisations entitled to be heard it lists—and I will not go through them all—a number who have a right in terms of the registration of an enterprise agreement to be involved in the process after the agreement has been reached.
I can understand that if there is a major disagreement in what is put forward, but the ultimate test must be to put it back to the employees themselves. That has to be the ultimate test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you approve of that, Burnsie?
—No.

—I will repeat: that has to be the ultimate test. That is a properly conducted secret ballot in the workplace with people in the workplace voting for the agreement. If one wants to play around with the wording, one could even say that 60 per cent or 65 per cent have to approve of it. But everyone knows that in an election once one gets one past 50 per cent one has won. I am not endeavouring to define that particular point.

PARA.TAB: In putting this bill together a lot has been built on the rights of individuals and the use of international conventions. I believe that to do otherwise than support this amendment one would be in breach of a number of those conventions. This amendment puts the acid test back on the government as to whether it believes in a democratic workplace in this country or in one that is controlled by outside influences. I say to those on the other side of the chamber and to those down that end of the chamber that this is the test of where they stand in the democratic process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Crane's amendment. It is worth putting to the committee that the government amended this clause in the House of Representatives. Originally, the only unions entitled to be heard were those with members employed in the enterprise applying to the commission. The amendment in the House of Representatives went on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: This section does not affect any other right of an organisation of employees, or of any other person or body, to intervene or be heard, or to apply to intervene or be heard, on an application to the Commission . . .

It is totally inappropriate for a union to be involved in enterprise agreements unless it is representing members in the enterprise concerned. This proposed subsection enables any union to come in and intervene in an enterprise agreement that has been determined between the employees and their own employer. It is one of these appalling things, the effect of which will be to diminish the rights of people who genuinely want to engage in an enterprise agreement.

PARA.TAB: The statutory involvement of unions will deter non-unionised employees from even attempting to negotiate enterprise agreements. It is worth quoting a recent Australian Chamber of Manufactures survey which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: .Only 8% of employers with non-unionised workplaces had entered into enterprise agreements requiring the approval or certification of the AIRC.
.42% of the non-unionised employers reported that the requirement for union involvement had discouraged them from pursuing enterprise agreements.

This makes a total sham of the remarks made by the minister and the remarks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that this legislation to introduce enterprise agreements was also meant to cover the non-unionised sector of the work force. That will not happen because neither the employers nor the employees want it to happen. They do not want their ordinary everyday work interfered with by some third party which has no relationship whatsoever to the organisation in which it is intervening. In fact, the terminology should be `interfering', not `intervening'.

PARA.TAB: The other comment made by Senator Crane was that the majority of the work force can decide things by secret ballot and there will be no union involvement. What is wrong with the majority of the work force making a decision? Is that not what our democracy is all about? After all, that is the way we elect people to parliament.

The second point, which I think Senator Burns took umbrage at, was the idea of a secret ballot. Anyone who has had any involvement in the work force and has seen militant unions at work will know that they have a vested interest in opposing secret ballots. There is a pretty good reason for that. People who go along to a union meeting to determine something that will affect them in one way or another—usually a strike—are not game to put up their hands to defeat a proposal by a union delegate.

What normally happens when the majority of the work force do not want to go along with the union representative—as I am sure Senator Burns will attest to because he is a honest man, even though a union man from way back—is that the majority of the people do not attend the meeting. I have seen this happen for years. One gets only 20 per cent of the work force turning up, and I have asked the people who did not attend, `Why didn't you go to the meeting?'. They say, `We're better off to go down the pub and have a few beers because we don't agree with what they're doing but we wouldn't be game to put our hands up'. As everybody knows, this happens in closed shop situations because the union has the economic power of life and death over those particular members; that is, `no ticket, no job'. It is not only `no ticket, no job' but also no democracy because the unions do not go along with secret ballots. The reason is that when they have to conduct a secret ballot, they cannot control their members. I find it difficult to believe that any reasonable person would not support a proposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —Go and have a cold shower!

—Here come the kneecappers from the other side, the left wingers. They talk democracy, freedom and all this sort of thing, but when they are put in a union setting all they want to do is to control the lives of other people. It is typical socialism. It is the stuff we saw in Russia for years and years.
—Social engineering.

—That is quite right. They are the experts in social engineering from the Labor side. It astounds me that people cannot support the proposition: `We have a vote and we have a secret ballot on that vote. After the determination is made that becomes the way in which the organisation will go'.
—What are they frightened of?

—We all know what they are frightened of, but that does not bother those opposite because they are only too happy to control the lives of people. It is an incredible infringement on the freedoms that a country such as Australia should have.

—I would like to endorse the remarks of my colleagues Senator Crane and Senator Parer. I do not think I would be astonished if anyone in this parliament got up and argued against the secret ballot. All of us would agree in a whole host of areas of our lives that secret ballots are important. In this modern era it would be a great surprise to me if we had honourable senators standing up in this parliament and opposing the right to a secret ballot on an issue which affects people's lives. If there are people who stand up and oppose this, I would hope they would only be on the other side of the chamber. It is my understanding that in the past the Australian Democrats have supported the use of secret ballots. I hope that they continue to support that.

PARA.TAB: In the debate on this amendment I thought that Senator Parer provided the committee with one very great insight. The clause as it now stands in the bill gives the trade unions the right to intervene in any arrangement in the industrial area; that is, any agreement freely entered into between employers and employees. It is a very worrying development that the government should be seeking to entrench a statutory right of the unions in that manner.

To translate, for any factory in a country town that is trying to make an enterprise agreement to keep its doors open in a highly competitive world, this will, in effect, mean that the John Halfpennys and the Wally Currans of this world—

TALK.START.PARA: —Both good blokes.

—Senator Burns says that they are good blokes. Only one person in this community has cost the jobs of more ordinary working people in this country than Wally Curran and John Halfpenny—and that is Paul Keating. These are people who have cost the jobs of so many ordinary working people. If ever a contradiction has been shown between the new Labor Party, which is mainly concerned with entrenching union power, and the old Labor Party, which was mainly concerned with improving the lot and jobs of workers, it came through that comment of Senator Burns.

PARA.TAB: This clause, as it is now, gives the John Halfpennys of this world the right to intrude into any factory where any agreement has been reached between employers and employees. I think that is a very worrying development. I would hope the Democrats will support the motion moved by Senator Crane. It is a very important motion; it is a motion which provides some protection for employees and employers against the power and privilege of trade unions. I think it is one of those tests that the Australian Democrats—a party which had its roots in small business—will have to undergo, as we wonder whether it is prepared to get up in this chamber and defend small business. I am fully aware of the enormous amount of work which has been done in the last two or three years by trade unions in lobbying Democrat senators trying to sway them. The ACTU has worked out that the main blockage to union power and privilege in this country is the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the Liberal Party!
—No. The ACTU was very much aware that Don Chipp's great slogan was to oppose big unions. Don Chipp stumped this country opposing big unions and big business.
—And big business.

—Big unions and big business. That is the historical basis of Senator Bell's party. I would have hoped that this would be an area where there would be no dispute between people on our side of the chamber—the Democrats and, indeed, the coalition—in standing up for small business. If Senator Bell will not support this motion, I hope he will get up in this chamber and explain to small businesses right throughout this country why he is not prepared to give them that freedom. I think this is an important test. Senator Bell can sneer, shake his head, carry on and all the rest of it. But small business is important—and it was important to Senator Bell's party.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate Senator Crane. This is a motion which, above all, stands up for small business. In the past Senator Bell's party has stood up for small business. However, if Senator Bell finds that he cannot support Senator Crane's motion, I would certainly like him to stand up in this chamber and record in the Hansard and over the radio why the Australian Democrats, under Senator Kernot, believe it is important that trade unions have the statutory right to intervene in small businesses, whether unionised or not, in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to hear people on the opposite side of the chamber talk about how trade unions operate and the day-to-day thoughts of trade unionists. If any of them have been involved in this sort of activity they are absolutely ignorant of these matters. Having conducted probably thousands of trade union meetings in my many years in the trade union movement, I can speak with some authority and quote instances where those opposite are so wrong as to be quite ludicrous.

PARA.TAB: I have always felt that the democratic process was important, but never have I seen the need for a secret discussion by trade unionists about their attitude to a particular set of wages and conditions that, with an employer, they may be seeking to reach agreement on. I have always encouraged open and forceful debate where people have put a point of view; it gives a clear understanding of the attitudes of people who represent those on the floor and how to go about negotiations.

I have seen situations, for instance, where a lot has been made of the fact that people vote a particular way because they do not have the protection of a secret ballot. Some years ago the National-Liberal party government in Queensland changed the legislation governing industrial relations to provide that strikes could be legally conducted if a secret ballot were held—and Senator Parer would recall this.

Quite a substantial number of people who were engaged in construction were involved in a dispute at the Gladstone power house. The dispute ran for some weeks and, finally, an order was made by the commission that a secret ballot should be held. During that time, included as part of the discussions, negotiations and meetings that went on, to which reports were made, there was a meeting of the wives who voted even more firmly than had their husbands in favour of a continuation of the dispute. But, finally, the Electoral Commission conducted the secret ballot and the vote in favour of staying on strike was even higher than it had been at open meeting—even higher. The point is that it was being said at the time that, if there were a secret ballot conducted, they would all return to work.

I do not want to see any small meeting at a workshop held to discuss conditions and wages being cluttered up with a silly secret ballot with people wanting to hide what they feel behind silence. They should feel free to say what they think and to vote however they choose—and they are. Let us look at this in comparison, though, with some other areas. Throughout this country there are virtually thousands of organisations continuing to operate and have meetings at which they do not hold secret ballots on policy issues, on decisions they make to go about the work for which they have been established; they do not do that.

For instance, if one looks at elections of people to boards of management, day by day we read in the paper who has cast their vote in favour of a particular board member. They do not hide behind the fact that they cast a million share votes behind a board member. But I must say this: when that board of directors is elected, behind the doors of their organisation they secretly make decisions every day which affect workers and people in the community; they do that secretly.

I do not believe that things should be done in that way. I think we should do things openly. Everyone should know what the discussion was about. It should be quality discussion and it should be clearly understood by everybody where the merits or demerits of any case lie.

The question has been asked: are unions afraid to have people who are in the workshop make decisions? Obviously, things that I have said in this chamber as well as history show that that is how I have operated always—having discussions in a workshop with people who are members of the union, although they are sometimes not, and majority decisions being made. But that has always been on the basis of there being some equality in terms of the negotiations where people have been empowered on both sides with knowledge of what the issue is about. It is not an uneven competition or contest where, on one side, we have people who know exactly what is going on—they understand the way in which the company is constructed, what its reserves are, what its policy is and are advised by the top industrial relations policy people available to them for whom they pay—and, on the other side, we have a group of people in a workshop who have had no experience with struggle or negotiation and who are so disadvantaged that it is totally unfair to go ahead with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what? That is what we are saying.

—Yes, I agree with the proposition that people should make majority decisions that way. But they have to be empowered by that knowledge and, through that empowerment of knowledge, have some basis for being able to negotiate from an efficient position of strength. What those opposite want and would propose is a situation where people will accept a substandard offer by the company that is involved. I reject that in every way.
—I was rather hesitant about rising—
—You have been trying to get up for a quarter of an hour.

—If Senator Bell will contain himself for a while, I will finish what I was going to say. I said that I was rather hesitant about rising last time so as to give Senator Bell, Senator Woodley and other Australian Democrats a chance to say why they do not support Senator Crane's amendment for a secret ballot. I will come back to Senator Bell in a minute. I gave him a chance; I was not in that much of a hurry to get the call. Obviously, he needs a bit more reminding.

PARA.TAB: Let us get back to the small businesses that the Industrial Relations Reform Bill is attacking. I said to honourable senators last Thursday that the whole bill is made to attack big employers but it is also taking down small businesses right across the country, and Senator Burns knows that small business is our biggest chance of reducing unemployment. On Thursday, Senator Margetts—that real champion of Western Australia—told us that the award in WA is $275 a week with unlimited hours of work. I do not think I have seen an award yet with unlimited hours—even Senator Burns, Senator Sherry and Senator Carr would not jump up and say that. I have not seen one yet. Have you?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in an award.

—No. That is what she stood up and said on Thursday night and she left it at that. Perhaps she does not know that small business has a lot of compliance costs—add-on costs; with her experience in small business she obviously does not know about that! She admitted that she has never employed anyone in her life.
—Who said that?

—Senator Margetts admitted that she had never employed anyone in her life. If she has changed her mind, she should put up her hand up and say so. Small employers—or big employers; but I am talking only about small business—have a lot of unpaid work to do. For example, collecting income tax is unpaid; there is a heap of forms to fill in to make sure that it is collected and properly accounted for. Small retail businesses have to collect sales tax without any reward or favour from the tax department. There are certainly a lot of disincentives for not collecting it, which I will not go into now. Small businesses have to collect prescribed payments and pay them within 30 days, or whatever it is. As employers, we also do a heap of other unpaid work which we have the privilege of doing on behalf of the government. Senator Margetts or anyone else, especially the Democrats—they are the champions of small business—
—No, they think they are the champions.
—That is right. The Democrats think they are, but they represented small business so well that they have been wiped out in South Australia. That is where the bulk of the Democrats—
—Tell us about the Liberal Party in Queensland.

—Senator Burns should not worry about the Liberal Party in Queensland. There are two Democrats from South Australia—a former leader and the deputy leader. The Democrats have been wiped out. That is how well they have been looking after small business.

PARA.TAB: I will come to the add-ons for small business. They are actual costs. Senator Margetts says it costs small businesses in WA $275 a week for unlimited hours—and she can perhaps apologise for that later, especially the bit about unlimited hours. She obviously does not realise that there is four weeks annual holidays, 10 weeks sick pay a year, 17 1/2 per cent loading on holiday pay, superannuation guarantee levy, employer liability payments, termination pay and so it goes on. When will Senator Margetts learn that small businesses have these oncosts and the costs of being unpaid collectors? The Democrats are much the same. Everything is loaded on to the employer.

The other night I did a straw poll of the other side of the chamber and the Democrats because I believed that no-one had employed anyone. Senator Spindler put his hand up. The others said that although they have not employed anyone, that does not mean that they cannot speak on behalf of employers—especially what is wrong with employers. But they cannot if they have not had the experience. They obviously have not, because none of them have mentioned the points that I have mentioned about the costs for small business—and big business as well, but I am talking only about small businesses that the government and the Democrats have neglected.

I just do not understand how they can speak on behalf of employers if they have not had the experience of being employers. If they have had the experience of being employees, of course they can talk about that, but not about employers if they have not experienced being employers. I just cannot see why the Democrats—the purveyors of everything good in Australia—will not support a secret ballot. What have they got to hide? What has Senator Burns got to hide?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a thing.
—Senator Burns gave us an example of when he had a secret ballot and the majority said, `Yes, we will stay on strike'.
—But it proved a lie of the National Party government of the day.

—It did not prove any lie. It just proved that at that time there was a majority. So what is wrong with a secret ballot? Senator Burns has something to hide. The only people who are frightened of a secret ballot are the union thugs, and some of them have come to that side of parliament. That is all they are frightened of. Why are the Democrats frightened of a secret ballot?

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I think Senator Panizza should withdraw that allegation that union thugs have come on to this side of the parliament. It is, in effect, what he was saying.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Order! I ask Senator Panizza to withdraw the term because it is offensive to members of the chamber on the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: I thought I said that some union thugs have come on to that side of the chamber. I do not think that is unparliamentary language. I would like to know under what standing orders I have to withdraw.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, Senator Panizza was not reflecting on members of parliament individually, nor do I believe he was reflecting on members of parliament collectively. Of course, there is a difference because one can call a government reprehensible or call people on the other side of the chamber reprehensible. But what Senator Panizza was saying, as I understood it, was that some people who had ended up on the other side of politics in parliament had been union thugs. That is not a reflection on them now. That is a reflection on what they had been before.

—On the point of order: Senator O'Chee is really misrepresenting the argument because I believe it is quite obvious that the person Senator Panizza would have been referring to would be a person we have already heard in this debate. It seems to me that it was directed at an independent person, not on either side of the debate, but a particular person who I believe is not a union thug.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—I have heard four senators on this point of order. I confirm my interim statement to Senator Panizza. I ask him to withdraw the remark on these grounds: it is not to my mind unparliamentary to use the term `thug'; it is not unparliamentary to make references of a generality to a group of senators or a party that would need to be withdrawn if directed at individuals; but it is in the standing orders that if a senator or senators object to and find offensive the remarks made by another senator, it is for the chair to request that that senator pay the courtesy to those objecting senators of withdrawing. Frankly, I cannot insist, Senator Panizza, that you withdraw. I am asking you to withdraw as a courtesy to senators who are offended. The actual words that were used is a matter for the Hansard; the glosses as to what was meant or who might have been referred to is irrelevant. It is a question of a courtesy to those senators who have objected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I will certainly withdraw if those on the other side have taken offence.
—Thank you. I call Senator Panizza to continue his remarks.

—May I also express my dissatisfaction with what Senator Woodley said, because I certainly did not intimate that Senator Burns—he is the only one from the other side who has spoken—is a union thug. As someone who shares the same birthday, I would certainly not call him a thug of any sort.

PARA.TAB: I come back to why the Democrats will not support a secret ballot. When the Democrats have a ballot for leadership of the party in the Senate—they do not have anybody in the House of Representatives, so leadership of the party cannot be held in that place—they have a plebiscite right around Australia. Mind you, the five or six Democrats in this parliament cannot even elect a leader without relying on membership for a decision. As far as I know, they have a full plebiscite and I think that plebiscite is secret. Bearing that in mind, I cannot see why the Democrats will not support Senator Crane's amendment. I cannot understand why the Democrats uphold the rights of anyone around Australia that they purport to represent if they are not prepared to support Senator Crane. I think any further part played in the debate by the Democrats should be considered irrelevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let what Senator Burns said go past without commenting. I remind the committee that the purpose of this amendment is to allow members of an organisation to have a secret ballot and, by majority decision, determine whether they will have union involvement in an enterprise agreement. It is as simple as that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Burns came in and objected to secret ballots, and used the example of a strike in Queensland at the Gladstone power station. He also made the comment that because all members should know what they were voting on, therefore, there is no need for a secret ballot and, therefore, there would be no fear engendered in a closed shop situation. Nothing can be further from the truth.

Just recently, within the last month or so, we saw members of the largest export industry in Australia, the coal industry, go out on strike for, I think, five days. The reason the coalminers went out on strike was that the miners' union chiefs said that they did not like the price at which BHP sold coal into Turkey. For that reason, they took the whole industry—our largest export industry—out across Australia. They said, `To hell with our reliability as an overseas supplier; to hell with the rest'.

The interesting thing about that is that miners from Singleton through to Moranbah, which is up in central Queensland for those who do not know, spoke to me and said that they had no idea why they were on strike; but that they were on strike because the union executive said they had to be. Those people went out, without any knowledge, in a closed shop situation. Senator Woodley is smiling at me benignly, as if this did not happen. But it did happen.

The point is that this bill attacks not big closed shop organisations—they already have their problems—but the small business sector. If this amendment is not accepted, the government will attempt to impose the same stringent controls over the work force as exist currently in a closed shop situation. The government wants that situation to apply to the 70 per cent of people in the small business sector who are not members of unions and who do not want to be members of unions. They want enterprise agreements and they do not want any third party involvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit hard down at this end of the chamber: one gets ones mind read by Senator Panizza; and one gets history read by Senator Kemp as to why one is on earth. The honourable senator wants to revisit policies of some 15 years ago. I do not think I have actually met the former Democrat leader, Mr Chipp. What was said is about as relevant as Sir Robert Gordon Menzies is to Senator Kemp's present deliberations.

PARA.TAB: Really, all this stuff is dragged in and thrown around. One wonders when one will get a chance to respond. One gets asked a few questions and 14 people intervene. I am complaining about the process which allows a question to be asked and half a dozen other people to interpret and anticipate the answer. Well, here is the answer—and Senator Crane will be able to anticipate our answer to the proposed amendment: the Democrats enthusiastically support the concept of a secret ballot. They practice it, unlike a couple of hypocritical groups in this place who wander in and say how wonderful it is. One really wonders what sort of leader might be delivered to the cacophonous group assembled on my right if a secret ballot were to take place for its leadership. I will not wonder about that for too long because I know that the process itself, in the right context, in the right place, is a wonderful device.

But I do wonder about its relevance. Those trumpeting the small business line are suggesting that we know nothing about this matter. We are talking about small business with an average number of employees—a work force of around seven or eight. I wonder about the relevance of a secret ballot in an enterprise of such a size.

However, it may be appropriate to direct the attention of the coalition to section 135 of the act. As Senator Burns has demonstrated, section 135 already allows the commission to instruct that a secret ballot be conducted, where appropriate. Senator Burns gave us an example. I support Senator Parer's criticism of some of the argument advanced by Senator Burns. It was pretty obvious to me that it would be appropriate for a secret ballot to be ordered in a great number of the situations that Senator Parer described. Secret ballots have been ordered in the past and they will be ordered in the future.

Under section 170MC—and this is my favourite—the commission must certify an agreement if it is satisfied. If the commission is not satisfied, it has the capacity to order secret ballots and it will be determined by the commission where it is appropriate to order secret ballots. I suggest that there are many situations where a secret ballot would be relevant, appropriate and, in fact, will be ordered by the commission.

The amendment that has been proposed will in fact have the effect of negating a union's right to be heard on an enterprise flexibility agreement where that agreement has already been approved by a secret ballot. Let us not get confused by the semantics that Senator Kemp and several other speakers threw at us. There has been a misunderstanding of the term `intervene'.

The intervention will apply in this regard at the point of the hearing. It will not apply at the point of negotiating the agreement. The impression was given that people such as those whose infamous names were mentioned earlier would be wandering on-site and intervening in the negotiating process. That is not the case. The intervention will be at the point of being heard, at the certification of the flexibility agreement. As a result of devastating ignorance, this misconception has been exaggerated and multiplied by those who have sought to misrepresent what the process actually is.

The intervention which is being spoken about here is in the process of the hearing, not in the process of the negotiation. Let us be sure about that. What has been revealed is the ignorance of those who would criticise the level of experience of some of us who have contributed to this debate.

I started off this little contribution with a criticism of the process by which several speakers can get up, ask rhetorical questions and deny the opportunity to answer any of them until either they have left the chamber or their contribution has been forgotten by the listeners. I am offended by that process. In criticising that, I also criticise the opportunity given to people who really only come in here to display their ignorance of other people's experience or qualifications. We have sat here for several days, and in the past months as well, and been on the receiving end of unfounded accusations that either experience or qualifications are lacking and that, therefore, contributions should be withheld.

Senator Kemp is a great one for this, and Senator Panizza also made a contribution along those lines recently, although I do not see that the lack of qualifications or experience in all sorts of other human endeavour stops them from contributing to debate on any number of things. An example is medical experience. I do not know how many brain surgeries Senator Panizza has conducted, but I do believe that contributions on those things—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I take offence at being branded—
—Are you a brain surgeon?

—Is there any chance of getting former Senator Button back so this bloke does not show his ignorance any further? I take offence at what Senator Bell has been saying—that I displayed ignorance by talking about people's lack of experience when I spoke earlier about employers. I take offence at being called ignorant, so I think Senator Bell ought to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Senator Panizza, I did not hear any sentence of Senator Bell's saying that you were ignorant. Senator Bell, if you did say that, would you please withdraw such a matter that is offensive to Senator Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on the point of order to explain what I was actually trying to get to.
—Did you say `ignorant'?
—I certainly used the word `ignorant'.
—Would you please withdraw that, as Senator Panizza finds it offensive to be called `ignorant'.
—I did not call Senator Panizza ignorant in any way, shape or form.
—With that assurance, I ask you to continue your speech.

—My contribution was meant to demonstrate how offence can be taken when contributions made in these debates rest on the ignorant assumption that one person can come in here and assume to know all about another person's past, experience or qualifications, and that that ignorance is demonstrated almost daily in debate by those who contribute in such a manner as to describe other senators' experience or qualifications as not being present, without knowing anything of such experience or qualifications.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza rose to his feet when I suggested that there were contributions made in the medical area by those who, I presume, are neither brain surgeons nor anaesthetists and who do not have any other qualifications in the area. Contributions are made in the area of defence by those who have limited service and by those who have no service. Contributions are made in the areas of education, sailing, swimming and sunbathing by those who do not have a lot of experience or qualifications in any of those areas. Yet we have this debate, predicated on assumptions made about other people's lack of experience or qualifications in employment.

I would like to put on the record that those assumptions have, in the main, been wrong. I think that nearly everybody who has contributed in this debate has been an employee at some stage, and a great number have been significant employers of several hundred people, without the knowledge or the permission of the contributors from the coalition. I suggest that further contributions based upon that ignorance should be recognised for what they are—ignorant.

Having disposed of that difficulty that I have in listening to some of the criticisms that have been directed our way, I return to the amendment that has been moved by Senator Crane and remind those who are listening that the capacity for a secret ballot exists upon the determination of the commission. The commission decides whether to determine that a secret ballot be held to determine the true will and opinion of the affected employees in any agreement.

If this amendment were agreed to, it would negate the right to be heard of a union that was affected by this, if at a workplace a secret ballot had been held. I remind honourable senators that that could mean, as it did in the case of Delta Hydraulics in Tasmania—I am sure that Senator Sherry, who may contribute to this debate, would recall the case—that such a path could be followed and later be found by the court to be invalid. I believe that such an amendment would suffer a similar fate. It would very soon be able to be demonstrated that it was both unjust and unwarranted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Kemp, I ask honourable senators not to spend large amounts of time on issues apart from the amendment actually before us, which is opposition amendment No. 7.

—I want briefly to respond to a number of Senator Bell's comments. I am very proud to belong to a party that was founded by Sir Robert Menzies and I would have hoped that Senator Bell would be proud to be a member of a party that was founded by Don Chipp. Senator Bell's admission that he could not care less about that actually helps sustain the point I am making. Former Senator Chipp, as a passionate supporter of small business, has said on the record that he is very concerned about how he felt the Democrats would vote on this bill. Indeed, experience is now proving him correct.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell raised the issue of whether people had the experience and qualifications to speak on this matter. I will not enter into that, but I put to Senator Bell that if he does not feel that the words, advice and debating points being made by members of the coalition on this matter are worth listening to, why does he not listen to what small business is saying? Why not listen to the people who will be directly affected by this?

I would have thought that in relation to this bill Senator Bell and Senator Kernot would have listened very carefully to the opinions of people in small business. They can wipe our opinions if they like and say, `Well, they're Liberals, I'm not going to agree with them', but why not listen to what those in small business are saying on this bill and listen to their concerns, particularly about the entrenchment of union power and privilege? The Democrats are not listening to small business at all. Small business is virulently opposed to this bill. They are not listening to small business, and to pretend that they are is quite wrong. I think that they have listened—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are an expert!

—I have spoken to people in small business. Many people in small business in my area have come around to see me. If you are trying to tell me that small business is in favour of the changes to sections 45D and 45E, you are absolutely wrong. If you are telling me that small business wants to make it more difficult to fire a lazy, incompetent worker, you are absolutely wrong. If you are telling me that small business is opposed to a secret ballot and would welcome the involvement of unions in their business, you are absolutely wrong.

—Order! Senator Kemp, first, I ask you to direct your remarks to other senators through the chair. Secondly, I remind you of my opening remarks and ask you to direct your remarks to this amendment—amendment No. 7.

—I made two points. First, I asked, `What is wrong with a secret ballot?' I received a very qualified answer from Senator Bell to that question. Second, it is not that the commission at some later stage can call for a secret ballot, but what concerns me is the ability that this clause gives to the John Halfpennys and Wally Currans of this world to involve themselves in the perfectly proper, private dealings between an employer and his employees. I do not think Senator Bell effectively addressed that issue at all.

PARA.TAB: The fundamental issue here is whether Senator Bell has listened to small business or to the ACTU. Whose advice has Senator Bell taken? We learned from his remarks that Senator Bell apparently has dumped small business and taken up with big unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed section of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill that we are dealing with in relation to this amendment provides for the right of trade unions to be heard before the Industrial Relations Commission before an enterprise flexibility agreement is approved by that commission. This amendment provides for an additional clause to be added, which is worded:

SPEECH.PARA: This section does not apply where a majority of employees in an enterprise have approved an enterprise flexibility agreement by secret ballot.

This amendment seeks to withdraw the right of a trade union to be heard before the Industrial Relations Commission where a majority of employees in an individual enterprise have agreed to an enterprise flexibility agreement. That is a quite logical and proper amendment to make to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: If a majority of employees in a particular enterprise have approved an enterprise flexibility agreement by secret ballot, what need or justification, what rhyme or reason is there for a trade union to get involved in that matter? What rhyme or reason is there for a trade union to be heard by the Industrial Relations Commission in regard to a specific enterprise flexibility agreement when a majority of the employees have, by secret ballot, said that that is what they want?

We are talking here of a situation where there are no union members on site, no union members employed by that particular enterprise. In this legislation they are still given the right to appear before the Industrial Relations Commission. If an enterprise flexibility agreement is approved by secret ballot by a majority of employees, it is clear to me that that enterprise flexibility agreement has been achieved without any of the intimidation that some may like to allege might occur with some enterprise flexibility agreements being established. If there is a clear decision by a majority of employees in a secret ballot, no intimidation has been present in the way which may occur if the agreement was achieved by means other than a secret ballot.

It is also clear that an enterprise flexibility agreement does not have general application. It applies only to a particular enterprise. It cannot be argued that the unions ought to have the right to appear before the Industrial Relations Commission because a particular agreement might have effects at other enterprises, because it might flow on to other enterprises where there are union members present and where the union therefore may claim to have some legitimate interest. The very nature of an enterprise flexibility agreement is that it applies only to that individual enterprise.

There is no reason for the unions to have a right to appear before the Industrial Relations Commission in the circumstances where a majority of the employees in that particular enterprise have said by secret ballot, `This is what we want. This is the way we want to go. This is the agreement we want with our employer. We agree to it'. As I said, it is done by secret ballot and without intimidation.
