There ought not to be the opportunity for a trade union, which has no legitimate interest in the affairs of that enterprise and those employees, to have the right to try, by appearing before the Industrial Relations Commission, to prevent that enterprise flexibility agreement being accepted and registered. That is why this amendment ought to be incorporated within the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is an attempt to enshrine in this legislation a bare modicum of industrial democracy. It seeks to give people who have already exercised a choice, by choosing not to belong to a union, the opportunity of making it incredibly clear whether they want the union to participate in the process before the commission. These people have already voted once with their feet not to belong to a union. We seek by this amendment to have secret ballots so that these people, for the avoidance of any doubt, can express their clear views on whether they want a union to be present before the commission.

PARA.TAB: What is wrong with people being entitled to say, secretly in a ballot, yea or nay to union participation in this process? What is there to be achieved by denying those people a process which I understand is guaranteed to people in Russia—that is, a right to a secret ballot? I know that there are people on the other side of the chamber who look askance when one says `secret ballot'. To those people a secret ballot is only secret if one shows at least one other person how one voted.

We on this side of the chamber believe that there is nothing wrong with a secret ballot. Why should a person who has already voted with their feet not to belong to a union be obliged to make an application and to fight for a right to have a secret ballot? Why should somebody have to apply for an order for a secret ballot? It is perverse to say that there is something intrinsically wrong with a secret ballot.

Those who oppose this amendment are saying, `We do not believe that a secret ballot is an appropriate way to proceed'. The people who are supposedly interested in the rights of employees are saying, `We do not believe employees should have a right to exercise their own conscience and their own freedom of choice by way of secret ballot'.

Those opposite believe that for one of two reasons. The first is that they believe secret ballots are intrinsically bad, which in itself is a ludicrous statement. That assumes that secret ballots are worse than the alternative to a secret ballot—namely, a public ballot which everybody knows to be wholly objectionable, wholly unconscionable and open to all sorts of terrible intimidation and manipulation. That goes without saying. Secondly, they believe that the better alternative is to give people no right at all, or to have to fight for the right to a secret ballot.

Either they believe secret ballots are bad, or they do not want the secret ballot to proceed for another ulterior motive. Surely the ulterior motive is fear. It is fear that the workers will exercise their rights, the workers' rights, in a manner which would preclude the union from being present before the commission—not in all cases but in this particular case—for a hearing to ratify this particular agreement.

That situation in itself raises some grounds for concern. These people would have already voted once with their feet. They would be voting yet again not to have the union present and for it to have absolutely nothing to do with the matter. The people who oppose this amendment are saying, `Notwithstanding the views of the employees who have twice expressed that they are against the presence and participation of the union in this process, somehow the union should be brought in over the top, contrary to the wishes of the workers in that workplace'. That is an incredibly patronising view. That view suggests that the workers do not know what is good for them.

That may have been the case at the turn of the century when some of the redoubtable union leaders came upon the scene. In those days in Australia, people were not on the whole terribly well-educated and exposed to concepts such as they are today. I would have thought that workers in the 1990s are at least capable of doing some basic arithmetic to work out whether they would be better or worse off and are at least sufficiently well-educated to be able to exercise some sort of conscience and free choice.

I note that hilarity and laughter has come from other end of the chamber. We shall see in just a few minutes exactly where everybody in this chamber stands, even those who have been assiduously sitting up the back of the chamber and sniggering. We will be calling a division on this amendment because we do not believe in the patronising view which is being expressed by those who are opposed to the amendment.

Moreover, we believe that there is an ulterior motive in wanting the union to be present. This arises not just because those who oppose this amendment do not believe that workers are capable of exercising their own minds without assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's just a smokescreen.

—That is a smokescreen. The motive is to get the union to appear all the time. There are three things that the union could say before the commission. In one instance, it might agree to the voluntary employment agreement. If it agrees to the agreement, why is it bothering to turn up? If the workers say, `We don't want you', and the union agrees, why should the union have the right to turn up anyway? The union is superfluous.

PARA.TAB: The union will be saying one of two things. It will be saying, `We do not believe that this agreement is in the best interests of the workers'—again, we get back to the patronising view that the union thugs know better than the workers whom they purport to represent; or, in this case, whom clearly they do not represent because the workers have told them where they can go and put their union tickets—or, in the alternative, they will be saying, `We do not believe that this agreement is in the best interests of union members who are not in this workplace'.

Why would that be? Clearly, the union members who are not in that workplace and who are not covered by the agreement will not lose any rights. They will not lose their pay, because this agreement is for that workplace only. They are afraid that the union members will wake up to the fact that the union is not doing a terribly good job of representing them. This occurred in the Gazal case. The union took the view that it would prefer to close down the factory rather than see these people make an agreement which they thought might show up the union.

The ulterior motive is the protection of unions, not the protection of workers. Ultimately, the protection of unions means the protection of trade union officials. A good union can adequately and effectively represent its members, be it in the workplace or other areas, and I congratulate unions on looking to give other benefits to their workers. A good union will always continue to exist and flourish. But the lax, large and uncompassionate unions are protected by this amendment. That is why we believe those who oppose this amendment do not have the best interests of workers' rights at heart.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respect Senator O'Chee, I have a great deal of time for him and admire many of his contributions. However, I feel that I have at heart both the workers' interests and the interests of industry. I reject any proposal which suggests that anyone who votes against this amendment does not have at heart the workers' interests, the employers' interests or the interests of orderly industrial progress. I admit that I have not heard all speeches in this debate because I have other commitments, but I cannot believe some of the remarks I have heard. The opposition is really saying, `Return to the shop committees. Let decisions in respect of industrial relations be completely determined by a shop committee'.
—Leave it as it is now. That's right, Brian; leave it as it is now.

—Senator Kemp's forebears appealed to me 25 years ago to stop the actions of the shop committees, which bred the likes of Laurie Carmichael and so forth. They were the ones who were appealing to me, as the then secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, to drag them into line. They said, `Look at what they are doing. They are murdering industry', which is precisely what they were doing at that time. The pro-communist Left was saying, `We make the decisions in this enterprise and that is that. We will come to an agreement with the employers'. It did come to `agreements' with the employers in, for example, the metal trades industry employers because it had the whip hand at that time. There was full employment then, and the unions could demand and get what they liked.

PARA.TAB: I remember meeting after meeting in the ACTU executive with Albert Monk, the then president of the ACTU executive, and Harold Souter, the secretary. I received appeal after appeal from employers to do something about the action that was taking place on the job. The issue was determined completely on an enterprise basis, irrespective of its effect on other enterprises, on orderly industrial progress or, more importantly, on the economy.

I will deal with the amendment in a moment. The opposition should remember what history has said. If it is going along this path and virtually saying that all areas of industrial relations, including conditions and wages, are to be determined on the job, it is doing precisely the same thing as the pro-communist Left did 20 to 25 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, Brian, that's not true.
—It is. One day, I might even write a book about this. I would love to have the time to do that.
—Why not.
—Yes, why not.
—I'll write the foreword for you. I'm sure it will be a best seller.
—I thank Senator Crane. I have this information in my files. I do not know where to lay my hands on those files at this time. Today is the 18th year since my first election to this place.

PARA.TAB: Some of those old TTLC files are in big boxes. Many honourable senators will know what I mean. Who knows where these documents are. They will be somewhere. I will find them at some stage. They will show a very interesting pattern.

I object to the implication that by voting, as I will, against this proposal I am voting against the best interests of unionists and employers. This will come and revisit the opposition if and when full employment returns.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's no prospect of that with a Labor government.

—This parliament needs to have a good look at the problems of unemployment. I do not want to go into that at this time. I do not know what the big argument is all about. I heard enough of the argument to understand that some honourable senators are saying that this is all about secret ballots. From my reading, it is not all about secret ballots. This legislation seeks to declare that section 170NB will not operate if there is a secret ballot and the majority of employees have voted in that secret ballot.

PARA.TAB: I will give the chamber an example. This precludes people in the same industry, not in the same enterprise, to have the right through their organisation to have a say at the actual hearing before the commission. The commission can instruct that a secret ballot take place. The opposition does not say who will take part in the secret ballot. The opposition is presuming that all of the employees of the enterprise will take part. Will that ballot include all of the full-time employees, all of the part-time employees—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about seasonal workers?

—Will that ballot also include all of the seasonal workers and all of the school casuals? Surely the opposition is not suggesting to me that the vote of an enterprise with 50 employees—and 25 per cent of those are school casuals—will, under these circumstances, prevail over everything, including orderly industrial progress and the interests of the community and the industry as a whole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to initially comment on the remarks made by Senator Harradine. I have a great respect for Senator Harradine, but I think he is not reading the clause correctly. This clause enables unions to become involved in an enterprise agreement where they have no involvement. In other words, where employees and employers get together and wish to apply for an enterprise agreement, the Industrial Relations Reform Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: This section does not affect any other right of an organisation of employees, or of any other person or body, to intervene or be heard, or to apply to intervene or be heard, on an application to the Commission . . .

This is to get a certified enterprise based agreement. Senator Bell said that we do not have to have a secret ballot of employees because there is already a provision in the Industrial Arbitration Act that provides for the commission to order a secret ballot. That is arrant nonsense, and Senator Bell knows it. I will tell honourable senators why. Individuals have no role to play at all in the Industrial Relations Act. It is only unions and employers, through their organisations, that have a say. Individuals do not count. They have no role to play.

TALK.START.PARA: —No rights.
—They have no rights at all under the Industrial Relations Act.
—They will have. That's why we are amending it—to give them rights.

—I think Senator Bell knows—unless something is wrong with his mental processes—that it is only when a group comes before the commission that it can request the commission to call for a secret ballot. This amendment is suggesting that the majority of employees—and we have to remember that 70 per cent of the private sector work force is at the moment non-unionised and they do not want to be unionised—can come to an agreement and have a secret ballot and say that they do not want any third party involvement. Senator Bell will not allow them to do this.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats said many years ago that they represent small business. Senator Bell also said in his address that he is reflecting the views of small business. I would like Senator Bell to give me just one example of a small business group that goes along with this idea. Small business groups are opposed to it. They are opposed to the removal of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. They are opposed to this bill because it is an attempt, by coercion and intimidation, to force people to become members of an organisation to which they do not wish to belong.
A remark was made about intimidation. Intimidation occurs when these union people come in uninvited and when they are not wanted by the employees or employers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.

—Senator Bell says that he agrees with that. If he agrees with that why does he not support this amendment which supports workers' rights? I can recall those bad old days that Senator Harradine spoke about. He made a remark about the shop committees. What Senator Harradine did not say was that those very people from what he called the communist left wing unions—
—No, the pro-communist Left.

—Those union organisers were the people that the groups Senator Harradine represented in those days were trying to do something about because they were destroying the Australian economy. We are talking about a position which has changed fairly dramatically. Some 70 per cent of people in the private sector are non-unionised. I think this is what is called the post-industrial phase. The Labor Party, which is traditionally the political arm of the trade union movement, is concerned about that and it is wanting to unionise people against their will. The Labor Party no longer represents the blue collar workers in this country because they mean nothing to it any more. It is unionised white collar workers who are affiliated with the Labor Party who are calling the shots. We have seen the government go into a whole range—

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. We have sat here for an hour and a half. You have on a number of occasions drawn the attention of speakers to the provision we are supposed to be discussing. This is Senator Parer's third contribution on this clause. He is not dealing with the amendment. I would ask you to make him speak to the amendment.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—I have been listening to Senator Parer. I believe he is speaking very directly to Senator Crane's amendment No. 7 and responding to the quite careful commentary in opposition to that clause that Senator Harradine has put. I take Senator Sherry's point that an honourable senator might have contributed three times. I ask honourable senators to keep relevant to the amendment. There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying—

—I am now being invited by Senator Harradine to stray from the amendment that has been proposed. I would love to debate that sometime, but I will desist. Let us take the opportunity at some time down the track to debate that very topic.

PARA.TAB: The remark I was making was that this amendment by the opposition will protect those people who do not want to be intruded upon by third parties in the normal day-to-day relationships they have. Senator Bell must be well aware of this. He is opposing it on phoney grounds. As I mentioned before the point of order, he claims that the Industrial Relations Commission, through the act—

TALK.START.PARA: —May order.

—May order a secret ballot. He has got the cart before the horse, and he knows it. What we are saying is that, when an enterprise agreement is formed willingly between employers and employees and they agree that they want this to be their agreement and not someone else's agreement, a third party should not be able to intervene in the process. It is as simple as that.
—In the hearing, not the process. Get it right.

—Senator Bell has interjected that it is in the hearing, not the process. If he likes to use some sort of technical language to split hairs, that is up to him, but it is the process. These groups have got together just to formalise something that they probably already do on a day-to-day basis anyway. What they do not want is a third party getting into the act. The tenacity of the unions in attempting to entrench their power was pointed out recently in an article by Judith Sloan in the Australian Financial Review. For those who read Judith Sloan, it read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the attachments of the unions to compulsory arbitration and the award system—
not the freedom of individuals and employers to get into enterprise bargaining, which is what we are talking about here—
probably has less to do with protection for low-paid workers than with underpinning the unions' representation rights.
That is what this is all about. The government knows this. It is not arguing against us on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—Judith Sloan. The government is committed to the agreement made between its minister and Bill Kelty. That is what this is all about. He kicked off by saying, `Let's have enterprise based agreements for the non-unionised sector'. But the trade union movement would not wear it. So we have ended up with this. As I mentioned earlier, the initial legislation in the House of Representatives allowed union involvement only when a union had its own workers in the particular work force of the organisation.

PARA.TAB: The clause, which we wish to amend, enables any union to get involved in the enterprise agreement regardless of whether it has any members in that work force. I remind those listening to this debate that, when we lose this amendment, they can point the finger at the Australian Democrats—not the government. The government is part of the trade union movement; that is its job. It is the Australian Democrats who have let down the small business sector in Australia, not just by refusing to agree to this amendment, but by refusing to agree to a whole series of other amendments to this particular bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened very carefully to what has been said here and I shall endeavour not to repeat what has been said—
—That would be impossible. Don't kid us.

—Senator Sherry is a silly little man at times. I just said that I would endeavour not to repeat what has been said. If Senator Sherry is going to make stupid, silly and crazy interjections like that, he is asking to be got stuck into.
—Get on with it and repeat it.

—If Senator Sherry behaves himself, I will. In essence, what this amendment could, and maybe should, be called is the small business amendment. I point out a couple of things which I did not say in my opening remarks. The first is that, purely and simply, this does not compel the employees in the workplace to have a secret ballot. It gives them the opportunity, if they so choose. I think that is very important. It is quite different from the proposition in section 135, which has been raised by Senator Bell and Senator Harradine. In that case, to have a secret ballot there has to be an instruction from the commission. In this particular case, our amendment gives employees in the workplace the right to have a secret ballot, if they so wish. There is a very big difference.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the point raised by Senator Harradine about the different types of occupations within a workplace. It is quite obvious that if the work force is made up of permanent employees, casual employees or employees of some other type, any agreement reached will be very different from that for a work force where the employees all work full time. I do not see how that in any way impedes the secret ballot.

It is important that we be fair. We spent quite a bit of time the other night debating discrimination. This particular clause, as it is now, discriminates very much against those employees who come into the agreement. It also discriminates against the employers. We notice that there is no provision for the employer organisation to be heard on behalf of the employer. It is a very selective discrimination in favour of the union movement. Every time we bring in legislation which discriminates in favour of one group, we tread on the toes of or discriminate against another group. It does not matter which way we look at this. This legislation is probably one of the worst examples of discrimination. Our amendment will put some balance back into the legislation—if the government chooses to exercise it. I think that particular point needed to be made.

The other point I want to make—and it is fundamental to the position of the Australian Democrats—concerns how a party can move or change its position at its convenience. It must be said that the Labor Party has been consistent in its position on this for a number of years, and I believe that we have been consistent in our position for a number of years. I have no doubt that when we deal with what I term the small business amendment, we will be looking at the history of the Democrats and how they have reacted to this legislation before us.

While Senator Bell may think that it is irrelevant, it is worth noting that a very different position was taken on industrial relations in the days of former Senator Chipp, former Senator Jack Evans, whom I knew particularly well at that time, and former Senator John Siddons. That position is in contrast to the changes that occurred when former Senator Powell and former Senator McLean were involved in issues such as this. At that time we saw the movement towards what small business fears most—mega-unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're just a mob of lefties.

—As Senator Chapman says, they are a mob of lefties. That is when the thrust to mega-unions was brought in. At that time there was no concern about the ILO conventions or the right of freedom of association from the opposite side of the chamber nor from the end of the chamber. Once again, much of this bill is based on the selective use of conventions and much of it will end up in the High Court. We must forget that when we put up legislation we have a responsibility in this place to try to avoid the lengthy cases and the drawn out situations which arrive from things being taken to the High Court. There is no doubt that this legislation will end up in the High Court.

PARA.TAB: I had thought that the Democrats had gone as far as they could to the left, particularly while they still claim to represent small business. Under the regime of Senator Kernot and Senator Bell, we have seen them moving even further to the left. In relation to that, they may be going down the track that Senator Harradine suggested may be taken. The Democrats are not taking the opportunity to take out some of the discrimination in this clause and to balance the ledger. I am particularly dismayed by that. As Senator Parer and others have said, all the small businesses which have approached me—I have talked to quite a number, and received many faxes, but I will leave the faxes out of it for a moment—have said that they do not want a bar of this legislation, these clauses and the way enterprise flexibility agreements are being handled.

I have no doubt that history will judge that the government's approach to bringing more flexibility into the labour market—picking up the thrust of Mr Keating's 21 April speech—did not succeed as a result of this legislation because too many barriers were put in the way of small business. At the end of the day, when the assessment is made on this legislation it will be primarily at the hands of the Democrats because they would not support us in this legislation. The government's position is purely and simply to pay back the ACTU for services rendered. We all know that. I do not see much point in debating that while speaking on this amendment. I certainly think that it is very important that if we are serious about giving small business the opportunity to develop flexibility agreements, this amendment must be carried.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We commenced this debate an hour and three-quarters ago. I note that of those opposite, one has spoken on three occasions and a couple on two occasions. It is regrettable that there is a certain amount of repetition in this debate because it takes up a considerable amount of time. I want to deal with a couple of the points that need addressing. I acknowledge that Senator Bell and Senator Harradine have comprehensively rebutted the claims made by opposition senators.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane raised the issue of so-called balancing the ledger and made the assertion that employers would not enjoy the same rights as a union organisation would under proposed section 170NB. The whole basis of industrial relations is in redressing the imbalance in bargaining power between employees and an employer. There is an imbalance. It is a matter of finding the mechanisms that preserve a relative balance in negotiating power between employees and the employer or groups of employees and groups of employers. Because employers do not have the same `right' before the commission, Senator Crane claims that that is discrimination. I would put it another way and say that he is saying that protecting people is discrimination. In effect, that is what he is arguing.

Senator Harradine was quite right in his contribution in this debate. Whilst I do not agree with some of the rhetoric he used, I do agree with the arguments he advanced and his central philosophical position on industrial relations—that is, the need to have a commission protect not only the interests of union members and employees, but also the interests of the wider community in general. That is a central principle that is held by Senator Harradine—he has held it for as long as I have known him—and a central principle on which he is correct. The arguments he put were very sound.

Senator Bell raised a number of issues that I intended to comment on. The opposition is attempting to amend proposed section 170NB relating to enterprise flexibility agreements. This section provides that a federally registered organisation of employees is entitled to be heard before the industrial commission on whether an agreement may be approved or whether an agreement's period of operation should be extended. It only has an entitlement to be heard if it is a party to an award that binds the employer in respect of work performed in the enterprise. Senator Parer was asserting—I notice he is not here—that any union could be heard. That is not correct. It is only a union that is a party to the award that attempts to bind employees in a particular enterprise for which the agreement is to be made that can be heard. So he was incorrect in his assertion in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only a union that has the right to cover its employees.

—Senator Murphy is right—only an union that has the right to cover the employees in terms of its constitutional coverage covers those employees before the enterprise. This section gives interested federally registered unions the right to go before the Industrial Relations Commission. It does not give them the right to exercise a right of veto; it gives them the right to be heard. That is the central principle that Senator Harradine and Senator Bell addressed. On what does it give them the right to be heard? It gives them the right to argue that there could be possible breaches of the statutory protections for employees. It gives them that right to be heard. Even if a secret ballot was adopted, what about the rights of the minority who did not agree with the majority in balloting on this enterprise agreement? Does not the minority have a right to be heard before the commission?

PARA.TAB: The opposition, by its amendments, is overriding the rights of a minority to be heard. I would have thought that a minority which does not agree with the majority in the ballot, whether in a union or not, at least has an entitlement to put a view before the commission. In effect, the opposition is excluding such a minority from even doing that. We are not opposed to secret ballots, but it is the point at which we exercise a secret ballot, it is the appropriate mechanism as to when we have a secret ballot, and this is not the appropriate time to have that secret ballot.

If the commission believes that it is appropriate to have a secret ballot, then as Senator Bell and Senator Harradine have pointed out, the commission will order that secret ballot under section 135. For example, it would be appropriate if there was uncertainty about the level of consent to an enterprise flexibility agreement. Senator Harradine raises a very important issue. It was a major problem in the SPC agreement about which we had much debate last year in the Senate. The enterprise agreement at SPC bound the seasonal workers, who were a majority of the work force at SPC at certain times of the year. But the seasonal workers were not consulted about the contents of the agreement. The agreement did away with many of the entitlements of seasonal workers. So Senator Harradine raised a quite legitimate point about who is the work force at the particular time when you have the ballot.

What we are saying, and what Senator Harradine and Senator Bell are saying, is that you should not take away the rights of a union to represent its member or members before the commission. You cannot take away its right to put an argument. You are not taking away its right to veto because it does not have a right to veto. I am also informed that employer organisations could appear and represent employers if this was necessary. Section 42 of the Industrial Relations Act does provide for that, so there is further argument against Senator Crane's assertion that this somehow is unbalanced. With those comments I ask the Senate to reject the amendment that is being sought by the opposition to section 170NB.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those remarks of Senator Sherry's cannot pass without comment. He objects to this opposition amendment on the grounds that it denies the minority the right to be heard if, in a secret ballot of employees of a particular enterprise, a majority agree to the particular enterprise flexibility agreement concerned. I direct his attention to clause 170NB(3) which says:

SPEECH.PARA: This section does not affect any other right of an organisation of employees, or of any other person or body, to intervene or be heard, or to apply to intervene or be heard, on an application to the Commission.

In other words, those employees can be heard at their own request. If they are not satisfied with the result of a secret ballot, they can apply to the commission to have their point of view put. Or, indeed, a trade union can apply to the commission to have its point of view put or, if you like, the employees can ask a trade union, which in turn can ask to be heard on their behalf. So nothing in the amendment that is being put by the opposition precludes the right of that minority of employees to be heard.

PARA.TAB: What this amendment seeks to achieve is to remove the automatic right of a particular trade union to be heard by the Industrial Relations Commission without any need to apply to the commission and put up argument as to why it ought to be heard. That is what we are about—removing this automatic right of a particular trade union which is involved with the award to which an enterprise flexibility agreement might apply to be heard without having to put an argument to the commission as to why it should be heard. It does not in any way remove the capacity for a minority of employees or indeed for a particular trade union to be heard if they have valid and good reasons to put to the commission as to why they should be heard. So that disposes of the argument put by Senator Sherry.

I wanted to deal with the points raised by Senator Harradine. As I interpreted Senator Harradine's remarks in relation to the opposition amendment—and I am sure Senator Harradine will correct me if I am wrong—and putting them in a nutshell, they were to the effect that this opposition amendment was returning us to the bad old days where the shop committees made decisions. In his terms, shop committees were dominated then by communists and, as a result of that, enormous damage was done to businesses and to the economy.

I believe that there are two fallacies inherent in what Senator Harradine has said. Firstly, we are talking here about a secret ballot of all employees at that enterprise, not a self-appointed or even elected group, but a small group of employees, a shop committee, making the decision but with every employee having the right to be involved in that secret ballot and to participate in that decision. More importantly, we are talking here about enterprises where there are no union members. So again we are not talking about a union shop committee; we are talking about employees who do not have any association or involvement with a union.

Secondly, in terms of the capacity of such an approach to inflict damage on enterprises more broadly and on the economy, therefore, what Senator Harradine is talking about is that from the decision taken with regard to this enterprise flexibility agreement there will be flow-ons to other enterprises. Other employees will get, in effect, the same deal. He is talking about the concept of comparative wage justice, that a deal and concessions and benefits won at a particular enterprise will flow on throughout the economy to other businesses, to other employees, so that everyone, in effect, gets the same benefits. That is the very antithesis of enterprise flexibility agreements.

I argued earlier in this debate that this legislation was a charade and a facade, that it was not going to get genuine enterprise agreements which were individual and appropriate to particular enterprises because the union movement will never give up the concept of comparative wage justice. So whatever benefits might be achieved at one enterprise will be sought in other enterprises. But if one genuinely believes that this legislation is about what the government claims, that it is going to get greater flexibility in the workplace, then there is no place for comparative wage justice in that concept. Again, the point made by Senator Harradine is, therefore, a fallacy. So on those grounds this amendment ought to be supported and passed by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pick up a couple of Senator Sherry's points and ask him a question. His comments in no way allay my fears that this is a discriminatory clause. He made particular reference to section 42 of the act. I have now checked what it says. Clause 170NB gives an exclusive right, firstly, to be notified and, secondly, to be heard to employee organisations or unions. It does not give the same right to employer organisations.

PARA.TAB: If I interpret section 42 of the Industrial Relations Act correctly, it says that, where the commission is of the opinion that an organisation, a person, including the minister, or a body, shall be heard in a matter before the commission, the commission may grant leave to the organisation, person or body to intervene in the matter. I believe what that is saying is that the commission may grant that right, whereas this clause—which I say is discriminatory—gives an exclusive right. I would be interested to hear the comments of the parliamentary secretary. I would like a full explanation as to whether what was said by Senator Sherry is the correct interpretation of this or whether my interpretation is correct.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane's assertion in his original comments, as I understood them, was that an employer could not appear before the commission.

—I believe that what was said about what I said was a misrepresentation of what I said. We will deal with it after dinner.

—Before the suspension of the sitting I had raised one matter with the then minister at the table, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry). PARA.TAB: I appreciate that there may be differences on this question between Senator Crane, on behalf of the opposition, and the government. That is understood. But I suspect that we are probably getting to the point where we are involved in a circular argument. While I appreciate the differences in position and emphasis, I realise that this clause has now been argued for some hours in the chamber. I think that we have probably reached the end of substantive debate on this point. There is little I can add to what has been said already.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have raised an entirely new matter which was not dealt with prior to the suspension of the sitting. If an agreement is amended when it goes before the commission, either by the commission itself or because of the ability of the union to be heard under this clause, then in plain simple English what rights do the employer and the employees who have come to that agreement have?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not want to prolong this matter but it seems absolutely extraordinary to me, if the minister's explanation is correct—and I am not disputing that it is correct—that we have a situation where a right is given but, in effect, that right does not mean anything.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me, from the answers that have been given to me, if they are correct—and as I have said, I am not disputing the correctness of the answers—that this particular clause does not really mean anything, that there is either a huge gap or hole in the bill, or that we are not being given an answer to what is a legitimate question which has been raised with me by a number of employers and employees who, as I have said, want to understand the mechanics of how they would go about this.

I do not know whether we need to bring back Senator McMullan or Senator Sherry, who know a little bit more about this. I am not saying that Senator Faulkner should; I am not having a personal jibe at him. But some people have some expertise in these matters. Amendment (by Senator Crane) proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: (8)Clause 31, page 41, proposed paragraph 170NC(1)(b), line 27, before "employees" insert "majority of".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be relatively brief because to some degree this amendment is similar to the coalition's amendment No. 6. Currently, under the provisions of subsection 170NC(1)(b) of the bill, on an application to the commission to approve implementation of an agreement, the commission must do so if, and must not do so unless, it is satisfied that:

SPEECH.PARA: wages and conditions of employment of the employees covered by the agreement are regulated by one or more awards (as defined in subsection (3)) that bind the employer . . .
Our amendment introduces the words the `majority of' before the word `employees'. The subsection would then read:
wages and conditions of employment of the majority of employees covered by the agreement are regulated by one or more awards (as defined . . .

This adjusts the threshold of the paragraph downwards so the commission can approve an enterprise flexibility agreement only if the majority of the employees concerned are covered by awards. As I indicated earlier, this is similar to our amendment No. 6, except that it applies to enterprise flexibility agreements rather than certified agreements. The whole aim of the enterprise flexibility agreements was to enable as many people as possible in Australia who wished to go into enterprise flexibility agreements, whether they be part of the unionised work force or the non-unionised work force, to do so.

PARA.TAB: Again, this relates to the majority. I suppose one cannot help wondering what has gone wrong with this country when one considers that the laws that have been made at all levels of government, I might say, going back 10 or 20 years, have been geared towards minorities. The minority views are important and they should not be overlooked, but in any sort of democracy the rule of the majority of people should apply with respect to any sort of agreement. I simply support the amendment because of that. It is all to do with the commission being able to approve the implementation of agreement where the majority of employees are covered by the agreement and regulated by one or more awards. Where that is not the case they do not have to do that.

I might just mention for the benefit of the Australian Democrats from Queensland that this important amendment was suggested to the committee that looked into this by the Metway Bank. The Metway Bank is a very interesting case. This was an agreement entered into freely between the employer and the employees of Metway Bank. While Metway Bank has union members—not many, but there is a percentage involved—the vast majority of employees are non-unionised. They had a ballot on it within the Metway Bank. They want to keep it that way. They do not want union involvement, neither do they want to be roped in—because the whole thrust of this legislation is to rope companies into awards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Conscription.

—I am grateful for Senator Kemp's interjection. It is a form of conscription. It is coercion and intimidation. No-one disagrees that people should be able to freely associate, if they wish, to look after their own interests. But forcing or intimidating them is simply no more than a pay-off by the political arm of the trade union movement who sit on the opposite side of this chamber. I like Senator Murphy pretending to play his violin over there; it is the sort of reaction one expects from the Labor Party.
—You have talked about Metway 10 times.

—Senator Burns has just interjected that I have talked about Metway 10 times. He is very sensitive about that. By way of retribution, honourable senators may recall that the Labor Premier in Queensland, because he was so upset about the fact that the enterprise agreement was entered into without any unions and because of the weight put on him by the unions, pilfered $18 million from Metway Bank, which was owned by the shareholders and the people who deal with Metway Bank. It was simply no more or less than that.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I rise on a point of order. Senator Parer has suggested that the Premier of Queensland had pilfered $18 million from a company. I think that is unparliamentary.
—What did you say, Senator Parer?

—We will have to look at the Hansard, but I think I said, `the Premier of Queensland'. If I said that, I withdraw. I think `the government of Queensland led by Premier Goss' is more acceptable, is it not?
—It is not acceptable to reflect upon a member of another parliament; indeed, it is not permissible to reflect upon the members of that government party in another parliament.

—I withdraw under those conditions. Mr Temporary Chairman, I would say, though, that I did have a debate on radio with the Treasurer of Queensland about this matter. I pointed out to him that if he were in the private sector and he did what he did, he would end up in the slammer.
—I suggest that you continue with your speech, Senator Parer.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I point out to the minister that this is fairly important. This was a landmark enterprise agreement. The committee was told that this was considered necessary. I think it was something that the minority of committee members took on board when they brought down their minority report in respect of this industrial relations bill.

—I am, of course, concerned about the hints that Senator Parer has been giving with regard to the situation in Queensland with Metway Bank. Our concerns are to do with what I think would rightly be called unfinished business in that situation. We are familiar with the assertions that have been made, and they are assertions with which all Australians should be concerned.

PARA.TAB: I think we should acknowledge that in previous industrial relations legislation in this place the arrangements that Senator Parer mentioned with regard to Metway Bank were fully supported by the Democrats. We believe that an amendment which was introduced previously in this place could rightly be almost called the Metway amendment, because it facilitated the arrangement which had previously been entered into.

The problem is that Senator Parer characterises this amendment as being necessary for the continuation of situations such as those which previously obtained at Metway. While it may have some relevance to that, it is not exclusive to the Metway situation and it does, by its very nature, permit and encourage the development—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's an example.

—I accept that it is an example—a very good example. It is an example which, if limited to the style of arrangement which we have at Metway, would deserve our fuller consideration and possibly our support. But the problem is that it does not just limit itself to the situation we have at Metway. By virtue of the very fact that it can and would extend a double stream in each enterprise—those who were in and those who were not in; those who had agreed and those who had not; those who were under an award and those who were under a enterprise flexibility agreement or whatever—it is not limited to the quite supportable situation at Metway.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats' support for that position can be demonstrated by our support for what was previously termed the subcontractors legislation, under which we agreed to make an exception for that which had been arranged at Metway. Our support can be demonstrated by that very fact. But our support will not be forthcoming for this amendment because it is not restricted only to the situation that has been described by Senator Parer as applying at Metway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never cease to be amazed by the Democrats who, when it comes to the crunch—as they are showing here this evening and as they have shown previously—seem, for every reason in the world, to be prepared to dump on the small business sector in this country. This is not the first time but about the fifth or sixth time that they have just ratted on the small business sector.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell has not given us any examples. He said, in response to Senator Kemp, that he believed that people in the small business sector supported this type of legislation. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is a figment of Senator Bell's imagination—I think that is the most polite way I can put it and remain within the bounds of parliamentary language.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight amendments have now been moved by the opposition and Senator Bell has supported us on a bare two of those. Senator Bell has supported the bill overall. We on this side of the chamber have tried to ameliorate the devastating impact that this bill will have on small business. At this stage, as the bill progresses through the chamber, we have moved eight amendments which would have left the bill largely intact but, nonetheless, would have had the effect of ameliorating the effect on small business. Senator Bell, once again, has failed to meet the test. We have asked him to stand up in this chamber and indicate where small business is supporting his position.
—I have answered it. Stop wasting time.

—Senator Bell has not answered it at all. It is not a waste of time when Senator Bell is asserting that small business supports his position. We say that this is a disaster for small business. It is not wasting the time of this chamber. We are asking Senator Bell to stand up and tell us which significant spokespeople for small business support his position.

PARA.TAB: As this debate continues during the evening we will be listening very carefully to Senator Bell, as we always do out of courtesy, to see whether, in respect of each of the tests, he will support the union position or the small business position.

As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, this is a seminal bill. It is particularly for small business. But Senator Bell, I regret to say, has decided to accept the union position on this and I think that is a disaster. It is a disaster for small business and I believe it to be a disaster for his own party.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really is quite ridiculous when the only example given in respect of this clause is that of a major bank, and when that example is laid on the table and purported to be the reason for what the opposition is proposing. We have the suggestion then that, because we have not addressed small business, somehow or other we have done the wrong thing.

PARA.TAB: All we are doing is following the trail through this legislation that has been carved by the coalition. In dealing with the parameters that have been established in regard to one side of an argument, it is idiocy to accuse us of not according to another set of parameters. Senator Kemp is off on an entirely different paradigm and he does not even understand why he is there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It never ceases to amaze me that when we have an amendment such as this, which covers the Metway situation but also has the capacity to cover like situations with regard to small businesses—or, in this case, a medium-sized bank—the Democrats could vote for or agree with the principle of restricting it to that, yet in a number of other like situations they could vote against it.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Parer and Senator Kemp have said, it really is just an outright attack on the capacity of small businesses to go about their business and organise their workplaces without interference from third parties. That is what the rejection of this amendment amounts to. I add to the comments that have been made by saying to the small businesses listening to this broadcast and the others who will follow this through that an opportunity which will allow them to be more dynamic and more flexible in the workplace has been denied them by the action of the Democrats in voting against this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —(8.42 p.m.)—I have been advised that to respond to each and every one of these concerns is to prolong the argument, but I would like to remind those who have presented this proposed new section as an opportunity for small business to attain the flexibility of striking enterprise agreements or enterprise flexibility agreements without the input from trade unions that such is a faint hope. I have given the example some, I think, dozen times.
—You have thrown in the towel—given up.

—The number of times I have given this example, I think, would be a dozen, but there are some cloth ears who do not want to accept the findings of the Tasmanian court. The enterprise commissioner in Tasmania brought down a finding of approval of an enterprise agreement where union participation had been denied at the point of being heard during the process of certification of that agreement. The Tasmanian court found in favour of the union being heard. I think this decision should be recognised by those who are suggesting that this amendment ought to be followed through.This faint hope that is being perpetuated is not a realistic one. If we were to support this amendment I suggest we would be supporting it in ignorance of what this court has found. I have made that point and I have given that example. I suggest that those who proceed with this, failing to recognise that example, are perpetuating a ridiculous aim.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Commission, in disregarding this, also has the opportunity to call those whom it thinks relevant to this case. I think it would be quite a misguided IRC which proceeded without at least hearing from the unions. What is being proposed is only that they be heard anyway. They have that capacity. That capacity has been recognised by courts. I think that to attempt to deny that capacity is to fly in the face of what has already been found to be a natural right—a right of natural law. After all, the expression of natural law, as I understand it, is the opportunity to present a case. To be denied the opportunity to be heard is something which our legal system is fundamentally opposed to and, rightly, should remain opposed to. That has not been listened to. I know Senator Kemp is anxious to speak, but he is not very anxious to listen.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a natural law to require that unions have a say in the activities of every business in this country.
—It should be.

—Senators Burns says, `It should be'. At least he is honest and he stands up for what he believes in. He does not pretend that he is standing up for small business and at the same time say it is part of natural law that trade unions have a right to intrude into the businesses of small business. I implore Senator Bell: this is the Labor Party, the political arm of the trade union movement; the Democrats are not the political arm of the trade union—at least, they were not. The Democrats were founded, among other things, on small business.

PARA.TAB: This is the eighth amendment which has been moved. The Democrats have supported two of our amendments. I say to them: do not quote to us what the courts say; do not quote to us what particular judges say. Why do they not quote to us what small businesses say? Why do they not actually address the issues of the people who are going to be dramatically affected by this amendment? There will be a number of other amendments moved during this debate. When Democrat senators stand up, if they wish to object to them, I suggest that they quote not what Bill Kelty says but what the people in small business want, because they are the people who are going to create the jobs.

This is not only an enormously important point for small business in this country; it is a very significant point for the Australian Democrats. This was the occasion on which, above all, they could have stood up and defended the 800,000 small businesses in this country. So far, I regret to say—and I hope that when we come to the end of this debate my opinion will be modified—the Democrats have failed dramatically in that test.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to Senator Kemp on this issue. As a Democrat and as a person in contact with a number of small businesses—at least, the number that I can cope with—who have made representations—
—Tell us who they are.
—I can tell Senator Parer who they are if he wishes.
—One or two?

—I can list them if Senator Parer likes. If he wants to take up some more time, I am quite happy to do that. I could refer to Mr Martin Janke, who has a prawn farm in my area and also runs a real estate business, who has made representation to me because he has been unable to get proper representation from the Liberal House of Representatives member in his area and believes that we are able to represent his interests far better than the Liberal Party is able to. That is just one; I could mention a number of others.

PARA.TAB: Let me, however, just reiterate what Senator Bell has said. Although the Liberal Party has made a lot of noise about representing small business, the only example it has given us is of a major banking institution in Queensland. It has not named the small businesses that it is representing. So again we have the problem of the Liberal Party using one example and then talking about something else entirely different.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the things that Senator Woodley said need to be put straight. It is most unsatisfactory for Senator Woodley to come into this place and talk about the Liberal member who represents his area. That Liberal, because he is not named, will not have the opportunity to defend himself. Senator Woodley left a cloud over who that person might be. It is one thing to get up and say, `Somebody came to me because the Liberal representative would not defend me'. We would like to know what that Liberal member was asked to do and what the situation was. Senator Woodley needs to be challenged when he makes accusations like that, leaving an insinuation against every single Federal Liberal member in Queensland—because that is what he is doing.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell talks about natural justice in terms of the right of unions to appear before the commission when an agreement is being dealt with. Other small businesses do not have that right. The employer organisations do not have that right. After argument, the commission may, as we have already canvassed, be given the opportunity to hear from the unions, but that is very different. The test of natural justice that Senator Bell refers to in relation to small businesses or large businesses—all business—has been negated by what the Democrats and others in this place are agreeing to.

It gets back to the matter of discrimination that we have talked about before. As soon as somebody is given an additional right over somebody else—which this part of the bill and other part do—somebody is being discriminated against. In this particular case, small business is being discriminated against most in terms of natural justice. The Democrats can wear that for as long as they like. This part of the bill will not affect large business to the degree that it will affect small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6)Clause 31, page 42, proposed subparagraph 170NC(1)(f)(i), line 2, omit "provides", substitute "establishes a process".

The purpose of this amendment is to remove a requirement that an enterprise flexibility agreement must provide for consultation on changes to work organisation and work performance. That obligation will be replaced by a requirement that the agreement must establish a process for such consultation. Without the amendment the provision could require consultation on every change to work performance or work organisation, no matter how minor.

PARA.TAB: This amendment will allow the participants in enterprise flexibility agreements appropriate flexibility in determining the circumstances which they consider should involve consultation. I commend this amendment to the committee.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7)Clause 31, page 42, proposed paragraph 170NC(1)(g), line 10, omit "the terms proposed to be included in".

The purpose of this amendment is to change the requirements concerning consultation with employees who are to be covered by an enterprise flexibility agreement. As the provision is presently drafted, the commission must refuse to approve the implementation of an agreement unless it is satisfied that employees were consulted about the terms proposed to be included in the agreement. This could require consultation with all employees on every term that was proposed, whether or not the term was eventually included in the agreement. This was not intended.

PARA.TAB: The amendment requires reasonable steps to have been taken to consult employees about the agreement. This will avoid unnecessary consultation over provisions which are, for example, not seriously proposed or which are withdrawn. Again, I commend this amendment to the committee.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 12.Clause 31, page 44, after proposed subsection 170ND(7), insert the following subsection:

"(7A) Subsection (7) does not apply in relation to an organisation if the employer could not reasonably be expected to have known at, or within a reasonable period after the time when negotiations for the agreement began, that the organisation was an eligible union at that time.".

This amendment applies to clause 31 on page 44 of the bill. One would imagine that, if all that the coalition had said on this matter were true, we would hardly be moving this amendment. However, we are. We believe that this amendment will have the effect of reducing the burden that is placed upon the employer in part of the requirements to inform those unions that are involved.

PARA.TAB: The amendment deals with notification of unions at the commencement of negotiations for an enterprise flexibility agreement. At the moment the bill requires employers to notify unions with members in the workplace that negotiations are beginning and to give them a reasonable opportunity to take part. The Democrats support the provision that, in an ideal world, notification of unions would be left to employees. But in the real world abandoning it in that way would increase the potential for employers to pressure employees to not do so. Our amendment provides that, where an employer could not reasonably be expected to have known that a certain union was represented in the workplace, failure to notify that union would not prevent the commission from approving the amendment. That reduces the burden on the employer and the obstruction to the process of breaching an agreement. It removes those burdens, recognising a little of the reality of the world and allowing things to progress much more smoothly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting this amendment for exactly the same reasons as those we put up in relation to our last amendment. It lifts some of the burden from business and takes away what we believe is an unnecessary obligation on business. It is indeed a pity that the Democrats have not adopted the same principle throughout this bill in dealing with the concerns that business has with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: We have gone through many cases in this debate where the liability that has been established by this government legislation could have been ameliorated. Of all the amendments that have been moved, this one is about removing some of the penalties which are being imposed because of that. Even if from here on in the Democrats supported our further amendments—which are all about the single principle of not putting barriers in the way of the employers of this country and the people who can address the employment problem—it would significantly improve this legislation and remove onerous obligations. On the grounds that this amendment assists in removing some of the onerous and unfair obligations, we will support it.

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 31, page 44, proposed subsection 170ND(9), line 14, after "colour, sex," insert "sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability,".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
