TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 31, page 44, at the end of proposed section 170ND, add the following subsection:
"`(10) Subsection (9) does not apply in so far as a provision:

TAB.TAB: (a)discriminates, in respect of particular employment, based on the inherent requirements of that employment; or
(b)discriminates:
(i)in connection with employment as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed; and
(ii)in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or creed.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment duplicates the exceptions that are set out in the definition of `discrimination' in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 in that that act does not apply to discrimination when either of these two exceptions are satisfied. The fact that an employer conducts a business in accordance with the doctrine, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed will not of itself be sufficient to attract the exception. The exception applies to employment in, for example, institutions established for religious, public, social or charitable purposes. A business conducted in accordance with religious or similar teachings will not necessarily be considered such an institution. Again, I commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly in support of this amendment because I believe that it outlines a very important exception that ought to be made. It parallels the exceptions that are made in the human rights and equal opportunity act.
—Because they are right.

—I will get to that. I want to underline what I am saying because I was misrepresented by a member on Senator Kemp's side of the chamber very severely the other night on religious discrimination. I was speaking about a number of faxes which have been received by members of all religious complexions in this parliament. It was said that I had described a particular group as a fanatical religious group. In fact, I described the particular group's interpretation of scripture as peculiar and particular. I used those words in their strictly technical sense in that because that group's interpretation of scripture is not in the mainstream, it is very particular.

PARA.TAB: I am very familiar with this group because my wife was a member of it for some years and I worshipped with them. I must say that it is the very opposite of fanatical. It is a very quiet group that goes about its own business. I do not agree with many of its interpretations of scripture, but I certainly would not describe it as fanatical. Those words were put in my mouth by Senator O'Chee and they are certainly incorrect.

I also said in my speech on a number of occasions that that group and any other religious group have a right to represent their own points of view. My only objection is when they seek to force those opinions upon other Christians.

Senator O'Chee's speech the other night was very interesting but, I am afraid, not very helpful in terms of the support that he said he feels for this group. I suggest that he was underlining and speaking against what this amendment tries to do. He was raising within this place religious prejudice. He spoke about patristics. I would like to let him know that the word he was looking for was patrology, which is the study of church fathers—patristics is an adjective. But, in fact, I was not talking about patrology.The study of the church fathers refers to the second to fourth, and fifth and sixth centuries AD. Certainly in those eras of the Christian church there was much discrimination and debate, which divided people from one another. I was speaking about the first century in which the new testament was written.

I could say a lot of things about this. I could draw Senator O'Chee's attention to an historical example which is very important to me. In the 1985 SEQEB strike in Queensland, the government of the time tried to discriminate against a group of Christians who took a particular part in that debate. These Christians were arrested under a law promulgated at the time by the National Party government and were charged under it.

The law was defeated in the magistrates court. When the state government appealed to the Supreme Court of Queensland the law was again defeated. Finally, in the High Court of Australia the law was again defeated. In other words, it was a bad law and bad government at the time. That government and that law was unable to discriminate against that group of Christians.

Another comment made by Senator O'Chee was that he could not find any reference in the Old Testament or New Testament to trade unions. Exactly, Senator O'Chee; that was the point I was making. Apparently Senator O'Chee did not listen to what I was saying. This is exactly what I am trying to say we need to address in the amendment moved by the government. There ought not be discrimination. When religious sentiments are involved people ought to be able to hold those beliefs as long as those beliefs do not interfere with the beliefs and practices of other people.
I could go on. Senator O'Chee made reference to the Reformation, which was a time when religions were bitterly divided. I think he wanted to re-fight those old divisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I say to Senator O'Chee that the ecumenical movement has overcome many of those divisions which caused not only bitter division but also the murder of many people for centuries. In recent years those divisions have been overcome and are part of the reason I am able to support the amendment moved by the government.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I will give Senator O'Chee another piece of information. The denomination to which I belong, originally the Methodist Church and now the Uniting Church, had some of its roots in the Reformation. But my particular denomination also had very strong roots with the Anglo-Catholic tradition. Senator O'Chee needs to understand that I refuse to allow him to represent me as someone who would describe another religious group as fanatical or seek not to allow it to have its point of view heard. I reject that aspersion. I support this amendment moved by the government because I believe it is certainly in the direction of all that I have said and stood for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have had the personal explanation under standing order 190 we can get on with the rest of the debate. The fact remains that Senator Woodley has throughout the debate on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill consistently supported provisions which advantage unionists over non-unionists. Senator Woodley has consistently supported provisions which enforce unionism, which give strength to the unions and which oppose the individual conscience of workers. That is the important point to make.

PARA.TAB: I do not intend to get into yet another debate about Senator Woodley's perverted view of particular texts. I merely note that there is a passage in Romans that runs along the lines of `they also gain pleasure that encourage these things'. I stand by the way the opposition voted. Senator Woodley can stand or fall by the way he has voted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley in his remarks a few moments ago said that he supported the rights of people to hold beliefs as long as those beliefs did not interfere with the beliefs of others. To my mind that makes those beliefs in a sense very ineffective. Certainly if people have rights which they wish to exercise, it is obviously beneficial if those rights can be exercised without interfering with the rights of others. If someone has very strongly held beliefs, those beliefs are largely irrelevant unless that person has the opportunity to exercise those beliefs or can act in accordance with those beliefs. If they are simply beliefs that a person holds in one's head then they are of no value at all. Unless people can give expression to those beliefs in the way they live, those beliefs are worthless.

PARA.TAB: If we are talking about beliefs that affect the way people run their businesses and we are going to respect the rights of people to hold those beliefs, those people must be given the right to exercise those beliefs. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill is particularly detrimental to small business. If we are talking about small business it is that person's business. People ought to have the opportunity to run their business in accordance with their conscience. That is why I believe the point made by Senator Woodley is fallacious.

Senator Faulkner moved this amendment on behalf of the government. In his absence, I will ask a question of Senator Sherry. We will certainly support the amendment of the government as far as it goes because it improves the situation. It provides an exemption for an institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed with regard to discrimination in employment. By what logic does the government include an amendment such as this which refers to an institution but excludes a business? People who own that business may similarly have doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed within which they would choose to run their business. The government is excluding a business from being run on that basis but is including what it describes in this amendment as an institution.

I believe it is false to draw a distinction between a business and an institution when the owner of either of those structures may have particular beliefs and wishes to run the business or institution in accordance with those beliefs. Why does the government draw a distinction between them when, in all logic, this amendment ought to apply to both?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If we approached it from Senator Chapman's logic, I could see why he would put forward business. It would open the floodgates to almost anything. If employers argued that they were conducting their business along particular religious faiths or creeds literally hundreds of thousands of employees could be covered by this section. That would clearly subvert the intentions of the Industrial Relations Act.
—Only if they could prove it.
—I think the balance the opposition is trying to strike is unreasonable. The amendment the government has moved duplicates—
—You're being inconsistent.

—I accept that the opposition is being consistent but I do not accept the logic of its position. We are being consistent with the terms and conditions laid down by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. The exceptions that are embodied in the amendment that we are moving strike the appropriate balance between those religious sensitivities of employers and the rights of employees. We do not propose to shift that balance any further than is contained in this amendment.

—I rise to support this amendment and the comments that have been made by my colleagues. As Senator Chapman said, we will be supporting this amendment. I also make the point that this amendment is an afterthought by the government, having agreed with the Australian Democrats to make amendments to this legislation which, in the opposition's view, are totally inappropriate. As I have already said on a number of occasions, this is what happens when we deal with matters which should be in other legislation.

PARA.TAB: I also mentioned a while ago that Minister Kerr gave notice that there would be further legislation from the government dealing with matters of sexual preference. Once the government agrees to amendments which are moved by a person or a party which is not part of the total process of putting the legislation together—and I do not deny the Democrats their right to move amendments—it creates a situation whereby it has to fix up or ameliorate amendments.

The problem with this particular amendment is that it does not go anywhere near far enough to address some of the legitimate concerns of individuals. It certainly appears to address the situation which exists for religious institutions, but it does not address the situation for individuals. As we have already said, but I will repeat it again, some people—whether their creed is Christian, Muslim, Buddhist or something else—do hold particularly strong beliefs and they live by those beliefs. The effect of what has happened here will unfortunately force those people to make a conscious decision to break the law. They have no other alternative but to break the law. That is the effect of what has been done to the industrial relations legislation, and I think that is tragic. It is a sad day for a lot of people in Australia who, as individuals, are concerned about this—

TALK.START.PARA: —And very law abiding.
—And very law abiding people, as Senator Chapman said.
—That is a contradiction; how can they be law abiding if they break the law?

—That is not a contradiction. Because of their beliefs, they will have no option but to break the law. They are being forced to do that. It is not an easy question to deal with. As I have said, I think it is a tragic day for Australia, particularly with respect to industrial relations legislation. The question I want to ask Senator Sherry relates to the exemption contained in this amendment. Does this amendment cover institutions such as child-care centres, kindergartens and preschools?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The exemption is confined to an institution. The commonly accepted definition of an institution is `an organisation for promotion of a public objective'. A private business would therefore not be an institution. So the types of businesses that Senator Crane has just named would not fall within the coverage of this definition.
—So that means the preschool in my home town of Jerdacuttup, which is a state government institution, is not covered. Is that what Senator Sherry is telling us?

—At the end of the day, that particular organisation or business would have to argue in a court that it is an institution within the meaning of the act. But I do not believe that it would be covered by this exemption.
—What is the situation with the preschool and kindergarten section of my old school, the Southport School?
—Oh, come off it!

—That is a fair question. Senator Sherry says, `Oh, come off it!', but we want to know to what we are agreeing. The government moved this amendment. We want to know the extent of the amendment. I assume that the Southport School itself is covered, but what about the preschool or kindergarten that is part of the Southport School?
—My previous answer stands.
—Senator Sherry's previous answer was in relation to a commercially run preschool or child-care centre. What is the situation in relation to the preschool at Southport School?

—I add to the question asked by Senator O'Chee. What is the situation with regard to a child-care centre, a preschool or a kindergarten run by a church, as distinct from one that is run as a commercial for profit business?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already read out the definition of an institution and indicated the sorts of organisations that would be regarded as a business or an institution. There is a commonly accepted meaning of `institution'. One needs to look at the particular circumstances. I do not know the particular circumstances of the institutions that honourable senators opposite have questioned me about. I think it is unlikely that they are covered by this provision. But, at the end of the day, if a particular institution wants to argue that it is covered by the provisions of this new amendment and that it is not a business, as such, then it will have to convince a court of that.

—I think we need a much more explicit explanation of exactly what is covered under this amendment. The parliamentary secretary has just indicated that a preschool, a kindergarten or a child-care centre run by a church is, in his view, probably not covered. Where is the line drawn? Is a primary school or a secondary school run by a church covered by this amendment? If it is, why is not the preschool or the child-care centre? Are educational institutions regarded as institutions under the terms of this amendment or are they not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Education institutions are not regarded—
—This amendment is worthless! You have tried to con us.

—Senator Chapman can come to his own conclusions. But those sorts of institutions that those opposite have named are generally covered by awards in either the state or the federal jurisdiction at the present time. The critical definitions are `religious grounds' and `for a public purpose'. If the organisations are run on either of those bases, then they would be exempt. But, at the end of the day, the courts will have to decide whether those particular organisations are covered by an industrial award or agreement.
—Surely education is a public purpose.

—The critical two aspects of determining this is not just public purpose, but also whether the institution is run on religious grounds, according to a religious tenet or creed. If it meets those two criteria, it is highly likely that it is exempt under this particular amendment.

—From my knowledge of Christian schools, I believe they are run in accordance with doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of particular religion or creed and they are run for a public purpose. May I have the parliamentary secretary's assurance that educational institutions run on that basis would meet the requirements of this amendment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already said, an institution that is run on religious grounds for a public purpose will be exempt.
—So you have changed your position from a few moments ago?
—No, you just did not understand it.

—I think Senator Sherry perhaps did not understand his position. Given that he has made his comments in relation to a school, I repeat my question: what is the situation in relation to a kindergarten or a preschool—for example, at the Southport School? Are we going to end up in a situation where these rules apply to the high school and the junior part of the school but will not apply to the kindergarten or preschool part of the school as well?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —My previous response applies. If it is religious grounds for a public purpose, there are some tests that would need to be looked at in terms of the way the business is conducted. We would need to examine the facts about how the particular institution is run.
—I note Senator Sherry's statement that there are some tests that would be applied. Perhaps he would be kind enough to advise the Senate what those tests are.
—You would match the two particular criteria that I have outlined against the facts.

—I do not really think that explains what Senator Sherry said about the tests. Senator Sherry seemed to indicate that there were a couple of objective criteria. He is outlining some fairly subjective things. He said that to particularise his earlier generalisation. I am hoping that Senator Sherry might be able to tell us what the particular tests are, or are we in the same uncertain situation that we were before? Whilst Senator Sherry is giving that some consideration, can he advise whether there will be a different criteria applied to a kindergarten or preschool run by the same establishment as is applied to the junior or senior school?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, there is no difference. As I indicated earlier, we look at the facts of the situation and apply the definition in the act and the two particular provisions that I have already mentioned a number of times to ascertain whether they are exempt or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the parliamentary secretary's attention to the case of the Pamas Foundation Incorporated v. the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, which is referred to on page 232 of Australian Law Report No. 106. This is the judgment by Justice Davies. The argument put by the appellant was that:

SPEECH.PARA: ". . . the tribunal erred in law in not finding that a body established for religious purposes was a religious institution".
Justice Davies then says:
However, there is no principle of law that every body established for religious purposes is a religious institution.

PARA.TAB: I need not deal with each of the errors of law alleged. Counsel for the appellant appears to have started from the assumption that the appellant was a "religious institution" and to have proceeded therefrom to the conclusion that French J must have found to the contrary because of some consideration which was wrong in law. In my opinion, no error has been shown.

SPEECH.PARA: That judgment indicates that there is not necessarily a clear definition of what an institution is. Therefore, despite what the parliamentary secretary said in response to my most recent question on the basis of the position I put to him that those sorts of schools would probably qualify, we really have no guarantee at all that they will qualify.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already responded to Senator Chapman. I am not aware of the particulars of the case that he read out. It is not easy to respond to a case that is read out in that fashion because we certainly did not have any advance notice of it. These definitions that are being inserted into the act are already in use in the human rights and equal opportunity legislation, so that the definitions are not new. I am not aware whether they have been tested under the provisions of that legislation.

PARA.TAB: The definitions are reasonably worded in the context of what we are seeking to achieve here—to give a reasonable exemption. I have already responded a number of times to the effect that if there is argument, the place for that to be ultimately decided, if that occurs, will be in a court. Senator Chapman has indicated one particular case where that appears to have happened. That is not unusual. However, we believe the definitions are appropriate in the circumstances, particularly given their application in other legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may well be that the place to test this is in the court, but one often finds that courts make a particular judgment according to very strict legal interpretation. They then say that if people believe that this is unfair or unreasonable, the remedy is in the hands of the legislature. We want to try to avoid that situation by having the legislation written properly in the first place so that institutions in the broad, not just in the narrow, such as schools based on a particular teaching by way of religion or creed, ought to be included. We ought to fix that up now rather than leaving it to a court to perhaps determine that the definition is much narrower than that and suggesting that, if one does not like that, one should go back and get the legislature to change it.

—While we have said that we will support this amendment because it will marginally improve the situation and address some of the concerns, I wish to put on the record on behalf of the opposition that this amendment is not satisfactory. It does not deal with all the issues that have been addressed in this place here tonight and last week. It is tragic that, once again, we have a clause in the bill which we know before we even walk out of this place will be in the courts. That could have been avoided had it been handled in the proper manner and in the proper place, and this has not been so handled.

PARA.TAB: It creates a situation that will mean that the whole of this bill is once again blurred because the Democrats and the government have not thought through the particular aspects of what they are introducing into the industrial relations bill. We on this side of the chamber condemn them for that. Nonetheless, as I have said, it is better than nothing and on that basis we will not be voting against it.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 31, page 45, after proposed section 170NF, insert the following section:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Commission to protect interests of certain employees

SPEECH.PARA: "`170NFA.(1) The Commission must comply with this section in performing its functions and exercising its powers in relation to an application to approve implementation of an agreement.

"`(2) The Commission must identify the employees ("relevant employees"), if any, who are covered by the agreement but whose interests may not have been sufficiently taken into account in the negotiations for, or the terms of, the agreement. Examples of employees whose interests may not have been so taken into account are:

TAB.TAB: (a)women;
(b)persons whose first language is not English;
(c)young persons.

SPEECH.PARA: "`(3) For the purposes of deciding whether it is satisfied as mentioned in paragraphs 170NC(1)(g) and (h), the Commission must do whatever is necessary to find out:

TAB.TAB: (a)whether:
(i)the relevant employees were consulted about the agreement, and informed about the matters referred to in subparagraphs 170NC(1)(h)(i) and (iv); and
(ii)the matters referred to in subparagraphs 170NC(1)(h)(ii) and (iii) were explained to the relevant employees;
in ways that were appropriate having regard to their particular circumstances and needs; and
(b)whether the effects on the relevant employees of the terms of the agreement were properly explained to those employees.

SPEECH.PARA: "`(4) If it considers that there has been a failure to consult or explain as mentioned in subsection (3), the Commission must make whatever orders it thinks necessary to remedy the failure and its effects.'.".

This amendment is similar in intent to amendment No. 1. As I mentioned earlier, I have made my statement in relation to that. It enables the commission to canvass under-represented groups when certifying enterprise bargains.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter concerned with this amendment, in the context of this legislation, is already covered. Once again we are going through the exercise of cluttering up a bill with amendment after amendment which do not add anything to what already exists in the legislation. When we deal with amendments such as this, right down the track the opposition will oppose them on the grounds that it is duplication after duplication. It confuses the whole issue and it is not necessary.
—The Democrats support the amendment for the reasons as proposed in the earlier debate on the amendment with a similar effect. I see no reason to prolong the discussion.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10.Clause 31, page 48, after proposed subsection 170NM(2), insert the following subsection:

"(2A) A Full Bench must, within 3 years of the date on which an enterprise flexibility agreement continues in force because of subsection 170NI(3), and within each subsequent period of 3 years, review the operation of the agreement after giving the parties to the agreement an opportunity to be heard.".

At the time of moving amendment No. 9, I indicated that this would be consequential and complementary. I made the statements which were necessary to facilitate that amendment at the time. I will not prolong the argument by repeating them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY

SPEECH.PARA: (8)Clause 31, pages 49 and 50, proposed section 170NO, line 21 (page 49) to line 3 (page 50), omit the section, substitute the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Eligible union may agree to be bound by enterprise flexibility agreement

PARA.TAB: (a)an employer has made an agreement under this Division; and
(b)the Commission has not yet approved implementation of the agreement (whether or not an application for approval has been made);

SPEECH.PARA: an eligible union may, by written notice given to the employer, agree to be bound by the agreement if and when the Commission approves its implementation.

PARA.TAB: (a)a variation of an agreement made under this Division is proposed; or
(b)an agreement made under this Division has been varied but the variation has not yet taken effect;

PARA.TAB: (c)if the union is already bound by the agreement—agree to be bound by the variation if and when it takes effect; or
(d)otherwise—agree to be bound by the agreement as varied if and when the variation takes effect.

PARA.TAB: "`(3) While an enterprise flexibility agreement is in force because of subsection 170NI(3), an eligible union may, by written notice given to the employer, agree to be bound by the agreement on and after a day specified in the notice. This subsection applies whether or not a variation of the agreement has taken effect.
"`(4) A notice under subsection (1), (2) or (3) cannot be revoked.
"`(5) An eligible union that has agreed as mentioned in subsection (1), paragraph (2)(d) or subsection (3) is bound accordingly.
"`(6) However, after a variation (however made) of the agreement takes effect, or a further such variation takes effect, as the case requires, the union:
(a)is no longer bound by the agreement as in force before the variation or further variation took effect; and
(b)is not bound by the agreement as varied unless, before the variation or further variation took effect, the union agreed under subsection (2) to be bound by the variation or further variation.

"`(7) Subsection (6) does not apply to a variation made under subsection 113(2) or (2A). If, immediately before such a variation of the agreement takes effect, the union is still bound by the agreement, the union is bound by the agreement as varied.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is intended to modify the circumstances in which an eligible union can become bound by an enterprise flexibility agreement. An eligible union is defined as a union that has members employed in the enterprise concerned and is a party to an award that binds the employer in respect of work performed in that enterprise. As drafted, an eligible union could become bound by an enterprise flexibility agreement at any time by providing written notice to the employer.

PARA.TAB: The amendment will limit the occasions on which an eligible union can become bound by an enterprise flexibility agreement to the following: the period prior to the commission's approval of the agreement; secondly, when the agreement is to be varied, the period after a proposed variation has been notified but before the variation takes effect; and, thirdly, the period when the agreement continues in force by operation of the act, that is, after a specified period of operation plus a three-month negotiation period, has expired.

The proposed section 170NO recognises the rights of unions to collectively represent their members. It is only fair that a union with award coverage and members employed in an enterprise should have the opportunity to be bound by an enterprise flexibility agreement covering that enterprise. Employees should be permitted to have their union involved in an agreement which will govern their terms and conditions of employment.

The government does not accept that employees should be denied the right to have their union involved. It should be remembered that these unions have no power of veto over the agreement. If the majority of the employees agree and the agreement meets the legislation criteria, it will be approved by the commission. Many enterprises will have a mix of union and non-union areas in their work force, although eligible unions to become bound by agreements will encourage comprehensive enterprise-wide agreements and provide for greater certainty and commitment to the agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose this amendment and we will seek to delete it in our next amendment if it is carried, or delete what is already in the bill. So we have a double whammy. Honourable senators can solve the problem, save a lot of time and please Senator Faulkner immensely by voting against this amendment at this time and this clause. I make that suggestion to Senator Bell as a person who likes to facilitate the processes in this place and save a lot of argument. Having said that, I will make any further comments I wish to when we get to our amendment if, of course, that is necessary.

—A tempting thought, but I am not quite tired enough to be tempted to do anything to resolve the timetable. This section attempts to achieve the same result as the section it replaces, but does it in a more efficient and comprehensive manner. It provides more certainty, and even more flexibility. Once a union has agreed to be bound by an enterprise flexibility agreement, this section will ensure that the union remains bound, but there is the possibility that the commission may vary the agreement to remove an ambiguity, an uncertainty or a discriminatory provision. In that case, the variation is not considered a variation in the sense of an agreed variation by the parties, but rather a variation which is required. Therefore, the union would remain bound by the agreement itself. So this is a necessary, almost technical, but desirable amendment which we support.

—Having listened to that, and while I said we would deal with it at the next stage, maybe with a little luck I can convince the Democrats to relook at this matter. Not so long ago we were debating whether or not employees should have the right to have registered an enterprise flexibility agreement by secret ballot. Yet this amendment says that if a majority of employees have agreed to be bound by the agreement then it can be proceeded with.

PARA.TAB: I pose the question as to how one determines how the majority of employees have agreed to be bound by it other than by running a ballot of those employees. We are seeing the greatest demonstration of inconsistency one can possibly think of—one rule in one situation, another rule when you hop over the other side and then, when you hop back here, another rule. It is plainly hypocritical to adopt this position on this amendment and to have adopted a different position on the previous amendment.

If this situation facilitates putting in place an agreement, why did not the previous amendment—which in essence sought to do a similar thing—facilitate the putting in of an agreement? I would like to hear from Senator Sherry and Senator Bell how they are going to decide how to determine a majority of employees if there is not a ballot, and if there is not a ballot in such a way that one can remove coercion and intimidation from the process.

We are seeing the most inconsistent application of similar clauses in the bill. I just pose that particular question. Having voted against the previous amendment, I cannot fathom how the Democrats can support either the amendment that is before us or the clause in the bill. Senator Bell has said that, in essence, what the amendment says—I hope that I am not misquoting Senator Bell because that is not my intention—is the same as the clause in the bill.

That begs another question: why do we have an amendment which says exactly the same as what is already in the bill? The more we look at this amendment, the more illogical it becomes. The simplest and quickest way to deal with this matter, and for the sake of consistency in the legislation, would be to defeat not only the amendment but also the clause in the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer one specific question that Senator Crane rightly asks, and that is how on earth one determines the opinion of the majority of the people involved. As I indicated in the debate over the secret ballot question earlier this evening, the answer lies on page 31,402 in division 4, section 135 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. If Senator Crane wishes me to, I could read the following sections all the way up to 31,503—
—Is that the whole of page 31,503?

—I would have thought that with Senator Crane's experience in this area, he would have been familiar with the fact that division 4 of the act is headed `Ballots ordered by Commission' and section 135 is headed `Commission may order secret ballot'. That is one of the many techniques that the commission has at its disposal to determine the findings of the majority of employees in question.

PARA.TAB: That is precisely why it is entirely consistent to support an amendment which, for its implementation, relies upon the commission having the capacity to determine the opinions of the majority. The commission does not have to restrain itself either to conducting a secret ballot or ordering one to be conducted. The commission may use any one or several methods to determine it. It can ask whether certain techniques have been conducted by those who purport to represent the workers involved. In fact, it is required to do that to determine that there has been a process of proper consultation, that there has been a process of proper information sharing and that there has been a process which allows for the proper expressions of opinion by those affected.

Because the commission is required to do that and because it also has the capacity to adopt whatever methods it finds necessary to determine what the opinion is, I would have thought that the answer to Senator Crane's question—which was how on earth do we determine the opinion of the majority—was obvious. As I stated previously, section 135, with its extensive description of how, when, where and why secret ballots should be conducted, is the very safeguard to prevent the commission from being flippant in its consideration of what is being put before it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on what Senator Bell has just said to the committee. He referred to section 135 of the Industrial Relations Act, which is headed `Commission may order secret ballot' which states:

TALK.START.PARA: —The real issue here is why should a union have the right or the opportunity to be bound by an enterprise flexibility agreement, when that agreement relates to an individual workplace in which no members of that union are present and where none of those employees have asked the union to become bound by the enterprise agreement? PARA.TAB: As we are very much aware, with 70 per cent of the work force in the private sector not being members of unions, and with the overwhelming number of those non-unionised employees being in the small business sector—where we would hope there would be some enterprise agreements reached—there is simply no desire on the part of those employees to have the union bound by the agreement, and there is simply no need for the union to be bound by that agreement. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to direct a number of questions to the parliamentary secretary. This whole division is based on a number of international conventions. I draw the parliamentary secretary's attention to those listed on page 50. There are some five heads of power, I suppose one could call them, on which this whole section operates. I am opposed to using these conventions and international law as the basis for a constitutional power for the government to legislate and intrude into what has previously been the domain of states and private arrangements between individuals.

PARA.TAB: This amendment moved on behalf of the government and, indeed, this whole division, go to the whole area of the right to strike. I think the fact that the government has had to rely on so many heads of power shows the weakness of its position. If the government, in its trawling through international conventions and international customary law, could have come up with one clear clause which gave a right to strike, I have no doubt that it would have junked all five conventions and put in that clause. I put it to the parliamentary secretary that that was not possible.

I would like the parliamentary secretary to provide some answers—I do not need to have them at the moment. This whole section will be tested in the courts and will ultimately go to the High Court. Therefore, it is of considerable interest, I believe, to find out the precise words the government is relying on under each of these five headings. For example, (e) refers to customary international law relating to freedom of association and the right to strike. I would like the parliamentary secretary to tell me—hopefully within the next 24 hours—what precisely the government is relying on in order to obtain, as one might say, the head of power.

I understand that under the ILO there is no unqualified right to strike. I believe that the government recognises this. This is why we have so many legs of international covenants and international law. I believe that the fact that we can attempt blatantly to alter and modify our constitution by relying on these heads of power is an absolutely appalling practice that will come back to haunt this country.

It is quite misleading. As Minister McMullan said in this chamber last Thursday, it does not really matter all that much because in order to put these covenants into effect we have to pass laws in the parliament. That is correct. But he misses the point that these ILO conventions, and apparently international customary law, provide a constitutional head of power. They are enormously significant and important in the way this country develops, and the government should not downplay that. Without those heads of power, this whole bill would fall down.

The government has not relied on heads of power within the constitution, as agreed to by our people; nor has it gone out and put to the people of this country by way of the normal process of referendum that it wants those heads of power. The government has gone off and signed various conventions, without any approval by or reference to this parliament. The government then argues that it has a constitutional head of power on which to enact wide ranging industrial relations legislation.

I would like an assurance from the parliamentary secretary that he will provide me in writing, or preferably incorporate the information in Hansard, just what particular conventions and customary law the government believes arise under each of those five obligations. I believe this will be of great interest to the High Court in years to come.

I also want to say how utterly foolish this whole exercise is. I put it to the parliamentary secretary that I belong to a party which at this stage is opposed to using ILO conventions in order to provide a head of power for legislation. I think that is a perfectly proper stance for our party to take. But it is more than likely that if the Labor Party continues to act in this manner, Liberal Party members in the future may say, `What is good for the goose is good for the gander'.
Let us look at this convention that the government has put in the schedule of this act. Article 2 of schedule 15 states:

Workers and employees, without distinction whatsoever, shall have the right to establish and subject only to the rules of the organisation concerned, to join organisations of their own choosing without previous authorisation.

SPEECH.PARA: What would that give as a head of power to any conservative government in this country? I will tell the parliamentary secretary what it would give. It would give the opportunity to legislate voluntary unionism in as many unions as people wish to join. That could override all the other laws which have been built up since Federation, since 1901. The government, in its naked pursuit for a head of power in order to entrench trade union power and privilege in this country, is setting up precedents which I believe will come back to haunt the Labor Party and the ambitious union leaders who have insisted on this bill being passed.

PARA.TAB: Let me come back to my original point. Can the parliamentary secretary or his advisers tell me precisely which are the clauses which give an obligation to provide the right to strike?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is well known that the opposition will be opposing this amendment. I have to say that we are now getting to the crazy part of this bill. I never thought I would be standing in this parliament putting in place a situation whereby people have 72 hours to do something and can then go on strike, or a situation where employers can give 72 hours notice to employees that they will be locked out. What are we here for? Are we not here to progress this nation?

PARA.TAB: It really comes back to the issues I raised at the beginning of the debate. I then talked about the objectives of the act. This is where the changes come into play. The 1993 bill states that its objective is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to provide a framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes . . .
The 1988 act states that its objective is:
. . . to promote industrial harmony and co-operation among the parties . . .

There is no doubt that the amendment now before us has created the necessity for the changes to the objectives. I just have to say, on behalf of the opposition, that that is totally the wrong way to go in terms of dealing with things. In fact, it is encouraging and legitimising disputation. It is creating a situation in which you actually write a letter to tell the other party that you are going to get stuck into them. Just how crazy can this become?

PARA.TAB: Do we want to address the situation faced by the one million people who are unemployed in this country? Do we want to get ourselves back to the living standards that we used to enjoy? This bill will do nothing on those lines. Indeed, it will send us in the opposite direction. The government has to ask itself a few questions about whether it is serving the interests of this nation or whether it is going to continue to placate the ACTU and bow to its demands. This is what this is all about.

The government said, `Employers objected to this so we put in a 72-hour clause to enable them to lock people out'. Who will they hurt if they lock people out? Who will get upset with them if they lock people out? They will upset the very people with whom they have to operate in the workplace. Who will they damage economically? They will damage themselves. It is stupidity, silliness and craziness at their absolute worst. For a government to bring into this and the other place legislation which in fact will cause and create disharmony amongst people in the workplace is totally beyond me.

The Industrial Relations Commission is still in place and it has some tasks. We have an arbitration and conciliation process. Is that not the sane, sensible way, if the government is going to continue down that line, to deal with these matters? It is the government's decision to continue down that line, but it is also its decision to put in place provisions in this legislation which will exacerbate and increase industrial disruption. Those provisions will damage business, they will damage our economy and we will fall even further behind the rest of the world in terms of international competitiveness.

We have heard a lot in recent times about GATT and the GATT agreement, and hopefully we will get a good result out of that. But why not put in place an industrial system that will allow us to maximise the benefit of that? Let us not have a repeat of what occurred when our financial system was devalued. That occurred because we did not grasp the other components of an economic situation and amend, change or deregulate them. We did not do that. Instead, we blew the benefits we could have gained from financial deregulation. Most of them went up in smoke and they are gone. It is no good saying now that our inflation today is two per cent or three per cent. The fact is that we blew that a long time ago and we cannot get the opportunity back.

The government is giving away the opportunity it has to bring about real industrial reform. It is creating a situation in which the old `us and them' situation will be built up. That is what the government is doing and that will be the result of this legislation. It almost leaves me speechless when I think of how one should try to deal with such a situation.

Industrial relations has been an interest of mine. I think back to the days when we had to load live sheep, something that I had hoped I would never have to do again. But I make the prediction that I will be back there helping to load the live sheep within three, four or five years. I have no doubt that will be the result of this legislation. This government is facilitating a situation that I did not want to see again in my lifetime.

I thought when I came into this place three-and-a-half years ago that one might have been able to make a constructive contribution to prevent that situation arising again. When we get legislation like this, we can get up and say everything we like. We can have inquiries and do all of those things, but at the end of the day if reason does not prevail, if people do not adopt a sensible attitude to these things and look at all sides of the equation, we will end up with very bad legislation.

I find it incomprehensible that we are now debating mechanisms that will encourage industrial disputation—on the one hand, encouraging employees to go on strike and on the other hand urging employers to lock their employees out of the workplace. I say to the government, to the Democrats, to the Greens and to Senator Harradine that that may be the model they want in Australia, but we on this side of the chamber do not want a bar of it. We reject it in its totality, and when we get into government at the next election we will do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment serves only to highlight the dangerously one-sided nature of this legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before that interruption, because of the blatantly obvious one-sided nature of this legislation and the protests that have been raised by the opposition and various business organisations about it, to create the facade of some measure of equality in the legislation, the government is now introducing an amendment to provide a right for employers to lock out employees. That is a mere facade—and, indeed, a charade. If I look back over the history of industrial relations in this country—even the last five years—I certainly cannot recall immediately any lockouts that have occurred. I do not know whether Senator Parer knows of any. There may have been one or two, but they would certainly be as scarce as hens' teeth.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —On the other hand, as I am about to say—and as Senator Parer interjects—the number of strikes over that period would be reasonably substantial.
—They have dropped substantially, though.

—The parliamentary secretary interjects that they have dropped substantially. One of the reasons they have dropped substantially, of course, is that this government has driven the country into recession. Employees, therefore, cannot afford to take the risks that industrial action involves. The other thing that he ignores is that other forms of industrial action have been substituted for strikes, such as work to rule and those sorts of quasi-strikes. If we go over the whole history in this century of Australia's industrial relations, we again find that the number of strikes that have occurred is many multiples of the number of lockouts that have occurred in our industrial history.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that this legislation writes into law a right to strike. Therefore, to give the appearance of equality, it writes into law the right to a lockout. But, in the practical application of this law, it will be the right to strike that is exercised and not the right to a lockout. As Senator Crane said a few moments ago, that is giving all of the wrong signals to the practitioners of industrial relations in this country.

At a time when we ought to be getting away from that sort of direct confrontation in the field of employee-employer industrial relations and getting employers and employees together to work out their differences in a rational way—that, of course, would be the approach that a coalition government would adopt, with its much more open approach to enterprise negotiations than that of this government—and heading away from giving any sort of support or encouragement to industrial action, this government writes into law a right to strike. By its very nature, once something is written into law, it gives encouragement to its practice—it gives it succour; it gives it approval. It is respected once it is written into law. Instead of heading away from industrial action and strike activity, which are detrimental to employers, to employees and to this country's economy, in this legislation this government is giving encouragement to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on this amendment from the government and reinforce the remarks made by Senator Crane and Senator Chapman. It seems to me to be introducing legislation which is a throwaway, like Marie Antoinette's `They haven't got bread. Let them eat cake'. The government has introduced the right to strike and someone has said, `Well, there's another side to that coin. Why don't we throw the employers the right to lockout?'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chapman raised the question of lockouts. Lockouts have not been a feature of industrial relations in this country. I can recall reading left-wing trade union papers some years ago that said that one of the worst things that an employer could do was lock out. We can hark back to examples in history. I might be wrong, but I have an idea that the miners reckon the 1949 coal strike, where Chifley put the troops in, was a lockout. To the union movement, this was the equivalent of scab labour. That was the sort of ferocity with which they looked at lockouts.

I ask the parliamentary secretary—because it was raised by Senator Chapman—just how many lockouts have been recorded by the Department of Industrial Relations over the past 10 years. Senator Sherry said that strikes have diminished. I might be wrong, but it is my understanding that there are still something like one million man days lost in strikes in this country.

The purpose of this bill, supposedly, is to encourage enterprise agreements. That means agreements at the enterprise level, whether they be with people who are members of recognised unions or people who are not members of recognised unions. There is no doubt that, once we start to introduce a bill or an amendment like this which gives various rules and regulations regarding lockouts, we will have lockouts where we have never had them before because they will be legal. On 72 hours notice it is possible to have a lockout. What that will do for employer-employee relationships boggles the mind.

I think everyone would agree—I have even heard people on the other side say it—that we need a more cooperative framework for industrial relations in this country. We need an attitude similar to the attitude of the successful countries in South-East Asia: for example, the very well-known attitude in Japan where there is a recognition between employees and employers that if the company is successful so too will be the employees and that if the company is not successful people's jobs are at risk.

As Senator Crane said, it entrenches the them and us position—`East is East, and West is West, and never the twain shall meet'. We do not want that. No-one wants that. Yet it goes down the line of the ACTU because the ACTU and the trade union movement have a vested interest in maintaining that split between the two. They would like the people who work for companies to believe that they are employed simply because of their union membership, not because of the fact that they work for someone who has made an investment and who wants to have a cooperative work force which is to the benefit of all concerned. I would be interested in the figure, if the parliamentary secretary could get it for me from the department, of just how many lockouts there have been over the last 10 years.

The other thing that concerns me about this amendment—there is a complete section on it—is in regard to immunity from civil liberty, which means that we entrench the right to strike and the right to lockout under certain conditions. There is talk about a bargaining period. When written notice may be given before the start of the bargaining period of either a lockout or a strike, whatever it might be, it seems to be open ended.

I would have thought that when framing industrial relations policy for any country, we would look at those countries whose policy has been successful as compared with those where it has not been successful. A classic example is the United States system at the time of the end of three-year agreements. It is not unusual to find that there is either a six-month strike or a six-month lockout or a combination of both, which is not to the advantage of the business, or to the employees, or to the country as a whole. It would be particularly disadvantageous for a country such as Australia with our high unemployment and our current account deficit continuing to run at an enormous deficit to go down that track. I fear that we will follow the United States line, which is not the one to follow in this particular instance.

It would surely be more productive if we were to follow the Japanese line. It is not that we should copy anyone in particular, but when we look at other countries and see what they have done we look to see why they are successful. It is not a matter of union bashing because those countries which are successful have company based unions. They are all working towards a common cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those companies often give jobs for life. That is not what you are advocating.

—I am pleased to have that interjection from Senator Margetts who said that those companies would often give jobs for life. Nothing would give employers in this country more pleasure than to be able to offer people jobs for life. If we have a successful and productive work force, people will have jobs for life. I do not know any company that does not have the ambition to grow, to become more successful, to become more productive and to employ more people. It is the natural nature of man and woman; satisfaction comes from growing and becoming successful. It used not to be the case in this country. I can recall complaints being made in the 1960s that people often stayed with one organisation too long and that they became entrenched and narrow and that it would have been better if they had done a little swapping and switching. That just shows us how things change.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister how many lockouts there have been. I think it is important that we know. It is a throwaway bit to say, `Let's appear to be even-handed'. My concern is that we are going to introduce something into the industrial relations scene which has not been a feature of Australian industrial relations. Leaving aside all the other bad things that have happened with industrial relations in this country, one thing we have not had is a history of lockouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the contributions so far, it is not silly to ask the parliamentary secretary exactly what this amendment does. I was under the impression that this amendment was heading along the lines of reducing the burden which the bill now places on employers to give written notice 72 hours beforehand of any industrial action that employers and employees might consider. I was under the impression that this amendment actually reduced that burden by removing the possibility that an employer could contemplate industrial action by mistakenly not notifying just one employee that that employer would no longer have immunity under the negotiating period while negotiations were being conducted to arrive at a single business certified agreement. If I was mistaken, perhaps we ought to look carefully at what the amendment does. I would appreciate the parliamentary secretary's advice as to what this amendment does. If it seeks to go along the lines that the Democrats had the impression of it doing, we are eager to reduce that burden on employers.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell is right. This amendment is intended to address concerns of employer representatives. Secondly, he expressed concern about the lockout and strike situation in the United States upon the lapse of an agreement.

PARA.TAB: It is true that in the United States strikes tend to be long and that lockouts tend to be longer than in Australia. However, I do not think that is going to occur in Australia. We have a different approach to industrial relations. There has been a significant improvement in the industrial relations culture. Whilst I am sure that the recession has been a contributing factor in the rate of industrial disputes, a continuing improvement in that rate has occurred over the last 10 years—long before the recession commenced.

I am confident that the sorts of industrial development practices we have seen in the United States tend to be unique to the United States. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10)Clause 31, page 53, after proposed section 170PI, insert the following section:

"170PIA. Before members of an organisation can engage in industrial action of a type described in paragraph (d) of the definition of ``industrial action'' in section 4 of the Act, the Commission must order that a vote of members of the organisation be taken by secret ballot.".

In this place tonight we have already run the merit of secret ballots and having a bit of democracy in industrial relations in this country. This amendment has become even more crucial in view of the amendment that was just carried in this place. People in the workplace who go on strike—in many cases, at a significant cost to themselves—should make the decision to do so and should not have it made for them by the hierarchy within the union organisations. In practice, in most instances—not all—the latter is what happens.

PARA.TAB: This amendment has reached a new dimension since we had our last debate, not in terms of democracy but in terms of its importance to this legislation and this clause. Once again, it will be a test of whether the government, the Greens or Senator Bell, on behalf of the Democrats, believe in industrial democracy.

It is not sufficient to hark back to the previous section in the 1988 act where the commission may order a ballot, because the situations in which that would occur would be very minimal. One might well pose this question to Senator Sherry: how many times has the commission ordered a secret ballot before people operating under an award—which can be much greater in number than the coverage of one award—have determined whether they will go out on strike?

I well remember about five or six years ago meeting some people who happened to live in the unit next-door to me in Como in Perth. It turned out that they happened to be a couple of union organisers who were working with one of the mining companies in the Pilbara. They were absolutely irate because their workplace was out because of a dispute which was related to their union in Wollongong. They said, `What the hell is going on here? Our people are up there in the dust, the heat and the flies with an opportunity to earn good money, which is why they go there. It is an opportunity which they take, and they work long, hard hours in difficult conditions'. I have no problem in acknowledging that. But when they should have been up there doing their job, they were out on a prolonged strike over something that had occurred in New South Wales.

If there had been a secret ballot of the membership of that organisation, I have no doubt that that strike would never have occurred. The individuals who work in the mining industry in Western Australia far outnumber—probably 10 to one; I do not know and I am not going to even try to predict it—the number of people in a similar situation in New South Wales. That emphasises very clearly the importance of the fact that, if there is to be a strike, there be an opportunity for all who will be involved and economically hurt—including the families, who have to meet their hire purchase commitments, housing payments and all the things that everyday Australians have to meet—to vote in a secret ballot to determine whether they want to hurt themselves, because that is what they are basically doing from an economic or financial point of view.
This amendment takes a different dimension from the previous one. In my view, it is equal in terms of industrial democracy. In terms of industrial harmony, it is significantly more important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that we failed to preclude the right to strike in the writing in of this legislation, it is absolutely essential that this opposition amendment, which provides for a secret ballot to be implemented before strike action is undertaken, be included in the legislation. Senator Crane has laid out fairly clearly the need for that. It is essential to ensure that industrial action is taken on a democratic basis and that it is genuinely the will of the employees who are required to embark upon that action, and not simply an action taken at the behest of union leaders or an active minority of employees.

PARA.TAB: In the past we have all seen the situation where public meetings of employees are called to discuss an industrial dispute, and a decision to strike is taken there and then at that meeting as a result of a vote taken on the basis of a show of hands. We all know what happens then: intimidation, thuggery and pressure is brought to bear to ensure that a majority vote in favour of that industrial action is obtained with that public show of hands. That in no way represents a genuine expression of opinion by employees. The only way that there can be a genuine expression of opinion by employees is by having a secret ballot conducted in accordance with the rules laid down by the commission. That will avoid having the vote taken on a public basis at the meeting, and it will avoid the opportunity for intimidation to be applied to the people attending the meeting.

That must be an absolute requirement. If this right to strike is to be retained in this legislation there must also be an absolute requirement written into the legislation to ensure that before any such industrial action can be taken a secret ballot is taken of the employees who are potentially embarking upon that industrial action to ensure that it is the genuine will and wish of a majority of those employees that such action be taken. They must be cognisant of the costs that will be borne by them and their families as well as the costs they will cause their employer and ultimately the capacity of that employer and business to provide them with better standards and remuneration and enable them to retain their jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Crane. I make it clear from the outset that employers do not want to lock people out and they do not want strikes. In the main, employees and their families do not want strikes and they do not want to be locked out. I think that should be the basis of industrial relations legislation.

PARA.TAB: It has been argued that if employees have a secret ballot on a strike it does not necessarily mean that they will vote against the strike. I agree with that. Senator Burns gave an interesting example with the Gladstone power station. In that case a secret ballot resulted in the employees deciding to continue to strike. My answer to that is, so be it. If that is the case, so be it. At least it gives them the opportunity to express their views without concern. It may not be heavy handed stuff from union delegates that makes employees strike but it certainly can be peer group pressure particularly in isolated areas. I am sure Senator Sherry would know about that given the experience he has had in Tasmania. People would prefer not to attend a meeting rather than put their hands up in support of a certain type of industrial action that they did not want.

We were talking before about Japan and industrial relations. I was in Japan when there was a strike. It involved one of the major shipbuilders. When I asked why the strike was on I was told that the company had cut back the working week from six days to 5 1/2 days. The employees were on strike because they felt it would diminish their productivity and thus reduce their competitiveness on world markets. That is a very different attitude and is interesting because it relates to the interjection that Senator Margetts made about the attitudes of people when there is a close relationship between a company and its employees.

A classic example of the right to a secret ballot occurred recently in my old industry. It decided to take five days off because the miners union decided that it did not like the price at which BHP sold coal to Turkey. So our biggest export industry went on strike for what ended up being three days because of the existence of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. The threat came from those companies that were not selling coal to Turkey. They were asking, `How come we are not involved?'. They were then threatening action under sections 45D and 45E. They did not pursue it. As is the case with most of the 45D and 45E actions, they were never pursued to the damages stage.

Anyone involved in the union movement will know—I see Senator Burns is in the chamber and I welcome him back—that the stories are legion. I can remember one union leader telling me that he had a gathering of the men, as he called it, and said to them, `Comrades, the decision is whether we strike on Friday or Monday'. One of the workers got up and said, `Shouldn't the question be, do we have a strike?'. The union leader said, `You are out of order. The question is whether we strike on Friday or Monday?'. That is the sort of thing that went on.

There is no doubt that it will continue unless people are given the opportunity to express their views. Prior to Senator Burns coming into the chamber, I mentioned the example he gave of the Gladstone power station. The opposition has no concerns with the fact that if people decide by secret ballot to go on strike, so be it.

Repeating what Senator Chapman said, having lost the right to strike clause, we would prefer to have a bill that is a deterrent to strikes and lockouts rather than one that encourages those. Having failed that, we believe the most democratic way to approach it and to improve legislation—which, I suppose one would argue, cannot be improved too much—would be to give people, before they pull a strike, the chance to vote on whether they want to go on strike or not.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Exercise of Bargaining Division's functions and powers by other Commission members

SPEECH.PARA: "`170QD. (1) The President may make available a member of the Commission to perform or exercise all or any of the Bargaining Division's functions and powers, as the President thinks fit.

This amendment applies to pages 58 and 59 of the bill. It aims to ensure that the creation of the new bargaining division will not create debilitating divisions between the award and the bargaining streams of the Industrial Relations Commission. As the bill is presently drafted, the provisions give the vice-president of the bargaining division an effective veto over decisions by the president to make available commissioners to help the core members of the bargaining divisions cope with the high workload periods. Our amendment would remove that right of veto and leave the decision solely in the hands of the president.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats are concerned that the new division raises a real potential for conflict and friction within the commission. The interface between the award and the bargaining streams could easily become unwieldy and inefficient, giving employers and unions opportunities to play procedural games with this process, making a to-and-fro effect between the two streams. In our view, the amendment that we propose would give the president a more appropriate degree of authority to ensure that the commission operates in a cohesive and productive fashion under the new arrangements. If there was ever anything designed to stymie the progress of the new bargaining division, it would be this potential friction between the two streams.

We had initially proposed that the president assign the core members of the new division. However, we have been made fully aware of the administrative difficulties that such a proposition would throw up. As we know, the minister appoints members of the commission and he will clearly be appointing some members on the strength of their conciliation and bargaining skills. I am pleased Senator Kernot is in the chamber at the moment because it is an amendment with which she has particular identification. This amendment requires that the minister commission and table an annual survey on the impact of enterprise bargaining, particularly on women, part-time employees and immigrants. This particular provision, in our view, is an essential device for monitoring the impact of enterprise bargaining on workers who may have low bargaining power. How that is defined is perhaps a matter of some degree of difficulty.

PARA.TAB: But in the discussions leading up to the introduction of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill there was a contention that some people who did not have the skills, the opportunity to develop skills, or the efficient representation to bring those skills to the bargaining table could well miss out on wage rises that were promised by the enterprise bargaining process—wage rises, improvements in conditions or flexibility of employment. It is quite often the case that some of those people who are in such positions may need that extra flexibility to be more productive in the workplace.

These fears had been expressed not only to the Democrats—I would be the first to admit that—but also to the government, to employer groups and to the committees that conducted inquiries into sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and the Industrial Relations Reform Bill itself. Those opinions and concerns having been expressed, we believe that it is important to assess the actual impact of enterprise bargaining.

In some instances the fears could be shown by statistics to be unfounded. But we all know that statistics can be presented in a number of formats and in a variety of ways to suit the arguments of those who use them. So the Democrats are very careful not to assume that one particular point of view prevails in this area. We want this survey to be commissioned and presented to parliament so that it can be discussed and evaluated in full.

A recent survey by the Department of Industrial Relations found that only 15 per cent of women had won pay rises through enterprise bargaining compared with 24 per cent of men and that, while such women may have access to pay rises through other means, the growing emphasis on bargaining will increasingly restrict other options as time goes on. We believe that it is essential that any regressive impact on workers with low bargaining power is identified promptly. One way of doing that is through this device of the report.

It is for that reason that we are moving this amendment, which achieves the commissioning of that report. It also brings about some degree of ongoing monitoring of this process through the parliament.
