TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 38, line 31 (page 65) to line 25 (page 78), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
"38. Division 7 of Part VI of the Principal Act is repealed.".
3.Clause 43, line 16 (page 80) to line 2 (page 81), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
"43. Section 45D of the Principal Act is repealed."
4.Schedule 3, page 209, proposed amendment to paragraph 6(2)(b) of the Trade Practices Act 1974, omit the amendment, substitute the following amendments:
Omit `45D (other than subsection (1A)), 45E,'.
Omit the paragraph.".

The amendments to which I refer relate to clauses 38, 39 and 43 and schedule 3, standing in my name. The Greens are very pleased that the government has at last improved the operation of the boycott provisions of the 1974 Trade Practices Act so as to more readily exclude political and environmental boycotts. Such boycotts should never have been covered in the first place, but at least now the situation has been improved. Nevertheless, the Trades and Labor Council in Western Australia has unanimously expressed its disquiet about the impact of the remaining sections on boycotts. The use of the legal sanctions in these sections against workers who express dissatisfaction with their working conditions has the effect of allowing employers to avoid dealing with the subject matter in a proper way.

PARA.TAB: Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act turn worker dissatisfaction into a legalistic argument. It actually restricts and often removes entirely the capacity for workers to directly address the real problems. Robe River is a useful case study. Issues that affect the lives of workers on and off the job have been treated with contempt by the management of that company. The only way workers can get the managers of that company to the negotiating table is to take industrial action. As a result of sections 45D and 45E, as soon as workers take industrial action the matter is taken out of their hands and is handed over to lawyers. This is hardly efficient. It removes the capacity of the work force to deal directly with its employer by transferring a dispute from the workplace to a court of law.

It may be cruel but I would like to remind the government that before this particular secondary boycott provision was in place there was not anarchy within the workplace. It is perhaps even crueller to remind the government that, from the 1991 Australian Labor Party platform resolutions and rules as approved by the 39th National Conference in Hobart, the Labor Party said that trade unions—

SPEECH.PARA: provide for a legal framework to ensure that registered organisations and community organisations and their members are able to exercise their right to take industrial action and other legitimate forms of demonstration consistent with the principles of freedom of association, without legal penalties such as the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act and common law actions in tort.

In fact, the Labor Party has asked for secondary boycott legal provisions to be withdrawn. We all know, as has been argued again and again by the business interests who appeared before the sections 45D and 45E industrial relations committee, that it is always possible for boycott provisions which specifically cause damage to one industry by another to be prosecuted under common law. So it does not allow one industry to damage another just for the sake of being nasty.

PARA.TAB: In order to express our deep concern for the situation as it exists, and as it is likely to continue with the secondary boycott provisions, the Greens WA are requesting that secondary boycott provisions be removed from both the Industrial Relations Act and the Trade Practices Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clarify something with Senator Margetts. What clauses are we dealing with?
—Perhaps I might be able to help to the extent that I have some interest in this debate. It is amendments 1, 3 and 4, covering clauses 38, 43 and schedule 3.
—Therefore, as is fairly predictable, I rise to speak against the proposition which has been put with these amendments.
—But very sensible.

—Yes, it is very sensible but also predictable. Of course, one cannot deal with these amendments which are before us now without looking at the whole concept of what the Greens, through Senator Margetts, are trying to do. With them having been described as—and I do not say this disrespectfully—`the gumnut twins', I think one can say that they are well and truly out amongst the gumnuts now in dealing with this. In short, what they are saying is that employers should have no protection or effective reform against any type of boycott action.

PARA.TAB: We can go into a whole range of matters on the effective mechanisms for protection against boycott actions, including restrictions on tort actions and others. But, of course, two features of sections 45D and 45E which came out in the inquiry into those sections of the Trade Practices Act were, firstly, their speed and effectiveness when employers were forced into a position of having to use those provisions; and, secondly—and this came out very clearly and is something which I am sure Senator Bell will remember—that the process was quick compared with a common law action, which is argued as the alternative to a tort action, through the supreme courts. The costs were only 60 per cent of those for a court action, providing that one only had to take out an action in one supreme court. There is much opinion and evidence to suggest that if we were caught in a situation without the protection of sections 45D and 45E, we would find ourselves in a position where we would have to take it out in a number of the supreme courts around the country.

The purpose of sections 45D and 45E is to allow business to go about its legal everyday process of doing business without being boycotted out of existence. I believe that that is a legitimate position for businesses to find themselves in. The sections have also been used on at least one occasion by one union against another because it was aggrieved—and that evidence was also presented to the committee.

But at the end of the day, when we are dealing with industrial relations, we have to ask ourselves whether or not we want an industrial relations system or the freedom and the right to go about our business; whether we want that to be handled through the law of the land or through one group of people being able to hold another group of people or individuals to ransom.

On this side of the chamber we would argue that the processes which are now in place have served this nation particularly effectively and they have prevented a lot of industrial disputation. As an example, they have certainly prevented the situation whereby we would have had to go back to the wharves and load our live sheep. But that is not the only example. It extends into the coal industry; it extends into the iron ore industry; it extends into such things as perishables.

I can well remember the situation when the cauliflower growers down at Manjimup—and I would remind Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette that they got a few votes down there or in the proximity of that area at the last election—put their cauliflowers on the wharves in Fremantle to be loaded onto a particular vessel that was there at that time. There was a boycott placed on those cauliflowers and without the speed and effectiveness of section 45D, those vegetables would have rotted on the wharves.

We on this side of the chamber believe that it is absolutely crucial under sections 45D and 45E to have an effective remedy—an injunction—so the process of exporting those cauliflowers, for example, can continue. Had that not been in place at that time, the other processes in law would have been too slow. Not only would the cauliflower growers have been hurt severely—and they have legitimate rights and were far removed from the industrial dispute—but also our Asian friends, who would have been the recipients of those cauliflowers which would have been safe once they had been put in storage in the ship under proper cooling conditions, would have been disadvantaged and hurt.

Not only is it giving those people down at Manjimup a real biff under the ear, but it is also damaging our cauliflower trade. It was very much in its infancy and developing into Singapore and—dare I say it—Malaysia. The horticultural industry in Western Australia has been expanding by about 2 1/2 to three times on a year by year basis. It is continuing to expand. We are developing markets into Asia.

That injunction, as I understand it, still remains in place and has been a very effective mechanism to stop what I call this rogue behaviour. It does not prevent the people who had the disputation in the first place from using the proper processes to resolve their dispute, but it prevents the cauliflower growers from being damaged and the consumers or recipients of those cauliflowers being damaged—as well as the people who developed that export industry.

This example with perishables might seem to be very dramatic, but the principle applies right through, in terms of the importance of sections 45D and 45E in ensuring, firstly, that we protect our markets at the end; secondly, that we protect those businesses developing markets in the middle; and, thirdly, that we protect the producers at the other end of the scale. I want to emphasise that sections 45D and 45E are a proper mechanism for resolving these types of issues so they can be dealt with in a sensible, proper manner.

The alternative model is one of holding people to ransom and saying, `Do what I say', as a gun is pointed at their heads. That will not resolve the issue. Inevitably, this model will go out of the process. The government's alternatives do not satisfactorily resolve this situation. They would certainly have difficulty resolving the type of situation I described. When they go, this country will go back to people having no option but to take the law into their own hands.

That is what the loading of the live sheep issue was all about. That is what the effect will be with the cauliflower growers I have mentioned. Extraordinary damage will be done to our coal, iron ore and nickel industries—and others added one after the other. It is absolute lunacy by the Greens, the government or the Democrats that we are even contemplating removing these sections—or fiddling with them on the edges and saying we will come back to these aspects.

Not only will a lot of individuals pay a huge price because of the intimidation that will be brought against them, but it will also result in significant damage to a number of our export industries. That is regrettable, unfortunate and bad policy by all the people advocating that this legitimate protection be removed for people going about their everyday, lawful and legitimate business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the agreement that we would finish at 12 midnight and I do not intend in any way to conflict with that, but I seek advice from the opposition. Obviously there will be a stage in the course of this debate when we will have a major debate about sections 45D and E. This does not seem to me to be the place to have it because the government is opposed to this amendment, as the opposition is. This amendment is clearly going down, the government's proposal on sections 45D and E will come forward and I assume that a lot of opposition people will want to speak. I wonder whether we can deal with this amendment tonight and then adjourn, and have the major debate on it when the opposition's amendment to oppose our sections 45D and E proposal comes up.
—Put it to the vote now.
—If that is acceptable, I will say nothing more than that the government opposes this amendment, and we will seek to get it done tonight and go on from there.

—That is not the case as we understood it, but we are prepared to go along with it. The Australian Democrats will not support this amendment as proposed. I understand Senator Margetts's concerns with regard to the opportunity for sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act, as they have recently been interpreted, to deny the participation of environment, community or any other groups which want to protest about a number of matters and which have now recently been threatened with and effectively intimidated from taking part in such actions. But I believe that to delete sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act in their entirety would have other great far-reaching effects which would result in perhaps greater trauma than is being effected by their current, I suggest, misinterpretation anyway.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have attempted to redress the fact that these sections of the Trade Practices Act have been interpreted to apply to areas for which we believe they were not originally intended. Our reaction to that has been to support the removal of the industrial aspects of those particular provisions into the Industrial Relations Act and to there apply those measures which are appropriate under that regime.

To remove them in their entirety would, as I understood Senator Crane to say, permit any form of boycott action. If that were so, we do not have to use very much imagination to reach the situation where virtually a frontier attitude would prevail—a cowboy situation where we would have a couple of enterprises facing off at dawn saying, `This town ain't big enough for both of us'. This sort of ridiculous stand-off is not too far from reality, because if commercial boycotts could be permitted, then we would have the sort of mayhem which is seen in any community where there is a lack of regulation.

The regulation which subsections 45D and 45E bring to the supervision of commercial competition is appropriate. What is not appropriate is when those particular provisions have been used to prevent genuine protests, on the basis of environmental concerns and community matters unrelated to industrial matters, which are not part of a commercial boycott but are the only action left for people with concerns.

To be provocative, I might say that in the instance of the live sheep loading, my interpretation is that this is not an industrial matter relating to the working conditions or wage and salary payments of those involved; rather, it is an animal welfare consideration. That is the core of the matter, and however it was translated is in fact irrelevant. I would suggest that the primary motivation was animal welfare, and that whatever opportunities could be taken were taken to address it from that perspective.

I think it important that the opportunity to take that action is retained. With that in mind, the Democrats have followed the path that we have to ensure that those aspects of subsections 45D and 45E which apply to industrial action are preserved within the Industrial Relations Act, and that the interpretation is clear that those aspects of the Industrial Relations Act do not pertain to actions by environmental or community concern groups.

It is with that understanding that we see no need to repeal subsections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act in their entirety. We see many good reasons for the retention within the Trade Practices Act of those aspects which govern commercial competition. As Senator Crane mentioned, there have been circumstances where unions have taken action against unions under these provisions.

I say in passing that I hope there is some way—although I cannot see it under 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act—by which we are able to look at a government instrumentality, or a quasi-government instrumentality, as it has become, namely, the Federal Airports Corporation. It is interpreting its role in the competitive business of airport car rental firms in a thoroughly improper way. If there were any way I could interpret 45D and 45E to prevent the Federal Airports Corporation from continuing its persecution of small businesses trying to conduct their affairs at airports, I would. I cannot find a way yet, but that does not mean that I will give up.

Redress should be possible for activities contrary to fair play and commonsense, as well as for activities that work against true competitiveness among our commercial enterprises. People should be looking at what we need to do to properly preserve the opportunities for small businesses—and the Federal Airports Corporation would be a fine example with which to start. Those who come in here and rant and rave about how wonderful they are and the attention they pay to small business would do well to investigate a situation where, as I see it, small businesses are being persecuted by the Federal Airports Corporation.

We need provisions such as 45D and 45E, which are contained within the Trade Practices Act and which do not relate to industrial relations matters, to at least contend that we are making some effort to regulate the style of competition between small businesses that is appropriate. For all of the reasons I have stated, we will not be supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In defence of the Greens (WA) amendments, one of the reasons why this request has been made very strongly by the labour movement in Western Australia is that it lives daily with the implications of organisations or corporations which have the money and the resources to provide Queen's Counsel whenever they feel they can intimidate their workers into submission. This is not the case with every employer, but the provisions exist and while they do exist this will continue to happen.

PARA.TAB: While we are pleased that some provisions for the right to strike have been included, the secondary boycott exemptions that are written into the new legislation are very narrow and limited to the bargaining period. I have been told of examples, especially in remote areas, where it has been very difficult for workers to fight a problem, even if it is something which may affect their health or perhaps even their lives.

One example was a dangerous truck at one workplace. The matter went through an inquiry stage but not an inquest, so much of the information did not get out into the public arena. People in other workplaces which had similar, but not the same, equipment were not able, for their own workplace safety, to take their own strike action to ask their own companies to take action. They would have had to go to court to prove that there was a connection between what they were being asked to do and what the other company asked its workers to do. A worker was in fact killed in an accident involving a piece of equipment which was inappropriately altered by the company.

So whilst we are pleased with some of the changes that have been made in relation to the secondary boycott provisions, it is still foreseen that there will be occasions when the provisions of this legislation will be used against workers who have legitimate concerns, simply because it can be argued that it is something from another workplace and not their own and that it will be counted as a boycott rather than a legitimate primary strike.

There are still fights to be fought but the workers must fight the legal system without access to the resources that are available to the large corporations. That is why we have been asked to undertake what we know is a flag-waving exercise—because these problems still have not been fully addressed by the provisions for secondary boycotts within this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to draw the attention of the Senate to a report entitled Conservation of native forests: the changing role of the Australian Heritage Commission, prepared by Daniel Rosauer as part of a parliamentary internship placement in my office. The aim of the report was to evaluate and provide information on the role and impact of the Australian Heritage Commission regarding the conservation of native forest in Australia, with particular reference to the south-west forests of Western Australia and the WA AHC-CALM model for assessment of heritage values. This report is timely. The AHC is expected to formalise the placing of all identified forest areas in Western Australia on the interim list of the register of the National Estate this week.

PARA.TAB: Further, this is a particularly crucial time for forests throughout Australia. We are on the brink of yet another round of woodchip export licence renewals and, as we rapidly approach the summer logging season, woodchippers are poised to move into irreplaceable areas of forrest of extreme beauty and high conservation value. I present this report to emphasise the valuable contribution that the Australian Heritage Commission can make to the protection of such areas while highlighting the shortcomings of the West Australian AHC-CALM joint study and the dangers that this approach poses to that protection.
In view of the lateness of the hour, I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the speech and table the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Reid

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not our practice to agree to speeches being incorporated. It being a report prepared by an intern working in a senator's office at the request, I think, of the parliament, in this situation we will agree.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: At a time when large tracts of native forest are under threat, there is a great need to accurately identify, and protect, wilderness areas, old growth forest and other areas of high conservation value. In the West Australian context, the AHC has done neither. While the AHC does not have a mandate to protect forests, it is expected to identify places to be included in the national estate and advise on matters relating on conservation, preservation and improvement of the national estate. However, by having to take into account forest management, its independence has been compromised. It has not adequately nor accurately identified forest areas that should be protected and, by its acceptance of CALM's management practices, it has implicitly endorsed the destruction of national estate forest by logging and burning.

There are some things that the AHC has done well. There is a need for a credible, nationwide inventory of high conservation value wilderness, old growth and other kinds of forest and the AHC has an important contribution to make to this inventory. AHC identification of such areas, and similar inventories, play a vital role in the preservation of our natural and cultural heritage. The AHC provides a valuable source of advice and information to governments and others involved in planning decisions. The method of regional assessment developed in WA is an improvement on the former, ad hoc examination of individual areas as nominations were made and it allows for the better identification of a particular area's value.

However, in the West Australian context, insufficient and outdated data, the lack of onsite confirmation of data and lack of public consultation means that the joint assessment does not comprehensively assess national estate values. There are additional areas of immense value that will not have been identified in this assessment. Further if the AHC is to be effective, it must be able to independently assess the conservation value of places of outstanding natural or cultural beauty. Involving the commission in management decisions, as was the case in WA, places that independence at risk. As Mr Rosauer points out:

"Instead of producing an independent audit of conservation values, to be weighed against other needs and priorities, the AHC has issued its advice `pre-weighed', with compromises to logging already incorporated, through its endorsement for CALM's management plans and timber production levels."

In conclusion, the AHC assessment process could make a valuable contribution to the preservation of our native forests. However the WA AHC/CALM assessment process, is a dangerous model and, contrary to the Government's recommendations in the `One Nation' statement, it should not be adopted by other states. Further, there is little point in identifying areas that need protection if we do not provide for that protection and allow them to be logged. State governments in WA, Victoria, NSW, Tasmania and Queensland have done little to stop logging activities that destroy the value of these areas. The onus is now clearly on the Federal Government to implement the National Forest Policy Statement and employ all its available powers to protect the AHC listed places before they are irrevocably lost.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) recommend chemical exposure concentrations which are safe to those exposed to such chemicals.
(2) Why has the Australian Allowable Exposure Concentrations of Glycol Ethers always been well above the United States (US) allowable levels.
(3) Why is the Australian allowable level for Ethylene Glycol Mono Butyl Ether 5 times that of the US.

(4) Is the NHMRC in possession of data on Glycol Ethers which is contrary to the data available to the US Environment Protection Agency from which it has concluded that `based on current data the agency is not able to establish a molecular size or weight above which there are no concerns for acute or chronic health effects'.

(5) What action has the NHMRC taken on Glycol Ethers since its 94th session in 1984, where it recommended, `that because of the strong animal evidence of reproductive toxicity of these substances, together with the animal and human evidence of haematological toxicity, manufacturers and users of the ethers should ensure that the atmosphere levels be kept as low as technically feasible and that skin contact be avoided'.
(6) Has the NHMRC performed tests or studies as to the effects of Glycol Ethers on cleaners using products containing these chemicals.
(7) How does the NHMRC receive feedback on the health effects of and numbers of people affected by chemicals such as Glycol Ethers.
(8) When was the last review of Glycol Ether data performed in relation to health effects and safe levels of exposure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The NHMRC does not recommend chemical exposure concentrations which are safe to those exposed to glycol ethers or related industrial chemicals.
(2) & (3) As neither my Department nor the NHMRC has a role in recommending Australian Allowable Exposure Concentrations, I am unable to answer the honourable senator's questions.
(4) I do not know what data the US Environment Protection Agency possesses and so I am unable to answer the honourable senator's question.

(5) The recommendation from the 94th session of the NHMRC in 1982 arose from a report of the former Occupational Health Committee to the former Public Health Advisory Committee. With the creation of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in the mid-1980s, responsibility for exposure standards for industrial chemicals passed to WORKSAFE Australia, and the NHMRC Occupational Health Committee was abolished. No further action has therefore been taken by the NHMRC.
(6) The NHMRC does not perform tests of this type.

(7) The NHMRC does not routinely collect information of this type. Matters of concern may be brought to the attention of the NHMRC by State health authorities and other agencies. Information on the incidence of poisonings by various classes of chemicals may be available from State Poisons Information Centres.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 18 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) On what basis are Defence Service Home Loan interest rates set and adjusted.
(2) What adjustments have been made since the current downward trend in commercial home loan rates began, and what future adjustments are planned.
(3) Are borrowers able to make special payments to reduce the size of their loans; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Matters relating to Defence Service Homes are covered under my Ministerial responsibility for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) DSH interest rates are set in legislation. They are designed to be concessional against prevailing market rates and fixed for the life of the loan. The interest rates on DSH loans vary according to the amounts of advances and when they are made, but the maximum rate on loans, other than supplementary loans, is currently 6.85%. This rate was introduced when the Westpac Bank acquired the lending rights in 1987. Loans granted prior to that had fixed interest rates as follows:
10% on $15,001—$25,000, which is an effective rate of 6.8485%.

(2) None. Successive Governments have seen fit not to adjust the concessional DSH interest rate in line with the variations in market rates. If the Government was to tie the DSH interest rate to changes in market rates, when interest rates increase, the DSH rate would increase to more than 6.85% per annum.
The Government has no plans for adjustment of DSH interest rates.
(3) Yes. DSH borrowers are able to make prepayments off their loan. For those with a tiered loan, any such payments are apportioned across the tiers so that each tier reduces proportionately .
